{"uri": "8118149589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:34:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:34:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://sea.ign.com/news/215447/baby-reindeer-took-every-reasonable-precaution-to-protect-subjects-identities-netflix-tells-uk-parli", "title": "Baby Reindeer Took 'Every Reasonable Precaution' to Protect Subjects' Identities, Netflix Tells UK Parliament", "body": "This post might contain affiliation links. If you buy something through this post, the publisher may get a share of the sale.\n\nNetflix made its first public comments about the online sleuthing surrounding its hit British stalker drama Baby Reindeer, telling a U.K. Parliament committee that it took pains to disguise the real-life identities that were the basis of its characters.\n\nBenjamin King, Netflix's Senior Director of Public Policy in the U.K. and Ireland, addressed the scrutiny around the series in a Wednesday hearing with the Parliament's Culture, Media and Sport Committee. While the hearing was generally about policy around British film and \"high-end television\" and also included execs from Prime Video U.K., NBCUniversal International, and Paramount, one Paraliament committee member asked King about Baby Reindeer in particular, pointing out that fans had seemingly found the real-life identity of the woman who was the basis of the stalker of the show.\n\n\"Baby Reindeer is an extrodinary story, and it is obviously a true story of the horrific abuse that the writer and protagonist, Richard Gadd, suffered at the hands of a convicted stalker,\" King began. \"We did take every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story in the making of the show while also striking a balance of veracity and authenticity of Richard's story, because we didn't want to anonymize that or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story, because that would undermine the intent behind the show.\"\n\n\"I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced.\n\nAs King noted, the creator and star of Baby Reindeer, comedian Richard Gadd, tells his the true story of his extensive stalking situation in the British series. Gadd has previously spoken about the lengths he went to keep viewers from being able to find the woman that the stalker character, Martha (played by Jessica Gunning), is based on, but as Baby Reindeer surged in popularity, online sleuths seemingly tracked her down.\n\nAfter fans claimed to have found another real-life person portrayed in the series, former Gadd collaborator Sean Foley, Gadd released a statement saying, \"Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. That's not the point of our show.\" Foley said on X/Twitter that police had been investigating \"all defamatory abusive and threatening posts against me\" in the wake of fans accusing him of being portrayed in the series.\n\nDuring the hearing, King further defended Baby Reindeer and Netflix's approach to its real-life subject, adding that they worked with U.K. stalker helpline Suzy Lamplugh Trust in the promotion and launch of the series.\n\n\"Richard Gadd was very clear that that was not the intent of the show, that it should inspire people to try and track down the real-life individuals,\" King added. \"Ultimately, it's obviously difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media. But fundamentally, this is about Richard's story and telling Richard's story in a truthful way. I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell his story.\"\n\nKing went on to say that they're \"following the situation very closely.\" When asked if the production had reached out to the real-life Martha in the making of the series, King said it wouldn't be \"appropriate\" for him to delve into specifics, and that he didn't \"want to give further fuel to some of the theories which are circling on the internet.\"\n\nMartha Seemingly Comes Forward\n\nDespite the attempted secrecy on the part of the production, a woman that's been targeted by fans and is claiming to be the woman that Baby Reindeer's Martha is based on, Fiona Harvey, has come forward herself. Piers Morgan announced earlier today that he's conducting an interview with Harvey, which will air on Thursday, and that she wants to \"set the record straight.\"\n\nHarvey previously said in an interview with Daily Record UK that she's considering legal action due to the disruption to her life that's come from the series.\n\nBaby Reindeer debuted on Netflix on April 11 and has since become a massive hit for the streaming platform, regularly appearing at the top of its Top 10 most-viewed chart. It's gotten raves from critics as well, with IGN's own 9/10 review saying it \"pulls no punches and raises the bar for Netflix originals.\"\n\nAlex Stedman is a Senior News Editor with IGN, overseeing entertainment reporting. When she's not writing or editing, you can find her reading fantasy novels or playing Dungeons & Dragons.", "source": {"uri": "sea.ign.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "IGN Southeast Asia"}, She will also say she will be taking legal action.\n\nHowever, she is also expected to admit she uses four phones as 'I like keeping people on separate phones'.\n\nBaby Reindeer's 'Martha' has said her real name is Fiona Harvey in a bombshell Piers Morgan interview about Richard Gadd's Netflix stalking drama\n\nThe 48-year-old alleged stalker is pictured on Morgan's programme\n\nThe show has been a global success and follows 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning) as she stalks aspiring comedian Richard Gadd - who is called Donny Dunn in the show\n\nPiers Morgan has dropped the first trailer ahead of his interview with the 'real-life Martha' from Baby Reindeer, which is set to air on Thursday evening at 8pm\n\nBaby Reindeer, the extraordinary hit Netflix drama, has been viewed more than 60 million times in the past month\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd at the hands of 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning, right)\n\nThe clip of the interview sees Morgan grilling the alleged stalker on everything from her views on Richard Gadd to whether she has ever been to prison\n\nMorgan has already faced a backlash from mental health campaigners and survivors of stalking over his 'irresponsible' decision to interview the woman.\n\nMailOnline had until now chosen not to name and picture her. But following her appearance with Piers Morgan we have decided to publish her picture.\n\nToday, the alleged stalker hit out at Morgan, saying she felt she had been 'set up' during her appearance on his show.\n\nThe Scottish woman broke her silence in her first ever TV interview with Piers tonight at 8pm.\n\nYet before the t\u00eate-\u00e0-t\u00eate with the celebrity interviewer even aired, the woman has already gone on the offensive, saying she is 'not happy' and felt she was being 'set up' by the interviewer.\n\nDescribing the 30-minute grilling as a 'sparring match', the alleged female stalker has accused Morgan of trying to 'trip her up' with his questions.\n\nRead More The real-life 'Martha' from Baby Reindeer is now targeting ME: I've had a four-day barrage of non-stop calls and terrifying messages just like on the Netflix show, writes NEIL SEARS. As I type, the phone is ringing again...\n\n'Piers kept saying to me ''are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?''. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this,' she told the Daily Record.\n\n'I said, ''Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff''. As I said, in order to bill something as a ''true story'', it's got to be pretty much 100 per cent true.'\n\nShe added: 'It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.'\n\nThe Piers Morgan Uncensored special is airing on the broadcaster's YouTube channel, which has 2.58million subscribers.\n\nThe woman will be looking to 'set the record straight' as she breaks her silence following Baby Reindeer's global success, the preview said.\n\nBefore her big interview, she paid a visit to celebrity hairdresser John Hala - who has styled the barnets of A-listers Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sigourney Weaver, Elle MacPherson and Kate Moss - at his salon in London's Canary Wharf.\n\nSpeaking to the Daily Record, she claimed she was paid \u00a3250 for the interview and had turned down requests from the likes of This Morning to talk about Baby Reindeer.\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd - who is called Donny Dunn in the show.\n\nWorking as a struggling stand-up comic, Dunn first meets his stalker after he offered 'a crying stranger a cup of tea' while he was working at a bar in London.\n\nBaby Reindeer delves into Richard's harrowing real-life stalking ordeal and brutal sexual abuse as he plays a fictionalised version of himself called Donny Dunn (pictured)\n\nThings rapidly turn sinister, with the series claiming 'Martha' bombarded the 34-year-old from Fife with more than 41,000 emails.\n\nShe also sent him hundreds of tweets and and flooded his phone with hours of voicemails over an alleged four-year campaign of terror.\n\nPosting ahead of the show, Morgan said: 'The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.'\n\nHe added: 'Is she a psycho stalker? Find out on Piers Morgan Uncensored.'\n\nBaby Reindeer has proven a surprise smash for Netflix, having been viewed more than 60 million times in the first month.\n\nRiding on the show's phenomenal success, the cast were pictured attending a swanky screening in Los Angeles on Wednesday.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning - who plays Martha - beamed as they posed arm in arm and joined Nava Mau and others for a Q and A on stage.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning attended a photo call for a screening in LA on Tuesday\n\nThe actress looked worlds away from her role as Martha and had a glamorous Hollywood makeover as they took to the stage\n\nOver four and a half years, Gadd says he received 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, letters totalling 106 pages and 350 hours of voicemail messages from the older woman, whom he calls Martha in the show\n\nHowever, the show's runaway success has been far from a joy for the 'real-life' Martha, who claimed she had been left a 'victim' by its surprise popularity.\n\nSpeaking exclusively to Mail+ last month, the woman insisted she was not a stalker and said: 'He's using Baby Reindeer to stalk me now. I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me.'\n\nShe accused Gadd of having 'main character syndrome' and claimed she had faced 'bullying' as a result of the show and was now considering legal action against him.\n\n'He always thinks he's at the centre of things. I'm not writing shows about him or promoting them in the media, am I? If he wanted me to be properly anonymous, he could have done so. Gadd should leave me alone,' she added.\n\nGadd claimed he went to great lengths to conceal the identity of the woman who stalked him in real life.\n\nDespite the comic begging fans not to search for the real 'Martha', internet sleuths went on to claim she was the inspiration for the character.\n\nIn the series, after Gadd meets his stalker at the bar, things soon descend into chaos.\n\nIt sees him being regularly followed at home and work, and tracked on Facebook using three fake accounts.\n\nRichard Gadd was a struggling stand-up comic working behind the bar at a pub in London\n\nHe told The Times: 'At first everyone at the pub thought it was funny that I had an admirer. Then she started to invade my life, following me, turning up at my gigs, waiting outside my house, sending thousands of voicemails and emails.'\n\nRead More Baby Reindeer knocked off Netflix's top spot by new 'must-watch' drama - but it's left people completely divided\n\nIt developed to terrifying lengths as the crazed fan got closer to her obsession - including her turning up at his gigs, his workplace and bombarding him with messages.\n\nThe actor and comedian was subjected to a campaign of obsession by the woman, known as Martha, that manifested in 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, 106 pages of letters and a staggering 350 hours of voicemail.\n\nHe says it was 'years' before the police eventually took his complaints seriously - and six years before they finally intervened - something which prolonged the agony for everyone involved including his relatives.\n\nThe police told him at the time that unless his stalker became physically violent, there was little they could do to resolve the issue.\n\nHe has said he still finds it hard to trust people and has had 'every therapy going'.\n\nHe added that the years of being stalked have left him with something 'like PTSD'. For the Netflix role, he lost weight to match his 10-and-a-half stone 'neurotic' self at the height of his own stalking nightmare.\n\nGadd has revealed he first encountered 'Martha' when he was working in a pub and offered her a cup of tea because she was crying\n\nRead More Who is the real-life stalker from Netflix hit Baby Reindeer and where is she now? Fans of 'mind-blowing' show desperately search for woman who made Scottish comedian's life a misery\n\nGadd says he's currently single and 'is more cautious' of people because of the campaign of terror that Martha inflicted, saying: 'It takes me a long time to trust them. Before, I entered situations with such abandonment and I got burnt.'\n\nHowever, performing a version of what happened to him has enabled him to have 'ownership' of the trauma. Gadd earned a Fringe award for his show, also called Baby Reindeer, in 2019.\n\nSpeaking to the Telegraph in 2019 about the one-man show that he wrote after the ordeal, which is currently on at London's Bush theatre, he said: 'It was debilitating beyond belief.\n\n'I'd listen to her voicemails and just feel my eyes welling up. They were tears of frustration. Proper brain-heavy stress.'\n\nMailOnline has approached Piers Morgan and Gadd for comment.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8119371464", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:13:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:13:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:11:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/tv/baby-reindeer-martha-interview-watch-32772302", "title": "How to watch Piers Morgan's interview with Baby Reindeer's real life Martha", "body": "The woman who is alleged to have inspired Richard Gadd's acclaimed true life Netflix drama Baby Reindeer will 'set the record straight' in an 'explosive' interview with Piers Morgan.\n\nIn the hit Netflix series, Gadd plays a fictionalised version of himself who gets stalked by a lonely and mentally ill woman in her 40s called Martha, whom he meets while working at a pub.\n\nIn the seven-episode series, which draws on events that occurred in Gadd's real life, Martha sends Gadd's character over 41,000 emails, over 350 hours of voice mails, 106 pages of letters and countless social media messages, as well as constantly turning up to his home and place of work.\n\nAfter Baby Reindeer aired on Netflix, some viewers tried to track down the real-life characters from the show - including Martha.\n\nREAD MORE:The chilling true story behind Richard Gadd's Netflix stalker drama Baby Reindeer\n\nFollowing much speculation, Scottish woman Fiona Harvey revealed her identity to The Daily Record over the weekend.\n\nHarvey said that she made the decision to identify herself \"because people have to know what is going on,\" as she described the Netflix series as 'a load of rubbish.'\n\nThe 58-year-old will now share her side of the story with Piers Morgan for what she has described as her first \"big TV interview\".\n\nHow to watch Piers Morgan interview with Fiona Harvey\n\nPiers Morgan's interview with Fiona Harvey is titled \"The Real Martha Uncensored\" and will be available to watch on the YouTube channel Piers Morgan Uncensored.\n\nThe interview will steam live from 8pm in the UK and Ireland, and will be available to watch from 3pm ET in the US.\n\nIn a post shared on X, formerly Twitter, on Wednesday, Morgan was pictured alongside Harvey, as he wrote: \"The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show. Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nWhat will Fiona Harvey discuss in the interview?\n\nThe interview will see Morgan grill Harvey over allegations that she became obsessed with Gadd and carried out a years-long stalking campaign against the comedian.\n\nThe interview was recorded earlier this week, with Harvey claiming that she felt \"set up\" and \"used\" by Morgan, who asked her several questions about the emails she sent to Gadd.\n\n\"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent,\" Harvey told the Daily Record.\n\n\"I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself but I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast-paced to catch me off guard.\n\n\"Piers kept saying to me 'Are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?'. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this.\n\n\"I said, 'Look, Even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff. As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100 per cent true.\n\n\"It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nHarvey described her interview as a \"sparring match\" and said was forced to refute claims by Morgan that she \"loved\" Gadd.\n\nShe also revealed that she was paid \u00a3250 for the interview and said that Morgan told her it \"went well.\"\n\n\"He referred to it as a sparring match,\" she said. \"He landed a few punches on me and I landed a few punches on him. He asked me if I loved Richard Gadd and I said you've got to be joking.\"\n\nWhat has Richard Gadd said about the 'real-life Martha?\n\nGadd hasn't publicly commented directly about Harvey but the comedian has urged fans to stop trying to uncover the identities of the real people who inspired the Netflix show.\n\nGadd has previously made it clear that certain details of his real stalking experience were omitted from the drama, and that he wanted to conceal the identity of his stalker, so as not to harm her.\n\n\"We've gone to such great lengths to disguise her to the point that I don't think she would recognise herself,\" he said.\n\nWhen asked whether he worried that Baby Reindeer could cause his real-life stalker to re-engage with him, Gadd said: \"The situation did result in a situation, shall we say, where she cannot contact me again.\"\n\nSign up for our daily newsletter to get the latest news direct to your inbox\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. and we can't wait.\n\nViewers can't get enough of Netflix's number one show, which follows comedian Richard Gadd, who plays a fictionalised version of himself.\n\nWhile working at the local pub, things take a sinister turn when he gets stalked by a woman called Martha.\n\nAfter watching all seven episodes, viewers have been predicting who they think the 'real-life' characters are and have been warned against doing so.\n\nBaby Reindeer creator Gadd has urged people not to speculate on who some people from the show might be in real life, while some wrongly accused one man of being Darrien, eventually causing police intervention.\n\nLegal experts have also warned of the 'significant legal and ethical implications' of fans who try to 'track down' people from the show.\n\nAmid all the speculation, the woman who has been dubbed the 'real-life Martha' has sat down with Morgan for an episode of Piers Morgan Uncensored.\n\nThe celebrity interviewer tweeted out a picture of himself and a woman named Fiona Harvey, saying she wanted to 'set the record straight' and 'have her say'.\n\nThe interview will be available to watch tonight (9 May) on YouTube via the Piers Morgan Uncensored account.\n\nThe show will stream live at 8.00pm in the UK and 3.00pm ET in the US.\n\nShe told the Daily Record that Morgan refused to accept her side of the story, saying: \"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent.\n\n\"I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself but I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.\n\n\"Piers kept saying to me 'are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?'. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this.\n\n\"I said, 'Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff. As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100% true.\n\n\"It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nHarvey has claimed that she was paid just \u00a3250 to appear on Morgan's TalkTV show.\n\n\"Piers said it went well. He referred to it as a sparring match. He landed a few punches on me and I landed a few punches on him,\" she added.\n\n\"He asked me if I loved Richard Gadd and I said you've got to be joking.\"\n\nWhile Richard Gadd claims Baby Reindeer is based on a true story, many viewers have been left questioning which parts were fabricated for the Netflix show.\n\nWe've separated the facts from the fiction.\n\nIn Baby Reindeer, Gadd's character Donny offers Martha a free drink after feeling sorry for her when she said she couldn't afford one.\n\nGadd claims this is true and his seemingly harmless act of kindness quickly snowballed into a shocking turn of events.\n\nGadd says his stalker sent him 41,071 emails, 350 hours of voicemail, 744 tweets, 46 Facebook messages and 106 pages of letters over four-and-a-half years.\n\nIn real life, she also reportedly sent him a variety of strange gifts, including a reindeer toy, sleeping pills, a woolly hat and boxers.\n\nNetflix said that every email Donny receives in the show is real, all of which end with 'sent from my iPhone' - despite the fact she didn't have an iPhone and wasn't emailing from one.\n\nIn the series, Donny wasn't taken seriously when he initially reported Martha to the police.\n\nAccording to Gadd, it was six years before they finally intervened.\n\nGadd has spoken about how some details of the show have been changed to protect identities of those involved.\n\nHe explained that 'Martha' had been disguised to such an extent that he doesn't think she'd 'recognise herself'.\n\nIt's also unclear whether the real-life Martha went to prison. Fiona Harvey says she's never been to jail.\n\nIn Baby Reindeer, Martha was sentenced to nine months in prison and given a five-year restraining order.\n\nThough Gadd told The Times the stalking issue has been 'resolved', adding that he 'mixed feelings about it' because he 'didn't want to throw someone who was that level of mentally unwell in prison'.", "source": {"uri": "ladbible.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8118940860", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:24:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:24:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:23:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/tv/11211064/fiona-harvey-baby-reindeer-real-life-martha-stalker/", "title": "Meet the woman accused of being real-life stalker Martha from Baby Reindeer", "body": "AFTER Baby Reindeer dropped on Netflix, fans became obsessed with tracking down the 'real life' woman that stalker Martha Scott is based on.\n\nThe mini-series is based on a true story inspired by an ordeal suffered by writer Richard Gadd, and now the alleged 'real stalker' Fiona Harvey is having her say on Piers Morgan's Uncensored.\n\nFiona Harvey from Fyvie, Aberdeenshire hit the spotlight following claims from armchair detectives that she was the 'real Martha' in Baby Reindeer.\n\nAfter weeks of speculation, the Scot said that she had met comedian Richard Gadd years ago when he was a bartender at The Hawley Arms in London's Camden.\n\nSpeaking to The Scottish Sun she admitted to befriending him, but denied she ever stalked him.\n\nAs for how she discovered Baby Reindeer, Fiona said she first became aware of it when Richard took it to Edinburgh Fringe Festival as a one-man show.\n\nShe said: \"He's come up with this character called Martha and he has put me right in the frame.\n\n\"This is a programme for the 20-somethings. The people with no lives, no jobs, whatever. I don't want to be a celebrity.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer follows Richard Gadd's character Donny as he works behind a bar while struggling to make it as a comic.\n\nOne day an emotional Martha walks in and he offers her a free cup of tea when she says she has no money.\n\nShe tells him she is a lawyer, but it soon becomes clear there is more to Martha than meets the eye.\n\nOver the coming episodes, Donny finds himself sent thousands of emails and texts from Martha, who affectionately refers to him as 'Baby Reindeer'.\n\nThe series takes many dark twists and turns as it delves into the trauma from Donny's own past, as well as confronting Martha's demons.\n\nThe show has become a huge breakout hit for Netflix, garnering millions of viewers across the globe and topping the chart in more than thirty countries.\n\nIt has even won praise from the master of horror, bestselling author Stephen King.\n\nRichard Gadd opened up about how important it was for him to tackle the tough themes highlighted in the autobiographical series.\n\n\"When a man gets stalked, it can be portrayed in films and television as a sexy thing. Like a femme fatale who gradually becomes more sinister,\" he told The Times.\n\nHe continued: \"It doesn't carry as much threat of physical violence, is less common and can be trivialised.\n\n\"I was physically scared because I didn't know how far she could take it.\"\n\nHe has admitted that some elements of the show have been dramatised to create added suspense.\n\nHowever, Richard also urged viewers not to target or look for the real life woman that made his life so uncomfortable.\n\nHe also claimed he went to great lengths to conceal the identity of the woman who stalked him in real life.\n\nTaking to social media Richard wrote: \"People I love, have worked with, and admire... are unfairly getting caught up in speculation.\n\n\"Please don't speculate on who any of the real-life people could be. That's not the point of our show. Lots of love, Richard.\"\n\nWARNING: The below contains some spoilers from Baby Reindeer\n\nIn the final episode of Baby Reindeer, viewers watched as Martha was jailed for stalking Donny.\n\nThis has led to fans wondering if Fiona ever went to jail for allegedly stalking Richard Gadd.\n\nSpeaking to the Daily Record, she said: \"Gadd needs to prove I went to jail, which just didn't happen.\n\n\"I've never been sent to jail. That is blatantly obvious.\"\n\nThroughout Baby Reindeer the character of Martha claims to be a lawyer.\n\nFiona has also revealed she is a lawyer, and that she studied law in Aberdeen.\n\nIn fact, she told us that she will use her legal skills to 'sue Netflix' over her alleged representation in Baby Reindeer.\n\nSpeaking exclusively to The Scottish Sun, Fiona said: \"I have a claim against Netflix as this is being billed as part of a true story.\n\n\"I'm a highly competent lawyer. I'd have to do it myself. I'm very good.\n\n\"I have a photographic memory and can memorise huge files. I was top in my school at everything.\"\n\nShortly after the armchair detectives claimed that Fiona was the 'real Martha' she hit out at Richard Gadd on social media.\n\nShe tweeted: \"My boyfriend thinks Gadds is angry that he never freckin got me in the bedsheets.\n\nAgain speaking to The Scottish Sun, she had some very harsh words.\n\nFiona said: \"There's a fat actress that's supposed to be me.\n\n\"He's come up with this character called Martha and he has put me right in the frame.\"\n\nShe added: \"I don't want to be a celebrity.\"\n\nTalented actress Jessica has enjoyed an incredible career so far, which includes starring in high profile shows like the comedy-drama The Outlaws which was directed by Stephen Merchant.\n\nFiona will now break her silence on Baby Reindeer in an exclusive interview with Piers Morgan.\n\nOver the US, you can stream the chat from 3pm ET and 12pm PT.\n\nAfter this time, you can continue to stream it on the Piers Morgan Uncensored YouTube Channel.\n\nPromoting the must see TV, Piers told fans: \"Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.\n\n\"Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.'\n\n\"Is she a psycho stalker? It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.\n\n\"Piers kept saying to me 'are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?'. As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100% true.\n\n\"It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nThe interview will be available to watch on YouTube via the Piers Morgan Uncensored account.\n\nThe show will stream live at 8.00pm in the UK and 3pm ET in the US.\n\nWhile Richard Gadd claims Baby Reindeer is based on a true story, many viewers have been left questioning which parts were fabricated for the Netflix show.\n\nWe've separated the facts from the fiction.\n\nIn Baby Reindeer, Gadd's character Donny offers Martha a free drink after feeling sorry for her when she said she couldn't afford one.\n\nGadd claims this is true and his seemingly harmless act of kindness quickly snowballed into a shocking turn of events.\n\nGadd says his stalker sent him 41,071 emails, 350 hours of voicemail, 744 tweets, 46 Facebook messages and 106 pages of letters over four-and-a-half years.\n\nIn real life, she also reportedly sent him a variety of strange gifts, including a reindeer toy, sleeping pills, a woolly hat and boxers.\n\nNetflix said that every email Donny receives in the show is real, all of which end with 'sent from my iPhone' - despite the fact she didn't have an iPhone and wasn't emailing from one.\n\nIn the series, Donny wasn't taken seriously when he initially reported Martha to the police.\n\nAccording to Gadd, it was six years before they finally intervened.\n\nGadd has spoken about how some details of the show have been changed to protect identities of those involved.\n\nHe explained that 'Martha' had been disguised to such an extent that he doesn't think she'd 'recognise herself'.\n\nIt's also unclear whether the real-life Martha went to prison. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this,' she told the Daily Record.\n\nRead More 'I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me': The alleged female stalker whose story has gripped the world in Netflix hit baby Reindeer tells HER side of the story and claims 'I'm being bullied for fame'\n\n'I said, \"Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff\". Find out on Piers Morgan Uncensored.'\n\nBaby Reindeer has proven a surprise smash for Netflix, having been viewed more than 60 million times in the first month.\n\nRiding on the show's phenomenal success, the cast were pictured attending a swanky screening in Los Angeles on Wednesday.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning - who plays Martha - beamed as they posed arm in arm and joined Nava Mau and others for a Q and A on stage.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning continued to ride the wave of Baby Reindeer being a huge Netflix hit as they attended the photo call for the screening in LA on Tuesday\n\nThe actress looked worlds away from her role as Martha and had a glamorous Hollywood makeover as they took to the stage\n\nOver four and a half years, Gadd says he received 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, letters totalling 106 pages and 350 hours of voicemail messages from the older woman, whom he calls Martha in the show\n\nHowever, the show's runaway success has been far from a joy for the 'real-life' Martha, who claimed she had been left a 'victim' by its surprise popularity.\n\nSpeaking exclusive to Mail+ last month, the woman insisted she was not a stalker and said: 'He's using Baby Reindeer to stalk me now. I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me.'\n\nRead More The real-life 'Martha' from Baby Reindeer is now targeting ME: I've had a four-day barrage of non-stop calls and terrifying messages just like on the Netflix show, writes NEIL SEARS. As I type, the phone is ringing again...\n\nShe accused Gadd of having 'main character syndrome' and claimed she had faced 'bullying' as a result of the show and was now considering legal action against him.\n\n'He always thinks he's at the centre of things. I'm not writing shows about him or promoting them in the media, am I? If he wanted me to be properly anonymous, he could have done so. Gadd should leave me alone,' she added.\n\nGadd claimed he went to great lengths to conceal the identity of the woman who stalked him in real life.\n\nDespite the comic begging fans not to search for the real 'Martha', internet sleuths went on to claim she was the inspiration for the character.\n\nIn the series, after Gadd meets his stalker at the bar, things soon descend into chaos.\n\nIt sees him being regularly followed at home and work, and tracked on Facebook using three fake accounts.\n\nFans of Netflix series Baby Reindeer claimed they revealed Martha's true identity (played by Jessica Gunning in the show)\n\nRichard Gadd was a struggling stand-up comic working behind the bar at a pub in London\n\nHe told The Times: 'At first everyone at the pub thought it was funny that I had an admirer. Then she started to invade my life, following me, turning up at my gigs, waiting outside my house, sending thousands of voicemails and emails.'\n\nRead More Baby Reindeer knocked off Netflix's top spot by new 'must-watch' drama - but it's left people completely divided\n\nIt developed to terrifying lengths as the crazed fan got closer to her obsession - including her turning up at his gigs, his workplace and bombarding him with messages.\n\nThe actor and comedian was subjected to a campaign of obsession by the woman, known as Martha, that manifested in 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, 106 pages of letters and a staggering 350 hours of voicemail.\n\nHe says it was 'years' before the police eventually took his complaints seriously - and six years before they finally intervened - something which prolonged the agony for everyone involved including his relatives.\n\nThe police told him at the time that unless his stalker became physically violent, there was little they could do to resolve the issue.\n\nHe has said he still finds it hard to trust people and has had 'every therapy going'.\n\nHe added that the years of being stalked have left him with something 'like PTSD'. For the Netflix role, he lost weight to match his 10-and-a-half stone 'neurotic' self at the height of his own stalking nightmare.\n\nGadd has revealed he first encountered 'Martha' when he was working in a pub and offered her a cup of tea because she was crying\n\nGadd says he's currently single and 'is more cautious' of people because of the campaign of terror that Martha inflicted, saying: 'It takes me a long time to trust them. Before, I entered situations with such abandonment and I got burnt.'\n\nRead More Who is the real-life stalker from Netflix hit Baby Reindeer and where is she now? Fans of 'mind-blowing' show desperately search for woman who made Scottish comedian's life a misery\n\nHowever, performing a version of what happened to him has enabled him to have 'ownership' of the trauma. Details explored", "body": "Richard Gadd's Baby Reindeer has taken the streaming platform by storm after it was released in April 2024 on Netflix. Following an autobiographical account of Gadd which traces an experience he had in his 20s of being stalked by a customer at a bar where he worked, Gadd had initially created a one-man show, which eventually led to the hit comedy-drama series.\n\nThe series stars Jessica Gunning as Martha Scott, a criminal lawyer with a concerning past who was effectively the stalker in the series. As the story is based on real life, Piers Morgan has landed an interview with the real-life Martha Scott, shedding light on her perspective of the story as she aims to disprove the notion that she is merely a 'stalker.'\n\nMorgan, an investigative journalist, television personality, and author, has held a range of big interviews in recent years, with the real-life Martha Scott, named Fiona Harvey, intent to have her say on the matter.\n\nThe interview is set to air live on Thursday, May 9, at 8 PM ET and will be available to be live-streamed on Morgan's YouTube Channel.\n\nWhere to watch Piers Morgan's interview with Baby Reindeer's real-life Martha Scott?\n\nIn an earlier post announcing the iconic interview, Morgan had noted the following on his X account earlier --\n\n\"The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show. Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nSince then, the interviewer has posted several updates about the live stream. Find out tomorrow on @piersmorganuncensored.\"\n\nThe trailer text for the interview reads: \"The 'real Martha' from Baby Reindeer tomorrow on Piers Morgan Uncensored.\n\n\"sent from my ihphone.\"\n\nIn Baby Reindeer, the Martha character often signs off her emails as if they were sent from an iPhone - despite being from her laptop - and are misspelt in a variety of ways.\n\nScots law graduate Fiona, 58, previously branded Gadd 'pathetic' in a savage social media blast.\n\nShe wrote online: \"Everything about Gadd will not be talked about now until after my TV show.\n\n\"I hope you all tune in. The explosive real truth about Gadd is finally out.\"\n\nMs Harvey added: \"I'm very nervous about my TV appearance.\"\n\nGadd, 34, claimed he went to great lengths to conceal the identity of the {"uri": "2024-05-350640193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:52:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:52:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:10:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.cbr.com/baby-reindeer-martha-fiona-harvey-interview/", "title": "Baby Reindeer's Real-Life Martha Hopes New Interview Will 'Set the Record Straight'", "body": "Netflix's hit show Baby Reindeer's real-life \"Martha\" tells her side of the story in a new interview denying allegations of stalking.\n\nBaby Reindeer's popularity has only grown since its release, topping the Netflix charts. However, the real-life person who inspired the show's stalker Martha Scott is not happy about it, having sat down for an interview to tell her side of the story.\n\nCreated by Richard Gadd, who was also the lead star and executive producer on the Netflix dark comedy, Baby Reindeer is based on Gadd's true story. The creator, who plays the fictionalized version of himself in the show called Donny Dunn, revealed he has deliberately changed his real-life stalker in the series to avoid getting sued or recognized, calling her Martha Scott on the show. However, the real-life Martha is now speaking up.\n\nRelated 'Thank God Misery Came Out First': Stephen King Pens Detailed Review of Netflix Hit Limited Series Stephen King has nothing but praise for the new Netflix series dominating the streaming service's top 10.\n\nFiona Harvey, who revealed her identity in a The Daily Record article over the weekend, has previously opened up about her portrayal on Baby Reindeer, admitting she is considering legal action against Gadd. \"He's using Baby Reindeer to stalk me now,\" she told the Daily Mail. \"I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me.\"\n\nHarvey has since sat down with Piers Morgan for an exclusive interview on Thursday night. Morgan has described the series as \"astounding,\" and he revealed that Harvey \"wants to have her say and set the record straight.\" The announcement also suggestively ends with the question, \"Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nThe official trailer previewing the interview consists of a series of clips of reviews of the show, several of Gadd from interviews, and several glimpses at some of the questions he'll ask. In the teaser, Morgan asked Harvey when she realized she was the person portrayed in Gadd's show, how she felt about Gadd, and whether she ever showed up at his house.\n\nRelated Netflix's Baby Reindeer Star Doesn't See Stalker Character as a Villain Baby Reindeer's Jessica Gunning reveals why she doesn't see her character as the villain. Close\n\nIn the full interview, which can be watched above, Harvey details the relationship she had with Gadd from her point of view. She denied the stalking claims, reaffirming that she's considering taking legal action. She denied sending emails to Gadd, noting, \"I didn't write him the emails... I think he probably made them up himself, I've no idea.\" Harvey also described the ordeal as \"obscene\" and \"horrendous,\" though she also admitted that she hadn't actually watched the show.\n\nRichard Gadd Didn't Want Fans to Find Martha's Real Identity\n\nAlthough Baby Reindeer is inspired by true events, Gadd made it clear he didn't want fans speculating on who the real Martha was. The comedian argued that was not the point of the show, and that he wanted to tell his story. After fans tried to discover her identity, he hopped on social media, writing, \"Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. That's not the point of our show.\"\n\nWhen speaking about whether the real-life Martha would be able to recognize herself, Gadd told GQ, \"We've gone to such great lengths to disguise her to the point that I don't think she would recognize herself. What's been borrowed is an emotional truth, not a fact-by-fact profile of someone.\" It looks like that wasn't the case, now that Harvey is planning to tell her side of the story.\n\nBaby Reindeer is streaming exclusively on Netflix.\n\nSource: The Daily Record, The Daily Mail, Piers Morgan, GQ\n\nTV-MA BiographyDrama\n\nRelease Date April 11, 2024 Creator(s) Richard Gadd Cast Richard Gadd , Reindeer sits down for tell-all Piers Morgan interview", "body": "The woman who allegedly inspired Richard Gadd's hit Netflix series Baby Reindeer will give her first TV interview this Thursday (9 May).\n\nIn the series, comedian Richard Gadd plays a fictionalised version of himself who gets stalked by a lonely and mentally ill woman called Martha, whom he meets while working at a pub.\n\nFollowing the series' success curious fans have tried to discover the inspirations behind the show, which members of the cast have vehemently discouraged.\n\nScottish lawyer Fiona Harvey, 58, who has been labelled the 'real Martha' has received death threats from Baby Reindeer viewers and will speak on Piers Morgan Uncensored to \"set the record straight after being unmasked by fans\".\n\nIt comes after Richard Gadd urged Baby Reindeer fans to stop trying to uncover the identities of the real people who inspired the Netflix show.\n\nAlthough the story is rooted in real events, Gadd changed names and specific details of the story to protect the identities of the people involved.\n\n\"Please don't speculate on who any of the real-life people could be,\" he told fans on Instagram. \"That's not the point of our show.\"\n\nJessica Gunning, who played Martha in Baby Reindeer, similarly told Glamour: \"I think it's a real, real shame, because it shows that they haven't watched the show properly.\n\n\"Netflix and Richard [Gadd] went to extreme lengths to try and make sure that the identities were kept private for a reason.\"\n\nSpeaking to the Daily Record after filming her first TV interview, Harvey said she felt \"set up\" and \"used\" by Morgan.\n\n\"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent,\" she claimed.\n\n\"I wouldn't say I was happy. She is pictured on Morgan's programme\n\nThe show has been a global success and follows 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning) as she stalks leading man Richard Gadd - who is presented in the show as Donny Dunn\n\nPiers Morgan has dropped the first trailer ahead of his interview with the 'real-life Martha' from Baby Reindeer, which is set to air on Thursday evening at 8pm\n\nKicking off with a round up of reactions to Baby Reindeeer, the clip then cuts to a collection of relentless rapid-fire question by the celebrity interviewer.\n\nRead More 'I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me': The alleged female stalker whose story has gripped the world in Netflix hit baby Reindeer tells HER side of the story and claims 'I'm being bullied for fame'\n\n'First of all, why have you decided to go public,' he asks, before continuing: 'When did you know that you were the person being depicted? Have you ever been to prison?'\n\n'What do you feel about Richard Gadd? Do you think he's mentally unwell? Did you ever turn up at his house? Would you accept that someone who did that would be very obsessive about someone.'\n\nThe trailer ends with Morgan asking: 'Here's the thing, I don't know the truth - you do. Would you look down the barrel of that camera... to people who still doubt you, what do you say to them?' before the clip cuts to the woman.\n\nBut campaigners have rounded on Morgan and slammed him for the decision to interview the alleged stalker.\n\nKerri Layton, whose life was destroyed after she faced a 14-year nightmare at the hands of her stalker - today said: 'I feel sick to the stomach for so many reasons.\n\n'Having being through the criminal justice system myself with a 14 year stalking incident, I know how dangerous this is.'\n\n'Stop glamourising stalking,' added the professional jazz singer and business coach in a post on social media.\n\nBaby Reindeer, the extraordinary hit Netflix drama which has taken the television world by storm, has been viewed more than 60 million times in the past month\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd at the hands of 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning, right)\n\nThe clip of the interview sees Morgan grilling the alleged stalker on everything from her views on Richard Gadd to whether she has ever been to prison\n\nThe Scot is set to break her silence in her first ever TV interview with Piers tonight from 8pm.\n\nBut before the t\u00eate-\u00e0-t\u00eate with the celebrity interviewer has even aired, the woman has already gone on the offensive, saying she is 'not happy' and felt she was being 'set up'.\n\nDescribing the 30-minute grilling as a 'sparring match', the alleged female stalker has accused Morgan of trying to 'trip her up' with his questions.\n\nRead More The real-life 'Martha' from Baby Reindeer is now targeting ME: I've had a four-day barrage of non-stop calls and terrifying messages just like on the Netflix show, writes NEIL SEARS. As I type, the phone is ringing again...\n\n'Piers kept saying to me \"are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?\". A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this,' she told the Daily Record.\n\n'I said, \"Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff\". As I said, in order to bill something as a \"true story\", it's got to be pretty much 100 per cent true.'\n\nShe added: 'It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.'\n\nThe Piers Morgan Uncensored special will air on the broadcaster's YouTube channel, which has 2.58million subscribers, at 8pm.\n\nThe woman will be looking to 'set the record straight' as she breaks her silence following Baby Reindeer's global success, the preview said.\n\nBefore her big interview, she paid a visit to celebrity hairdresser John Hala - who has styled the barnets of A-listers Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sigourney Weaver, Elle MacPherson and Kate Moss - at his salon in London's Canary Wharf.\n\nSpeaking to the Daily Record, she claimed she was paid \u00a3250 for the interview and had turned down requests from the likes of This Morning to talk about Baby Reindeer.\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd - who is presented in the show as Donny Dunn.\n\nWorking as a struggling stand-up comic, Gadd first meets his stalker after he offered 'a crying stranger a cup of tea' while he was working at a bar in London.\n\nBaby Reindeer delves into Richard's harrowing real-life stalking ordeal and brutal sexual abuse as he plays a fictionalised version of himself called Donny Dunn (pictured)\n\nThings rapidly turn sinister, with the series claiming 'Martha' bombarded the 34-year-old from Fife with more than 41,000 emails\n\nShe also sent him hundreds of tweets and and flooded his phone with hours of voicemails over an alleged four-year campaign of terror.\n\nPosting ahead of the show, Morgan said: 'The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.'\n\nHe added: 'Is she a psycho stalker? Find out on Piers Morgan Uncensored.'\n\nBaby Reindeer has proven a surprise smash for Netflix, having been viewed more than 60 million times in the first month.\n\nRiding on the show's phenomenal success, the cast were pictured attending a swanky screening in Los Angeles on Wednesday.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning - who plays Martha - beamed as they posed arm in arm and joined Nava Mau and others for a Q and A on stage.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning continued to ride the wave of Baby Reindeer being a huge Netflix hit as they attended the photo call for the screening in LA on Tuesday\n\nThe actress looked worlds away from her role as Martha and had a glamorous Hollywood makeover as they took to the stage\n\nOver four and a half years, Gadd says he received 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, letters totalling 106 pages and 350 hours of voicemail messages from the older woman, whom he calls Martha in the show\n\nHowever, the show's runaway success has been far from a joy for the 'real-life' Martha, who claimed she had been left a 'victim' by its surprise popularity.\n\nSpeaking exclusively to Mail+ last month, the woman insisted she was not a stalker and said: 'He's using Baby Reindeer to stalk me now. I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me.'\n\nShe accused Gadd of having 'main character syndrome' and claimed she had faced 'bullying' as a result of the show and was now considering legal action against him.\n\n'He always thinks he's at the centre of things. I'm not writing shows about him or promoting them in the media, am I? If he wanted me to be properly anonymous, he could have done so. Gadd should leave me alone,' she added.\n\nGadd claimed he went to great lengths to conceal the identity of the woman who stalked him in real life.\n\nDespite the comic begging fans not to search for the real 'Martha', internet sleuths went on to claim she was the inspiration for the character.\n\nIn the series, after Gadd meets his stalker at the bar, things soon descend into chaos.\n\nIt sees him being regularly followed at home and work, and tracked on Facebook using three fake accounts.\n\nRichard Gadd was a struggling stand-up comic working behind the bar at a pub in London\n\nHe told The Times: 'At first everyone at the pub thought it was funny that I had an admirer. Then she started to invade my life, following me, turning up at my gigs, waiting outside my house, sending thousands of voicemails and emails.'\n\nRead More Baby Reindeer knocked off Netflix's top spot by new 'must-watch' drama - but it's left people completely divided\n\nIt developed to terrifying lengths as the crazed fan got closer to her obsession - including her turning up at his gigs, his workplace and bombarding him with messages.\n\nThe actor and comedian was subjected to a campaign of obsession by the woman, known as Martha, that manifested in 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, 106 pages of letters and a staggering 350 hours of voicemail.\n\nHe says it was 'years' before the police eventually took his complaints seriously - and six years before they finally intervened - something which prolonged the agony for everyone involved including his relatives.\n\nThe police told him at the time that unless his stalker became physically violent, there was little they could do to resolve the issue.\n\nHe has said he still finds it hard to trust people and has had 'every therapy going'.\n\nHe added that the years of being stalked have left him with something 'like PTSD'. For the Netflix role, he lost weight to match his 10-and-a-half stone 'neurotic' self at the height of his own stalking nightmare.\n\nGadd has revealed he first encountered 'Martha' when he was working in a pub and offered her a cup of tea because she was crying\n\nGadd says he's currently single and 'is more cautious' of people because of the campaign of terror that Martha inflicted, saying: 'It takes me a long time to trust them. Before, I entered situations with such abandonment and I got burnt.'\n\nRead More Who is the real-life stalker from Netflix hit Baby Reindeer and where is she now? Fans of 'mind-blowing' show desperately search for woman who made Scottish comedian's life a misery\n\nHowever, performing a version of what happened to him has enabled him to have 'ownership' of the trauma. Gadd earned a Fringe award for his show, also called Baby Reindeer, in 2019.\n\nSpeaking to the Telegraph in 2019 about the one-man show that he wrote after the ordeal, which is currently on at London's Bush theatre, he said: 'It was debilitating beyond belief.\n\n'I'd listen to her voicemails and just feel my eyes welling up. They were tears of frustration. Proper brain-heavy stress.'\n\nHe added that the years of being stalked have left him with something 'like PTSD'. For the Netflix role, he lost weight to match his 10-and-a-half stone 'neurotic' self at the height of his own stalking nightmare.\n\nGadd says he's currently single and 'is more cautious' of people because of the campaign of terror that Martha inflicted, saying: 'It takes me a long time to trust them. Before, I entered situations with such abandonment and I got burnt.'\n\nHowever, performing a version of what happened to him has enabled him to have 'ownership' of the trauma. {"uri": "8119296589", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:18:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:18:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:17:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/richard-gadd-says-real-tears-32772243", "title": "Richard Gadd recalls tears on Baby Reindeer set as 'real Martha' speaks on TV", "body": "Jenelle Riley, Richard Gadd and Jessica Gunning attend the SAG-AFTRA Foundation Conversations Presents Netflix's Baby Reindeer\n\nRichard Gadd has opened up about some of Baby Reindeer's intense scenes and revealed the show's crew cried as the fourth episode was filmed - hours before the so-called 'real life Martha' prepares to share her side of the story.\n\nJessica Gunning, who played the role of obsessive stalker Martha in Netflix's surprise runaway hit series, has also recalled the filming process and described her character as \"really complicated\" and praised Gadd for showing how \"messy\" life can be via his writing.\n\nGadd and Gunning's comments come amid Piers Morgan sitting down for a televised interview with a woman who claims to have provided the real-life inspiration for the character of Martha.\n\nThe former Good Morning Britain anchor spoke with the woman, who the Mirror is not naming or sharing pictures of, recently and the footage is due to air on Morgan's YouTube channel Piers Morgan Uncensored this evening.\n\nMorgan announced his 'scoop' yesterday, with many slamming the broadcaster for filming the interview and possibly exploiting a potentially vulnerable woman suffering from mental health issues. The woman lashed out at Morgan on Facebook, calling him \"a twerp and a bully\" following their sit-down chat.\n\nAhead of Morgan's interview premiering at 8pm tonight, a new interview with Baby Reindeer stars Gadd and Gunning has been published, with both actors revealing new information about the creation of the show that is set to break Netflix records and become the streaming platform's most-watched show.\n\nThe seven-episode series, drawing from creator Gadd's own harrowing experiences with stalking, portrays Martha as a relentless stalker who ends up jailed for nine months after her persistent harassment of the Scottish comedian, starting in a Camden pub after Gadd offered her a free cup of tea.\n\nJessica Gunning, Richard Gadd and Nava Mau in L.A earlier this week\n\nThrough his experiences with Martha, Gadd's character Donny is also forced to address a past trauma, thanks to being raped and sexually abused by a writer years before meeting Martha. Donny's abuse - similar something to what Gadd experience in real-life - is revealed throughout episode four of the series, with some dark and traumatic scenes.\n\n\"We did close the set, but I was looking over and you'd see the props guys wiping tears from their eyes as they would be putting the props back how they should be,\" Gadd recalled when discussing how he filmed the possibly triggering scenes. \"The show was based in such a trauma that everyone on set felt at times it was a huge, weighty thing. And it's why I think everyone had such respect for everything. I was blessed with this amazing team who kind of felt it with me in a lot of ways.\"\n\nIn the same interview Gunning explained how Gadd works with We Are Survivors, a nonprofit organization that supports male and nonbinary sexual abuse, rape and sexual exploitation survivors across Greater Manchester, and since Baby Reindeer premiered at the start of April, the organisation has experienced a 200% increase in people joining for support, with 60% citing Baby Reindeer as the reason why they got in touch.\n\nThe Martha actress then described her character as \"really complicated\" as she told Variety how Gadd's writing helped her tap in to the fictional stalker. \"It's not an easy, buttoned-up story,\" Gunning told the publication. \"Everything doesn't get tied up at the end. I think it's messy, like life is. Their dynamic is complicated and he's really honest about that. That's so refreshing to see. The response to it is shown that audiences are really hungry for that. Hungry for honest, messy storytelling.\"\n\nGadd previously urged Baby Reindeer viewers not to try and identify any of the real-life characters\n\nThe woman claiming to be the real-life Martha has seemingly hit out at Morgan on social media following their interview hours before it hits the air. Writing on her Facebook page after sitting down with the broadcaster, the woman told her connections on the platform: \"Piers is a twerp.\n\n\"But we [already] know this. You will see in my interview. I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views. By far most of his other interviews with all misogynist men he often defends Andrew Tate Donald Trump.\"\n\nTaking to Twitter to promote the upcoming interview, Morgan yesterday shared an image of himself and the woman on the set of his Piers Morgan Uncensored YouTube show and boasted: \"WORLD EXCLUSIVE The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show. He continued: \"[Redacted] wants to have her say and 'set the record straight. ' Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on @PiersUncensored. \"\n\nThe Mirror has approached representatives for Richard Gadd and Netflix for comment.\n\n*If you've been the victim of sexual assault, you can access help Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nDuring the interview, Harvey told Morgan how internet sleuths tracked her down and and that she has received online death threats because of the series.\n\nIn a recent interview with the Daily Mail, the-then unnamed Harvey said she was threatening to sue Gadd because she was \"being bullied for fame.\"\n\nHarvey doubled down on her claims in her interview with Morgan, saying she considering legal action against both Gadd and Netflix.\n\nIn the Netflix limited series that debuted on April 11, Gadd tells a fictionalized version of his harrowing tale as Donny Dunn, a struggling comedian and bartender who is stalked by a woman he calls \"Martha\" (played by Jessica Gunning) after he shows the lonely woman a bit of kindness at the pub he works at.\n\nBaby Reindeer is based on Gadd's 2019 one-man stage show in the UK. Martha is said to have sent Gadd more than 41,000 emails and left 350 hours of voicemails over four-plus years.\n\nMorgan asked Harvey about the emails, and she said she only sent a few, along with a few text messages and about 18 tweets. She estimated that she maybe sent about 10 emails to Gadd.\n\nIn a Wednesday interview with the Daily Record posted after Morgan's X announcement, Harvey said of her talk with host, \"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent. I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself but I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.\"\n\nAs such, Harvey said, \"Piers kept saying to me 'are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?' A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this.\"\n\nIn interviews about the series, Gadd said while Baby Reindeer was fictionalized for the Netflix series, he noted that, \"Emotionally, it's all 100% true.\"\n\nHarvey countered Gadd's story in the Morgan interview, saying, \"I just generally think he's got extreme psychiatric problems... It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said. And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times ...\"\n\nIn her interview with the Daily Record about the Morgan interview, Harvey also questioned the claims of the series' truthfulness.\n\n\"I said, 'Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff,'\" Harvey told the Daily Record. \"As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100% true. It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nIn the aftermath of her video interview with Piers Morgan, Fiona Harvey recalled how the TV host said the sit-down \"went well.\"\n\n\"He referred to it as a sparring match,\" Harvey told the Daily Record. \"He landed a few punches on me and I landed a few punches on him.\"\n\nShe didn't take kindly, however, to one particular question. \"He asked me if I loved Richard Gadd and I said you've got to be joking,\" Harvey told the Daily Record.\n\nHarvey noted for the publication that Morgan contacted her last week for the interview and that other shows have be contacting her to talk.\n\n\"I've had people telling me they are publicists or agents but it's difficult to know who to trust,\" Harvey told the Daily Record. \"I've had people using the most foul language on the phone telling me they could make me a lot of money.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer has amassed big viewership for Netflix since the series debut. In numbers released by the streaming platform this week, Baby Reindeer topped Netflix's Global Top 10 TV Shows chart for the week of April 29 to May 5 with 18.6 million views, which translates to 73.6 million viewing hours.\n\nThe series has attracted such high profile viewers as horror novelist Stephen King.\n\nRichard Gadd, meanwhile, participated in a Netflix interview panel for Television Academy members earlier this week, where expressed empathy for the woman he calls \"Martha\" in the series.\n\n\"I saw someone who was kind of lost by the system, really,\" Gadd said during the panel. {"uri": "2024-05-350365746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:42:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:42:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:38:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.comingsoon.net/guides/news/1709723-where-how-to-watch-piers-morgan-interview-baby-reindeer-martha-fiona-harvey", "title": "How to Watch Piers Morgan's Baby Reindeer Interview With 'Martha' Fiona Harvey", "body": "The unsettling plot of the popular Netflix series Baby Reindeer prompted many to wonder about the identity of the real Martha Scott. After the series came out, Fiona Harvey, who claims to be the real Martha, agreed to an interview with British journalist and TV personality Piers Morgan. Want to know how to watch the controversial interview? Here is everything you need to know.\n\nWhere to watch Piers Morgan interview with Baby Reindeer's Martha?\n\nInterested viewers can watch the interview on Morgan's YouTube channel, Piers Morgan Uncensored. Titled \"The Real Martha Uncensored,\" it will begin streaming on Thursday, May 9, 2024, at 3:00 PM ET (noon PT) in the U.S. and 8:00 PM in the U.K., according to a post on X -formerly known as Twitter -- by Morgan.\n\nReferring to the interview as a \"World Exclusive,\" the former Daily Mirror editor wrote in another X post, \"The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show. Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nSeries creator and star Richard Gadd drew from his own experiences to develop Baby Reindeer. In seven episodes, the limited series portrays a harrowing depiction of what Gadd endured in his 20s through his stand-in, Donny Dunn. He was working at a London pub when he realized that one of the patrons was stalking him. The series premiered on April 11, 2024, and quickly became one of the most successful ventures for Netflix.\n\nWhile speaking to Daily Record, Harvey called the interview, which was filmed earlier Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nDuring the interview, Harvey told Morgan how internet sleuths tracked her down and and that she has received online death threats because of the series.\n\nYou can watch the Morgan interview by clicking the video below.\n\nIn the Netflix limited series that debuted on April 11, Gadd tells a fictionalized version of his harrowing tale as Donny Dunn, a struggling comedian and bartender who is stalked by a woman he calls \"Martha\" (Jessica Gunning) after he shows the lonely woman a bit of kindness at the pub he works at.\n\nBaby Reindeer is based on Gadd's 2019 one-man stage show in the UK. Martha is said to have sent Gadd more than 41,000 emails and left 350 hours of voicemails over four-plus years.\n\nMorgan asked Harvey about the emails, and she said she only sent a few, along with a few text messages and about 18 tweets. She estimated that she maybe sent about 10 emails to Gadd.\n\nIn a Wednesday interview with the Daily Record posted after Morgan's X announcement, Harvey said of her talk with host, \"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent. I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself but I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.\"\n\nAs such, Harvey said, \"Piers kept saying to me 'are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?' A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this.\"\n\nIn interviews about the series, Gadd said while Baby Reindeer was fictionalized for the Netflix series, he noted that, \"Emotionally, it's all 100% true.\"\n\nIn her interview with the Daily Record about the Morgan interview, Harvey questioned the claims of the series' truthfulness.\n\n\"I said, 'Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff,\" Harvey told the Daily Record. \"As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100% true. It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nIn the aftermath of her video interview with Piers Morgan, Fiona Harvey recalled how the TV host said the sit-down \"went well.\"\n\n\"He referred to it as a sparring match,\" Harvey told the Daily Record. \"He landed a few punches on me and I landed a few punches on him.\"\n\nShe didn't take kindly, however, to one particular question. \"He asked me if I loved Richard Gadd and I said you've got to be joking,\" Harvey told the Daily Record.\n\nHarvey noted for the publication that Morgan contacted her last week for the interview and that other shows have be contacting her to talk.\n\n\"I've had people telling me they are publicists or agents but it's difficult to know who to trust,\" Harvey told the Daily Record. \"I've had people using the most foul language on the phone telling me they could make me a lot of money.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer has amassed big viewership for Netflix since the series debut. In numbers released by the streaming platform this week, Baby Reindeer topped Netflix's Global Top 10 TV Shows chart for the week of April 29 to May 5 with 18.6 million views, which translates to 73.6 million viewing hours.\n\nThe series has attracted such high profile viewers as horror novelist Stephen King.\n\nRichard Gadd, meanwhile, participated in a Netflix interview panel for Television Academy members earlier this week, where expressed empathy for the woman he calls \"Martha\" in the series.\n\n\"I saw someone who was kind of lost by the system, really,\" Gadd said during the panel. \"I saw someone who needed help and wasn't getting it.\"\n\nDuring their interview, Harvey told Morgan that she thought Gadd had \"extreme psychiatric problems.\"", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", interview", "body": "The woman believed to be the inspiration behind the character Martha in the hit Netflix series Baby Reindeer is set to speak out publicly for the first time.\n\nPiers Morgan announced on social media on Wednesday that he would be conducting an interview with Fiona Harvey, who claims to be the real Martha Scott in Richard Gadd's acclaimed drama series.\n\nBaby Reindeer is a fictional story inspired by Gadd's own experience which tells a nightmarish tale about how an act of kindness morphed into a dangerous obsession.\n\nREAD MORE:Richard Osman claims 'everyone' in the industry knows who Baby Reindeer TV writer abuser is\n\nThe chilling drama series centres on struggling comedian Donny Dunn's (Gadd) strange and layered relationship with a woman named Martha (Jessica Gunning), whose initially friendly demeanor unravels as she begins to stalk Donny relentlessly.\n\nDuring the course of multiple years, Martha sends Donny more than 41,000 emails, 744 tweets, 100 pages of letters and 350 hours of voicemails.\n\nFollowing its release last month, Baby Reindeer became a word-of-mouth sensation and is on course to be one of the Netflix's most-watched shows.\n\nNow, in a bid \"to set the record straight\", Fiona Harvey will speak to former Good Morning Britain news anchor Piers Morgan in what he describes as a \"world exclusive\".\n\nThe interview is set to air at 8pm Thursday (May 9) on Morgan's YouTube show Piers Uncensored.\n\nSharing the news on social media, the outspoken journalist posted a picture of himself alongside Harvey in his studio.\n\n\"Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight',\" Morgan tweeted on Wednesday. \"Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on Piers Morgan Uncensored.\"\n\nFollowing Baby Reindeer's release, Gadd had urged viewers not to attempt to to track down the real-life counterparts to the characters depicted on the show.\n\nIn a statement shared on Instagram, Gadd wrote: \"People I love, have worked with, and admire (including Sean Foley) are unfairly getting caught up in speculation. Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. {"uri": "8119800186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:13:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:13:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:13:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/baby-reindeer-real-life-martha-32776055", "title": "Real-life Martha appears on Piers Morgan Uncensored to refute stalker allegation", "body": "The woman identified as the real Martha from the hit TV show Baby Reindeer has appeared on Piers Morgan Uncensored to refute allegations that she is a stalker.\n\nFiona Harvey, 58, gave her first \"big TV interview\" to the controversial broadcaster on his YouTube channel.\n\nOver half-a-million viewers tuned in as the woman who inspired the TV phenomenon of the year broke her onscreen silence on Morgan's show.\n\nScottish lawyer Harvey threatened to sue Baby Reindeer's star and writer, Scots comedian Richard Gadd as well as Netflix over the show - which tells the \"true story\" of Gadd and his stalker.\n\nIn Morgan's 50-minute show, which was pre-recorded, Harvey denied she had sent Gadd more than 40,000 emails, 350 hours of voicemail, 744 tweets, 46 Facebook messages and 106 pages of letters.\n\nShe described Baby Reindeer as \"completely untrue\" and \"very defamatory to me, very career-damaging.\"\n\nShe added: \"And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions. And this is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nAsked about Gadd, Harvey said: \"We've had no apologies from Netflix or him, nothing.\n\n\"I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology.\n\n\"My character seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal, been to prison.\n\n\"There are a number of other allegations, and... That's not true.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer is billed as \"a True Story\".\n\nShe said Gadd was \"making money out of untrue facts\" and vowed to sue the show's makers after being thrust into the spotlight and suffering online abuse.\n\nShe denied ever being at his home, contacting his parents or sending thousands of texts and emails messages.\n\nDuring the much-anticipated one-on-one, she admitted owning four mobile phones and a string of different email addresses.\n\nShe claims to be in a five-year relationship with a lawyer. She went public after being 'outed' within hours as the 'real-life Martha' online.\n\nShe said: \"On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats.\n\n\"So it wasn't really a choice. I was forced into this situation.\"\n\nAsked by Morgan if she had watched Baby Reindeer, she said: \"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene.\n\n\"I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online... You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nhe added: \"I just generally think he's got extreme psychiatric problems... It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said.\n\n\"And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms.\n\n\"And we met, two or three times...\"\n\nOn whether she was ever in love with Gadd, she said: \"Piers. Is that a serious question? No... I gave him the brush off.\n\n\"He asked me to sleep with him with a big green spot in his face one day. I said no I'm sorry, I'm not interested. He asked me to sleep with him.\n\n\"He said, 'would I like my curtains fixed'? And I laughed and he said, that's a euphemism.\n\n\"You want me to come home with you?\n\n\"I said, 'I've got a boyfriend'. I gave him the brush off big time, I think, you know, subtly so.\n\n\"But the bottom line is, no, I don't fancy little boys without jobs. That sounds awful. That sounds really, really callous. But, you know.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer was based on the real-life experiences of Scots comedian Gadd, the show's creator and star.\n\nIt follows a disturbing chain of events after he gave a customer of the Hawley Arms pub in London, where he was working as a barman, a free cup of tea.\n\nThe woman, who is called Martha Scott in the mini-series, becomes obsessed with him, camping out at his home, attacking his trans girlfriend and sending him thousands of emails.\n\nIt is just over a month since the Netflix Show Baby Reindeer premiered and it has earned Gadd rave reviews, along with praise over how he portrayed themes of stalking and sexual abuse.\n\nBut one person who isn't impressed is Harvey, the woman internet sleuths quickly identified as the 'real' Martha, who harasses Gadd's character Donny Dunn in the show.\n\nHarvey first denied being a stalker exclusively in the Daily Record. She also agreed to an exclusive photo shoot and to be identified in this paper last week.\n\nBut this was her first appearance on a TV channel, albeit YouTube, with thousands tuning into the Piers Morgan Uncensored show an hour before the interview had even begun to air.\n\nThe Scot, originally from Fyvie in Aberdeenshire, went head to head with celebrity interviewer Piers Morgan in the TV clash.\n\nShe repeatedly denied stalking Gadd in real life; calling the Scots comedian \"psychotic\" and a \"liar\".\n\nShe also claimed she intended to take legal action in the near future.\n\nBut when pressed on whether Gadd possessed around 41,000 emails from her, she revealed that she uses four separate phones, saying: \"I like keeping people on separate phones\".\n\nsent from iphoen\n\nTo
