{"uri": "8119803063", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:17:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:17:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:15:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/arts_and_culture/entertainment/after-baby-reindeer-fiona-harvey-who-claims-martha-is-based-on-her-has-fiery-interview/article_69952d4b-3563-5016-9433-a20fceb96dff.html", "title": "After 'Baby Reindeer,' Fiona Harvey, Who Claims Martha Is Based on Her, Has Fiery Interview With Piers Morgan: Here Are the Highlights", "body": "On Thursday afternoon, Fiona Harvey came forward to set the record straight about Baby Reindeer, the Netflix sensation, which Richard Gadd reportedly based on his real-life experience being stalked by a woman, called Martha in the series and portrayed by Jennifer Gunning. In a testy YouTube interview with Piers Morgan, she explained her reasons for believing the story is false enough to deserve her filing a lawsuit against Gadd, Netflix, and others associated with the series.\n\nIn the nearly one-hour-long interview, Harvey denied stalking Gadd, saying it was \"completely untrue\" and \"very defamatory to me.... I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail. I've got no injunctions.\"\n\nRelatedIs 'Baby Reindeer' Based on a True Story?\n\nHarvey complained that she received no apologies from Gadd, the streaming service, or others associated with the show, even after being harassed by \"internet sleuths\": \"[They] tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats, so it wasn't really a choice [to come forward].\"\n\nIn late April, shortly after the show's debut, Gadd did implore audiences not to try to seek out the real-life people who'd inspired the series in a social media post, writing, \"That's not the point of our show.\" Meanwhile, Netflix's policy chief said at a UK Parliament hearing that the streamer took \"every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story.\"\n\nThough Harvey claimed she had not watched Baby Reindeer, she took issue with the portrayal of Martha, saying, \"It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said. And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times.\"\n\nShe went on to say that she \"doubted\" he could prove his story by producing hundreds of voicemails from her, claiming that the only way it could happen is if he'd recorded her at the bar. She also said it was \"categorically\" untrue that he'd ever been caught peeping in her window and it was \"simply not true\" that she sent the number of emails and social media messages the show claims Martha did -- \"There may have been a couple of emails,\" she said, adding there were \"about 18 tweets,\" zero Facebook messages, and \"a couple of emails\" in all. She also denied ever heckling him at a comedy show.\n\nMore from this section Insane Like Me? England goalkeeper Mary Earps receives MBE at Windsor Castle Investiture In A Violent Nature Is Reportedly Making Audiences Sick - But Is It Really That Brutal?\n\nOne bit she did concede may be based in reality is the source of the show's title, admitting that she did have a reindeer toy, and saying, \"I had a toy reindeer and he'd shaved his head, that bit is true, and there were reindeers in the shops because it was Christmas time or something. It was a joke. So I have inadvertently penned the name of the show.\"\n\nHarvey went on to suggest Gadd had \"extreme psychiatric problems.\" Her ultimate message to Gadd? \"Leave me alone, please, and get a life, get a proper job.\"\n\nWatch the full interview in the embed above.\n\nBaby Reindeer, Netflix\n\nMore Headlines:\n\nAfter 'Baby Reindeer,' Fiona Harvey, Who Claims Martha Is Based on Her, Has Fiery Interview With Piers Morgan: Here Are the Highlights'9-1-1' Star Ryan Guzman on Buck & Eddie: 'It's Baby Steps Towards Anything & If Anything'Taye Diggs Returning to 'All American' -- How Can Dead Billy Baker Come Back?'Frasier' Season 2 Begins Production, Peri Gilpin Returning as Roz DoyleWill 'Mary & George' End Like the Book? {"uri": "8119711324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:48:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:48:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:47:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/4-things-self-proclaimed-real-32775203", "title": "4 things 'real life' Martha from Baby Reindeer claims is untrue in new interview", "body": "Martha in Baby Reindeer is played by actress Jessica Gunning\n\nThe woman claiming to be the real life Martha from Baby Reindeer spoke out tonight during an interview with Piers Morgan.\n\nThe individual, who The Mirror has chosen not to name or photograph, insists that she is the inspiration behind stalker Martha in the Netflix show Baby Reindeer. The programme tells the story of writer and comedian Richard Gadd's experience of being stalked by a woman named Martha in the show. In Gadd's seven part series, Martha is a terrifying stalker who winds up with a nine month jail sentence for a campaign of harassment against the comic after meeting him in a Camden pub.\n\nDuring an interview with Piers Morgan tonight, she claims several things were untrue about the Netflix show - including that he never offered her a free cup of tea, and she never messaged him as much as she said she did.\n\nRichard Gadd wrote the Netflix show Baby Reindeer\n\nThe Netflix show is marketed as a 'true story'. However, in the interview, she told Piers: \"It's completely untrue. Very, very defamatory to me, very career-damaging. And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions. And this is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nOffer of tea\n\nThe \"real life\" Martha disputed that she had been offered a free cup of tea when he was working in the pub. Asked directly about that, she said it was untrue. She explained: \"No, that's not correct. He didn't offer me a cup of tea... I was in for a meal with, a drink of lemonade, and I was very, very hungry. I'm diabetic, so, very hungry. So that's true.\"\n\nCorrespondence\n\nIn the show, Martha sent 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters to Gadd but the self-proclaimed \"Martha\" has denied this was the case in her experience, insisting she did have correspondence with him but not of this volume.\n\nAsked about this, she said: \"That's simply not true. If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots.\" When asked what she did send, she later added: \"Now, none of that's true. I don't think I sent him anything... No, I think there may have been a couple of emails exchanging, but that was it. Just jokey banter emails. There may have been a couple of emails,\" but insisted she never sent text messages or Facebook messages.\n\nJessica Gunning plays Martha in the show\n\nWhen asked if she tweeted him, she added: \"I may have done years and years ago... No, it wasn't numerous. It's about 18 tweets.\"\n\nSmashing up a bar\n\nThe 'real life' Martha has insisted she never smashed up a bar. She told Piers tonight: \"We've had no apologies from Netflix or him, nothing. I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology. My character seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal, been to prison. There are a number of other allegations, and... That's not true.\"\n\nJail time\n\nShe also denied she has ever faced prison for what happened. The 'real life' Martha has said she did not watch the show and has no plans to - admitting she'd be \"sick\" if she ever laid eyes on the Netflix show.\n\nAsked if she's seen it, she told Piers: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it. I think I'd be sick [if I watched it]. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nWhat is true\n\nDuring the interview, the woman claiming to be the 'real life' Martha called the show a 'work of fiction', and said there were just two true facts in it.\n\n\"It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said. And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times,\" she told Piers.\n\nNetflix or Gadd himself have yet to comment on claims the lady - who The Mirror is not identifying through photographs or by name - is the 'real-life' Martha. Netflix's policy chief Benjamin King said yesterday that Netflix and the production company \"took every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that Check it out:\n\nFans were left on the edge of the sofas thanks to Netflix's miniseries Baby Reindeer, and with its twists, turns and absolutely bonkers true-life storyline, everyone was left asking the same question.\n\nThe interest in comedian Richard Gadd's former stalker was palpable, and some internet sleuths even narrowed it down to one person they believed it could be.\n\nThey searched high and low to find a Scottish woman who had trained as a lawyer, lived in Camden for a bit and drank at Gadd's pub - identical to Martha in the series.\n\nEven though Gadd urged people not to speculate on who some people from the show might be in real life, the woman who has been dubbed the 'real-life Martha' has now sat down with Morgan for an episode of Piers Morgan Uncensored.\n\nThe controversial journalist went on to post out a picture of himself and Fiona Harvey, saying she wanted to 'set the record straight' and 'have her say'.\n\nShe even claimed afterwards that she was paid \u00a3250 to appear on Morgan's Talk TV show.\n\nBut according to Harvey, she felt 'a bit used' after the interview with Morgan and told the Daily Record that he refused to accept her side of the story, saying: \"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent.\n\n\"I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself, but I wouldn't say I was happy. {"uri": "8119104286", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:13:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:13:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:10:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-13399877/Netflix-insist-took-precaution-protect-real-life-people-inspired-Baby-Reindeer-fans-Richard-Gadds-stalker-online.html", "title": "Netflix 'took 'every precaution' to protect real life Baby Reindeer", "body": "READ MORE: The real-life 'Martha' says SHE has been bombarded with calls\n\nA Netflix executive has claimed producers took every precaution to protect the real life people who inspired the characters of Baby Reindeer after viewers managed to identify Richard Gadd's stalker.\n\nSpeaking in parliament, policy chief Benjamin King said that Netflix and Clerkenwell Films - who made the hit show - took 'every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story.'\n\nMr Gadd, who plays the lead in the series, and has said it is based on his own experiences of being stalked and sexually abused by a high profile comedy agent has urged fans not to look for the characters' real-life counterparts.\n\nHowever, since the show aired, fans have gone crazy over potential theories on who each of the characters could be in reality.\n\nMr Gadd has been forced to ask people to stop trying to figure it out, as it leading to false accusation against his friends.\n\nMr Gadd (pictured), who plays the lead in the series, and has said it is based on his own experiences of being stalked and sexually abused by a high profile comedy agent has urged fans not to look for the characters' real-life counterparts\n\nHe wrote on his Instagram page about how 'people I love, have worked with, and admire' were being targeted unfairly.\n\nHe added: 'Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. That's not the point of the show.'\n\nSNP MP John Nicolson, who sits on the Culture, Media and Sport Committee, added that efforts hadn't stopped fans finding the real life Martha onlin.\n\nBut Mr King said Netflix needed to balance protecting identities with upholding the 'veracity and authenticity' of the show.\n\n'We didn't want to anonymise that or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story because that would undermine the intent behind the show,' the senior public policy director said.\n\n'Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media.\n\n'I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.'\n\nMr Nicolson also asked if Netflix had given any support to the woman identified online as Richard's stalker - who is set to do a TV interview this week.\n\nMr Nicolson also asked if Netflix had given any support to the woman identified online as Richard's stalker - who is set to do a TV interview this week. Pictured,Jessica Gunning as Martha in the show\n\n'I cannot get into the specifics of what happened around the making of the show because it wouldn't be appropriate for me to comment. I don't want to give further fuel to some of the theories which are circling on the internet,' Mr King said.\n\nHe added that Netflix worked closely with the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, a support charity for stalking victims, and the show had raised awareness for male victims.\n\nBaby Reindeer delves into Richard's harrowing real-life stalking ordeal and brutal sexual abuse as he plays a fictionalised version of himself called Donny Dunn.\n\nDonny is flooded with 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, 350 voicemails and 106 pages of letters from stalker Martha, played by Jess Gunning. The series also details Donny's horrifying rape at the hands of his comedy mentor Darrien played by Tom Goodman-Hill.\n\nDarrien coaxes Donny to come to his flat and get high on drugs, by promising him that TV producers are interested in his work.\n\nHowever while on drugs he sexually assaults Donny multiple times.\n\nMr Gadd has opened up about what it was like to re-enact his trauma for the small screen - and how he hopes it will aid his healing process.\n\nOn reliving his 'severe' twenties, Mr Gadd told Attitude: 'It's hugely challenging, but I hope for catharsis when the show comes out.'\n\nBaby Reindeer, the extraordinary hit Netflix drama which has taken the television world by storm, has been viewed more than 60 million times in the past month\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd at the hands of 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning, right)\n\nIt comes as the real-life 'Martha' claims she has been bombarded with calls since the show became a global sensation.\n\nThe woman has claimed that since the release of the show, she has been inundated with calls from 'foul-mouthed' publicists or agents trying to book her.\n\nRead More 'I'm the victim. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this,' she told the Daily Record.\n\n'I said, \"Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff\". It is based on series star and creator Richard Gadd's real-life experience with a stalker and as a victim of sexual abuse. The stalker, Martha, is portrayed by Jessica Dunning and quickly endears herself to lead Donny Dunn (Gadd), before turning obsessive, inundating him with emails and phone calls, then eventually showing up outside his home.\n\nHarvey recognized quickly that Martha was based on her, and while Gadd has made it clear that Martha was never meant to be an exact replication of his real-life stalker, Harvey still spoke out, threatening legal action against him.\n\n\"He's using Baby Reindeer to stalk me now,\" she claimed in an interview with The Daily Mail. \"I'm the victim. {"uri": "2024-05-350557389", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:03:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:03:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:00:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.nme.com/news/tv/who-is-the-real-life-martha-in-baby-reindeer-3754972", "title": "Who is the real-life Martha in 'Baby Reindeer'?", "body": "The woman who inspired the character revealed her identity this week for the first time\n\nBaby Reindeer is one of the year's most talked-about shows, but who is the real-life woman that inspired the character of Martha?\n\nThe hit Netflix series was created by Richard Gadd, and claims to tell the true story of his experience of being obsessively stalked by a woman called Martha after he befriends her in the pub he works in.\n\nIn the show, Martha has already served a four-and-a-half year sentence for a previous stalking conviction, and in the final episode she is given a further nine months in prison.\n\nAfter the show's release, some viewers attempted to uncover the real identities of characters in the show, including Martha. Gadd subsequently urged viewers to refrain from speculating, saying: \"That's not the point of our show.\"\n\nWho is the real-life Martha in Baby Reindeer?\n\nThe woman chose to publicly reveal her identity this week in an interview with the Daily Record, after a flurry of speculation since the release of the show.\n\nShe is Fiona Harvey, a 58-year-old Scottish lawyer, who in the interview described the show as \"a load of rubbish\".\n\nSpeaking about the decision to come forward, she said she did so \"because people have to know what is going on.\"\n\nShe went on to tell the newspaper that she has not been to prison, adding: \"I don't know where the four-and-a-half years and nine months comes in.\"\n\nThreatening legal action against Gadd and Netflix, she said: \"Gadd needs to prove I went to jail which just didn't happen. I've never been sent to jail. That is blatantly obvious.\n\n\"Police at your door would be the first thing, then you'd be charged, then you would have a trial. Then you'd be fined or something or go to prison.\n\n\"This is all made up and hyperbole. There are no restraining orders, injunctions or interdicts anywhere. There's just no way. I've not had the police at my door about any of these things.\n\n\"It's a load of rubbish. I don't have any money but I'm a perfectly capable lawyer so I will represent myself.\"\n\nHarvey is also due to appear on Piers Morgan Uncensored on May 9, in an attempt to \"set the record straight\".\n\n\"I'm the victim here, not Richard Gadd,\" Harvey also told the Daily Record. \"I've had death threats as a result of his show despite the fact that a lot of the things he claimed are just not true.\"\n\nShe went on to say that she had been getting by on \"two hours sleep\" per night since the show had been released, which she said she had not watched.\n\n\"I was in Richard Gadd's company on occasions but I didn't stalk him like he claims. His story is that this is a gross intrusion into my privacy. I haven't seen him for 12 years.\n\n\"I read that he had written that show for the festival four or five years ago and I thought, 'Oh my God'. This weekend I Googled and stories about Richard Gadd and Baby Reindeer were all over the place in flashing lights.\"", "source": {"uri": "nme.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NME Music News, {"uri": "8119504583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:50:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:50:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:50:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/monicamercuri/2024/05/09/richard-gadd-and-netflix-tried-to-hide-marthas-identity-on-baby-reindeer-it-didnt-work/", "title": "Richard Gadd And Netflix Tried To Hide Martha's Identity On 'Baby Reindeer' -- It Didn't Work", "body": "Baby Reindeer is on track to become one of Netflix's most successful series. While millions tuned in to Richard Gadd's dramatized account of his real-life experience with a stalker in his 20s, there was one unfortunate consequence he desperately wanted to avoid: revealing Martha's identity.\n\nIn Gadd's defense, the Scottish comedian said that he never told his stalker's name to the media. He also changed key facts about her for the Netflix show, so much so that the woman wouldn't even recognize herself.\n\nIn an interview with GQ in April, Gadd explained that their \"focus was on capturing the emotional truth, not creating a factual profile,\" he said. \"We've gone to such lengths to disguise her that I doubt she would recognize herself in the show.\"\n\nYesterday, Netflix Policy Chief Benjamin King told a UK Parliament that the streamer and producer Clerkenwell Films had taken \"every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story.\"\n\n\"We didn't want to anonymise that or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story because that would undermine the intent behind the show,\" King said. \"Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media.\"\n\nHowever, their best efforts to hide Martha's identity unraveled when internet sleuths began hunting for clues. Quickly, social media users directed attention to the Twitter account of Fiona Harvey, a woman who sent multiple tweets to Gadd in 2014, one of which was allegedly mentioned in the show.\n\nGadd and Gunning urged the public to stop trying to uncover the identity of his former stalker. \"Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. That's not the point of our show,\" Gadd said in a now-expired Instagram story.\n\nMeanwhile, Gunning told BBC Scotland's The Edit that the speculation around Martha was \"quite sad\" and \"not the point of the show at all.\" She continued, \"If you like the show and you are a fan of it, you should stick with the story of Martha and Donny being what connects you, not trying to do any detective work and find out any real identities.\"\n\nOn April 26, 2024, a woman claiming to be Gadd's stalker anonymously told the Daily Mail that she was considering legal action against Gadd.\n\nThe woman said that Gadd's script amounted to \"bullying an older woman on television for fame and fortune\" and that she had received online \"death threats and abuse from Richard Gadd supporters.\" She insisted that now, Gadd was the one who was obsessed with her.\n\n\"He's using Baby Reindeer to stalk me now,\" she told the tabloid. \"I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me.\"\n\nBut the speculation about Martha's identity didn't stop there. Fiona Harvey, the woman that social media sleuths were convinced was Martha, will now be interviewed on Piers Morgan Uncensored on May 9.\n\n\"The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show,\" Morgan wrote in the tweet. \"Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.\"\n\nWhen John Nicolson, a Scottish National Party MP who sits on the Culture, Media, and Sport Committee, was asked at the UK Parliament panel whether Netflix had provided any support to Harvey -- who is planning to give an interview with Morgan -- he said that he couldn't get into any details.\n\n\"I cannot get into the specifics of what happened around the making of the show because it wouldn't be appropriate for me to comment,\" Nicolson clarified. \"I don't want to give further fuel to some of the theories which are circling on the internet.\"\n\nKing added that Netflix worked with the Suzy Lamplugh Trust to It is based on a live show by Gadd in which he recounts the true story of his attempts to transition from barman to comedian -- including how he ended up being stalked for six months by a customer and was sexually assaulted by a man in the entertainment industry he had hoped would mentor him.\n\nGadd claimed he had changed enough details about his stalker, named Martha in the show and played by Jessica Gunning, to ensure she wouldn't be recognized but fans quickly began combing through the internet and identified a woman named Fiona Harvey as a possible candidate.\n\nIn the series Martha is portrayed as a Scottish fantasist who claims to be a high-powered lawyer with impressive political contacts but in real life was a pitiful figure with a conviction for stalking. {"uri": "8118104705", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "21:47:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T21:47:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T21:46:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://variety.com/2024/tv/news/baby-reindeer-richard-gadd-jessica-gunning-1235986480/", "title": "'Baby Reindeer' Star Richard Gadd Reveals Crew Cried While Filming Emotional Episode 4", "body": "Jessica Gunning, who plays the haunting stalker Martha in Netflix's \"Baby Reindeer,\" says creator and star Richard Gadd was on her radar even before she auditioned for the show -- ever since she saw his one-man show \"Monkey See Monkey Do\" at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.\n\n\"I just thought it was one of the most profound things I've ever seen really on stage,\" she said. \"Then I tried to go and see 'Baby Reindeer' the play, but it was sold out. So, I actually bought the play text, which is a bit Martha of me.\"\n\nGadd, Gunning, actor Nava Mau, director Weronika Tofilska and editor Peter Oliver served as panelists Tuesday night at the DGA Theater Complex for Netflix's FYC screening and panel for the limited series. The streamer submitted \"Baby Reindeer\" for consideration to be nominated for best limited series at the Emmys, along with Gadd to be considered for best actor and best writing.\n\nAdapted from Gadd's eponymous stage play, which premiered at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in 2019, \"Baby Reindeer\" follows a fictionalized version of Gadd named Donny who meets a woman named Martha (Gunning) while working in a pub. What starts off as Donny offering her a cup of tea out of sympathy turns into a twisted and complex relationship where Martha wreaks havoc on Donny's relationships. Through his experiences with Martha, Donny is forced to confront the trauma of a past sexual assault and come to terms with his sexuality.\n\nGadd said he went into an \"obsessive place\" to write the series, which started off as his one-man hour-long show. He wrote the series during the COVID-19 lockdown and described the process as difficult and cathartic.\n\n\"I never wanted to kind of lie,\" he said. \"I always had to constantly check myself to be like, 'Does this feel truthful to me to my experience all the way through?' And if it didn't, I would have to bring it back.\"\n\nHe continued to explain that filming episode 4, which depicts scenes of his sexual assault by a writer he worked with, was difficult for the entire crew.\n\n\"We did close the set, but I was looking over and you'd see the props guys wiping tears from their eyes as they would be putting the props back how they should be,\" Gadd said. \"The show was based in such a trauma that everyone on set felt at times it was a huge, weighty thing. And it's why I think everyone had such respect for everything. I was blessed with this amazing team who kind of felt it with me in a lot of ways.\"\n\nGunning explained that Gadd works with We Are Survivors, a nonprofit organization that supports male and nonbinary sexual abuse, rape and sexual exploitation survivors across Greater Manchester. She said since the airing of the series, the organization had a 200% increase in people joining for support, with 60% citing \"Baby Reindeer\" as the reason why they got in touch.\n\nShe also said Gadd's writing helped her tap in to her character Martha, who she describes as a \"really complicated character.\"\n\n\"It's not an easy, buttoned-up story,\" Gunning said. \"Everything doesn't get tied up at the end. I think it's messy, like life is. Their dynamic is complicated and he's really honest about that. That's so refreshing to see. The response to it is shown that audiences are really hungry for that. Hungry for honest, messy storytelling.\"", "source": {"uri": "variety.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Variety"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baby_Reindeer", The woman, who the Mirror has chosen not to name or identify via photographs, branded Morgan \"a twerp and a bully\" on her Facebook page since the interview was conducted.\n\nReleased with little promotion of hype at the start of April, Baby Reindeer quickly topped streaming charts across the world and is now on course to become one of Netflix's most-watched series of all time. The comedy-drama tells the chilling tale of writer and star Richard Gadd's character Donny's ordeal with a persistent stalker named Martha, played by Jessica Gunning.\n\nThe seven-episode series - inspired by creator Gadd's actual real-life experiences with stalking and sexual abuse- depicts Martha as an unyielding stalker who ends up behind bars for nine months due to her constant harassment of the Scottish comic, beginning in a Camden pub.\n\nMorgan announced yesterday that he recently sat down for a chat with the 'real-life Martha', dividing fans of the series still dominating cultural conversations and debates weeks on from its premiere. Taking to Twitter today, just hours before the interview airs at 8pm, a delighted Morgan shared a snap of a newspaper's front page dedicated to the upcoming broadcast.\n\n\"Front page news before it even airs....\" Morgan boasted as he captioned the image. However, many of the journalist's followers and critics were quick to share their concerns regarding the controversial interview. \"What could go wrong? Thinking this is maybe not a good idea for anyone participating, on so many levels,\" one Twitter (X) user wrote as they quote-tweeted Morgan's original post.\n\nUndeterred by the criticism, Morgan teased the chat would be bigger than his infamous interview with Cristiano Ronaldo, in which the footballer aired his grievances with Manchester United.\n\nThe fictional Martha was played by Jessica Gunning\n\n\"Not had such a massive global build-up reaction to any of my interviews since Ronaldo. I don't think anyone will be disappointed,\" he posted followed by a series of flame emojis.\n\nDespite Piers' hype, fans were quick to vent their concerns for the 'TV event'.\n\nOne argued: \"Men like piers morgan will cry about male victims not getting the same recognition as female victims, and then go ahead and platform their abuser/stalker when they do.\" A third wrote: \"Hearing Piers Morgan has interviewed the 'real life Martha' portrayed in Baby Reindeer fills me with dread. A vulnerable woman exploited for the entertainment of people who became stalkers themselves. What the fuck are we doing as a society?\"\n\nOthers shared different thoughts on the interview ahead of its premiere, with one musing: \"In two minds about the Martha from Baby Reindeer thing because a) I had my own Martha and was continuously met with expectations to show them grace because they weren't all there while they terrorized me unchecked and also don't think she should be anywhere near Piers poxy Morgan.\"\n\nMany expressed excitement to watch the woman's chat with Morgan, with one admitting: \"Have I cancelled a cinema mate date to watch martha on Piers Morgan with a takeaway? {"uri": "8119758945", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:33:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:33:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:33:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.tvinsider.com/1135322/baby-reindeer-fiona-harvey-interview-piers-morgan/", "title": "Fiona Harvey, Who Claims 'Baby Reindeer's Martha Is Based on Her, Has Fiery Interview", "body": "Netflix Addresses 'Baby Reindeer' Social Media Manhunt as Real 'Martha' Speaks Out\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, Fiona Harvey came forward to set the record straight about Baby Reindeer, the Netflix sensation, which Richard Gadd reportedly based on his real-life experience being stalked by a woman, called Martha in the series and portrayed by Jennifer Gunning. In a testy YouTube interview with Piers Morgan, she explained her reasons for believing the story is false enough to deserve her filing a lawsuit against Gadd, Netflix, and others associated with the series.\n\nIn the nearly one-hour-long interview, Harvey denied stalking Gadd, saying it was \"completely untrue\" and \"very defamatory to me.... I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail. I've got no injunctions.\"\n\nHarvey complained that she received no apologies from Gadd, the streaming service, or others associated with the show, even after being harassed by \"internet sleuths\": \"[They] tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats, so it wasn't really a choice [to come forward].\"\n\nIn late April, shortly after the show's debut, Gadd did implore audiences not to try to seek out the real-life people who'd inspired the series in a social media post, writing, \"That's not the point of our show.\" Meanwhile, Netflix's policy chief said at a UK Parliament hearing that the streamer took \"every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story.\"\n\nThough Harvey claimed she had not watched Baby Reindeer, she took issue with the portrayal of Martha, saying, \"It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said. And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times.\"\n\nShe went on to say that she \"doubted\" he could prove his story by producing hundreds of voicemails from her, claiming that the only way it could happen is if he'd recorded her at the bar. She also said it was \"categorically\" untrue that he'd ever been caught peeping in her window and it was \"simply not true\" that she sent the number of emails and social media messages the show claims Martha did -- \"There may have been a couple of emails,\" she said, adding there were \"about 18 tweets,\" zero Facebook messages, and \"a couple of emails\" in all. She also denied ever heckling him at a comedy show.\n\nOne bit she did concede may be based in reality is the source of the show's title, admitting that she did have a reindeer toy, and saying, \"I had a toy reindeer and he'd shaved his head, that bit is true, and there were reindeers in the shops because it was Christmas time or something. It was a joke. So I have inadvertently penned the name of the show.\"\n\nHarvey went on to suggest Gadd had \"extreme psychiatric problems.\" Her ultimate message to Gadd? \"Leave me alone, please, and get a life, get a proper job.\"", "source": {"uri": "tvinsider.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "TV Insider"}, "authors": [{"uri": "amanda_bell@tvinsider.com", "name": "Amanda Bell", "type": "author", {"uri": "8119799535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:13:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:13:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:12:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.themarysue.com/?p=793375", "title": "When Did Baby Reindeer Happen? Answered | The Mary Sue", "body": "Netflix's sleeper hit Baby Reindeer gives viewers a vague timeline of events when telling the unbelievable true story of comedian Donny Dunn (Richard Gadd) and his stalker, Martha (Jessica Gunning). But when did the incident take place in real life?\n\nAfter dominating the streaming charts for just shy of a month, Netflix's dark comedy Baby Reindeer has officially been dethroned by Jeff Daniels' new series, A Man in Full. Still, Baby Reindeer had a seriously impressive run in the No. 1 spot, bringing its cast -- particularly its writer/star/producer, Gadd -- into the limelight with a gripping tale of love, suspense, and drama.\n\nBaby Reindeer follows down-on-his-luck comedian Donny Dunn (a fictionalized version of Gadd himself) over the course of five years as he becomes the victim of a serial stalker named Martha. The two initially meet at the pub Donny works at, and a simple act of kindness -- giving Martha a free cup of tea -- quickly spirals into flat-out obsession when Martha begins following Donny home, showing up unprompted at his gigs, and sending him raunchy emails, among other things.\n\nEventually, Martha turns dangerously possessive and starts to meddle in Donny's personal life, threatening his parents, his ex-girlfriend, and even his prospective love interest, Teri (Nava Mau). However, when Donny seeks out the police for help, they turn him away, citing a lack of evidence -- despite Martha having a criminal record of stalking and harassment. Understandably, the whole situation takes a toll on Donny's mental health, made even worse by his personal struggles with sexuality, identity, self-blame, and trauma at the hands of a successful TV writer.\n\nUltimately, Martha is sent to prison on three counts of stalking and harassment, though it's hard to say if the real-life \"Martha\" suffered a similar fate. Although Gadd himself has never publicly confirmed her identity, a women claiming to be the inspiration behind the character has since stepped forward after internet sleuths tried to unearth her identity despite Gadd's wishes and belief that she's mentally unwell. bashing the Netflix miniseries and denying that it's true.\n\nRegardless, Gadd knew this was a story worth telling, and made art out of his seriously disturbing experience by turning the incident into a one-man show. Also titled Baby Reindeer, the play opened at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2019 and was picked up by Netflix around 2022 ,before being adapted to the small screen in April 2024. So when did the real-life events that laid the foundation for the Baby Reindeer TV show take place?\n\nA review published by The Guardian, following the Baby Reindeer play's opening in 2019, claims that Donny first met Martha in 2013, as he said the events took place \"six years ago\" at the time. The ensuing chaos -- a.k.a., Martha's thousands of emails, Facebook messages, and tweets -- occurred throughout the next four or so years, putting her trial around 2017 or 2018. Given that Gadd told the outlet that he considered the issue to be resolved by 2019, this seems to imply that he hasn't been in contact with \"Martha\" since, similar to the timing of the Netflix show.\n\nAlthough the timeline of Baby Reindeer is a bit spotty -- especially in the Netflix series -- the only thing that really matters is that Gadd seems to have gotten a sense of closure from the He explained: \"We didn't want to anonymize that or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story because that would undermine the intent behind the show. Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media. I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.\"\n\nThe MP asked Richard if Netflix had provided any support to Fiona Harvey, a woman who says she is the real life Martha, who is appearing in an interview with Piers Morgan tonight. Now, the person accused of being the 'real life' Martha by internet sleuths has spoken out by going head to head with interviewer Piers in a TV clash.\n\nThe woman, who we are not naming, recorded her first \"big TV interview\" with the controversial broadcaster earlier this week in which she hoped to \"set the record straight\".\n\nLet's take a look at some of the most explosive bombshells from her interview...\n\n'I won't watch Baby Reindeer'\n\nPiers' interviewee was asked numerous questions about the show to which she is suspected to have inspired the 'Martha' character. But when asked whether she has watched the Netflix series, she replied: \"I haven't watched any of it. I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life.\"\n\nShe continued to say: \"I find it quite obscene. I've had a horrifying, misogynistic.\"\n\nDeath threats\n\nThe woman on the show had been 'unmasked' by internet sleuths who named her as the 'real Martha' after investigating her on social media. The woman then revealed that following the airing of Baby Reindeer, she has received a number of death threats.\n\nShe said: \"Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that.\n\n\"And it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nDenying stalker charges\n\nIn the final scenes of Baby Reindeer, the character of Martha is jailed for nine-months with charges of stalking of Richard's character, Donny. When Piers asked his interviewee about whether she'd ever been to prison, she replied: \"That is completely untrue, very, very defamatory to me. Very career damaging and I wanted to rebut that completely on this show, I'm not a stalker, I've not been to jail - it's complete nonsense.\"\n\n\"If you're charged with a criminal offence it will go fine, bigger fine, very few people go to jail nowadays.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer details\n\nDuring the course of the interview, the 'real life' Martha has disputed the 'facts' of the show. The first being the cup of tea that Martha in the Baby Reindeer series accepts from Richard's character Donny - instead, she said: \"I was in for a meal with, a drink of lemonade, and I was very, very hungry. I'm diabetic, so, very hungry.\"\n\nThe next thing she says is untrue is the amount of correspondence she had had with Richard. In the show Martha sent 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106. However when Piers puts that to her, she responds with: \"Now, none of that's true. I don't think I sent him anything... No, I think there may have been a couple of emails exchanging, but that was it.\"\n\nIn the show, Martha smashes up the bar which the interviewee also denies. {"uri": "8119788263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:04:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:04:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:03:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.avclub.com/piers-morgan-fiona-harvey-interview-baby-reindeer-gadd-1851467583", "title": "Piers Morgan's interview with the \"real\" Martha is a tough watch", "body": "Morgan's interview with Fiona Harvey proves exactly why she shouldn't have been platformed in the first place\n\nBaby Reindeer is a transfixing, vulnerable tale of creator and star Richard Gadd's real experience with sexual assault and with a stalker pseudonymously referred to as \"Martha.\" Upon the release of the Netflix series, which was advertised from the jump as a \"true story,\" Gadd asked viewers not to speculate about the real-life identities of any of the characters. \"That's not the point of our show,\" he insisted. Still, the internet is the internet, which is how a woman named Fiona Harvey ended up on Piers Morgan today talking about how Gadd is the real obsessive liar.\n\nEven though Gadd and Netflix claimed to scrub any identifying details from the show, the internet quickly identified Harvey -- a Scottish lawyer who bears a resemblance to Jessica Gunning, the actor who plays Martha -- as the most likely candidate. That connection was initially made based on a number of tweets she had sent to Gadd over the years, and furthered by a Daily Mail article that did not include her name. Still, that didn't stop dozens of other outlets from putting it out there, leading to her first major interview today.\n\nThe entire 54-minute Piers Morgan segment is a brutal watch. Harvey repeatedly claims that Gadd made up the entire series (which she claims not to have watched) and that he's the one with \"extreme psychiatric problems,\" before contradicting her own answers over and over again, sometimes within the same sentence. There are only \"two true facts\" in the show, she opens: \"His name is Richard Gadd and he worked as a barman at the Holy Arms, and we met two or three times.\" Later, she says they met \"five or six\" times, refers to him as a (former) friend, and admits she went to his comedy show. At one point, she says she didn't send Gadd anything and then immediately admits she sent \"a couple emails but that's it. Just jokey banter emails.\" She admits to making the joke about her curtains and says Gadd asked to sleep with her. You get the picture.\n\nWe're not here to speculate about whether Harvey's claims -- or Gadd's, for that matter -- are true or false. We certainly don't have all the necessary information. What is evident, though, is that this whole situation is incredibly sad. What happened to Gadd was awful. The fact that people took his story and immediately turned it into an exploitative media sensation is awful. That Netflix and producer Clerkenwell Films failed this dramatically in their duty of care toward the show's subjects is awful. The fact that Harvey is making talk show appearances instead of getting the assistance that she needs -- either because the allegations in Baby Reindeer are true or because her identity was made public and is now receiving death threats -- is awful. Stories like Baby Reindeer are important and brave, but it's time for a reckoning in our true crime-obsessed society. Sometimes, it's okay to just appreciate a piece of art for what it is and stop trying to dig any further.", "source": {"uri": "avclub.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The A.V. {"uri": "8119764891", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:39:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:39:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:39:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/four-things-real-life-martha-32775807", "title": "Four things 'real' Martha from Baby Reindeer says not true in Piers Morgan chat", "body": "The woman claiming to be the real life Martha from Baby Reindeer spoke out during an interview with Piers Morgan tonight.\n\nFiona Harvey insists that she is the inspiration behind stalker Martha in the hit Netflix show Baby Reindeer.\n\nThe programme tells the story of writer and comedian Richard Gadd's experience of being stalked by a woman named Martha, reports the Mirror.\n\nIn the seven part series, Martha is a terrifying stalker who winds up with a nine month prison sentence for a campaign of harassment against the comic after meeting him in a Camden pub. During an interview with Piers Morgan tonight, she claims several things were untrue, including that he never offered her a free cup of tea, and she never messaged him as much as she said she did.\n\nThe Netflix show is marketed as a 'true story' but, in the interview, she told Piers: \"It's completely untrue. Very, very defamatory to me, very career-damaging. And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions. And this is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nOffer of tea\n\nThe \"real life\" Martha disputed that she had been offered a free cup of tea when he was working in the boozer. Asked directly about that, she said it was completely untrue.\n\nShe explained: \"No, that's not correct. He didn't offer me a cup of tea... I was in for a meal with, a drink of lemonade, and I was very, very hungry. I'm diabetic, so, very hungry. So that's true.\"\n\nCorrespondence\n\nIn the show, Martha sent some 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters to Gadd but the self-proclaimed \"Martha\" has denied this was the case in her experience, insisting she did have correspondence with him but not of this volume.\n\nAsked about this, she said: \"That's simply not true. If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots.\" When asked what she did send, she later added: \"Now, none of that's true. I don't think I sent him anything... No, I think there may have been a couple of emails exchanging, but that was it. Just jokey banter emails. There may have been a couple of emails,\" but insisted she never sent text messages or Facebook messages.\n\nWhen asked if she tweeted him, she added: \"I may have done years and years ago... No, it wasn't numerous. It's about 18 tweets.\"\n\nSmashing up a bar\n\nThe 'real life' Martha has insisted she had never smashed up a bar. She told Piers tonight: \"We've had no apologies from Netflix or him, nothing. I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology. My character seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal, been to prison. There are a number of other allegations, and... That's not true.\"\n\nJail time\n\nShe also denied she has ever faced jail for what happened. The 'real life' Martha has said she did not watch the show and has no plans to - admitting she'd be \"sick\" if she ever laid eyes on the Netflix show.\n\nAsked if she's seen it, she told Piers: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it. I think I'd be sick [if I watched it]. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nWhat is true\n\nDuring the interview, the woman claiming to be the 'real life' Martha called the Netflix show a 'work of fiction', and said there were only two true facts in it.\n\n\"It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said. And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times,\" she told Piers.\n\nNetflix or Gadd himself have yet to comment on claims that Fiona Harvey is the 'real-life' Martha.\n\nNetflix's policy chief Benjamin King said yesterday that the streaming service and the production company \"took every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story.\"\n\nDon't miss the Well done Piers, a new low I see.\"\n\nMeanwhile, others thought it was fair to offer two sides of the story, to which one Instagrammer hit back: \"These comments literally prove the lack of support male victims get... there's two sides to every story??? Why just why?\"\n\nThe interview is set to air on the Piers Morgan Uncensored's YouTube channel on Thursday at 3 p.m. ET (12 p.m. PT) in the U.S. and 8 p.m. in the UK. {"uri": "8119743810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:20:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:20:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:18:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/tv/martha-baby-reindeer-piers-morgan-32775636", "title": "4 things 'real-life' Martha from Baby Reindeer claims is untrue in new interview", "body": "The woman claiming to be the real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer spoke out during an interview with Piers Morgan on Thursday night.\n\nThe individual, who The Mirror has chosen not to name or photograph, insists that she is the inspiration behind stalker Martha in the Netflix show Baby Reindeer. The programme tells the story of writer and comedian Richard Gadd's experience of being stalked by a woman named Martha in the show. In Gadd's seven-part series, Martha is a terrifying stalker who winds up with a nine-month jail sentence for a campaign of harassment against the comic after meeting him in a London pub.\n\nREAD MORE: Baby Reindeer - what's true and what's fiction as 'real Martha' shares her side with Piers Morgan\n\nDuring an interview with Piers Morgan, she claimed several things were untrue about the Netflix show - including that he never offered her a free cup of tea, and she never messaged him as much as he said she did.\n\nThe Netflix show is marketed as a 'true story'. However, in the interview, she told Piers: \"It's completely untrue. Very, very defamatory to me, very career-damaging. And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions. And this is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nOffer of tea\n\nThe \"real-life\" Martha disputed that she had been offered a free cup of tea when he was working in the pub. Asked directly about that, she said it was untrue. She explained: \"No, that's not correct. He didn't offer me a cup of tea... I was in for a meal with, a drink of lemonade, and I was very, very hungry. I'm diabetic, so, very hungry. So that's true.\"\n\nCorrespondence\n\nIn the show, Martha sent 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages and 106 letters to Gadd, but the self-proclaimed \"Martha\" has denied this was the case in her experience, insisting she did have correspondence with him, but not of this volume.\n\nAsked about this, she said: \"That's simply not true. If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots.\" When asked what she did send, she later added: \"Now, none of that's true. I don't think I sent him anything... No, I think there may have been a couple of emails exchanging, but that was it. Just jokey banter emails. There may have been a couple of emails,\" but she insisted she never sent text messages or Facebook messages.\n\nWhen asked if she tweeted him, she added: \"I may have done years and years ago... No, it wasn't numerous. It's about 18 tweets.\"\n\nSmashing up a bar\n\nThe 'real-life' Martha has insisted she never smashed up a bar. She told Piers: \"We've had no apologies from Netflix or him, nothing. I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology. My character seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal, been to prison. There are a number of other allegations, and... That's not true.\"\n\nJail time\n\nShe also denied she has ever faced prison for what happened. The 'real-life' Martha has said she did not watch the show and has no plans to - admitting she'd be \"sick\" if she ever laid eyes on the Netflix show.\n\nAsked if she's seen it, she told Piers: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it. I think I'd be sick [if I watched it]. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nWhat is true\n\nDuring the interview, the woman claiming to be the 'real-life' Martha called the show a 'work of fiction', and said there were just two true facts in it.\n\n\"It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said. And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times,\" she told Piers.\n\nNetflix or Gadd himself have yet to comment on claims the lady - who The Mirror is not identifying through photographs or by name - is the 'real-life' Martha. Netflix's policy chief Benjamin King said that Netflix and the production company \"took every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story\".\n\n*Follow Mirror Celebs and TV on TikTok, Snapchat , Instagram , Twitter , Facebook , YouTube and Threads .\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. {"uri": "8119449574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:09:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:09:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:07:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://movieweb.com/netflix-baby-reindeer-characters-real-identities-controversy/", "title": "Netflix Says They Took 'Every Reasonable Precaution' to Disguise Real-Life Identities Baby Reindeer Characters", "body": "Netflix recently faced scrutiny from the UK Parliament over Baby Reindeer, and if they did everything in their power to protect the innocent.\n\nSummary Benjamin King addressed concerns over viewers guessing the real identities behind characters in Baby Reindeer . Netflix aimed to balance protecting identities with upholding the authenticity of Richard Gadd's story. Despite efforts, real-life individuals like Fiona Harvey faced online backlash after being identified in the show.\n\nSince it's debut on April 11, 2024, Baby Reindeer has become a smash hit for Netflix by racking up almost 54 million views, and staying at the top of the streamers' charts as their most popular English-language series for three consecutive weeks. Not only have viewers been captivated by the story based on comedian Richard Gadd's real-life experiences with a stalker, but internet sleuths have also been trying to figure out the real identities behind the characters. Netflix has said little about what's been happening on social media regarding the guessing game that's been going on, but all that changed recently when policy chief, Benjamin King, stood before the UK Parliament.\n\nAccording to Deadline, King stood before the Culture, Media and Sport Committee to answer questions about whether Netflix did all that it could to keep the identities of the characters in Baby Reindeer under wraps. King commented that Netflix had the difficult task of balancing the job of protecting everyone's identities, while at the same time upholding the \"veracity and authenticity\" of Gadd's story. He says that was the one part they didn't want to \"anonymize.\"\n\n\"We didn't want to anonymize that or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story , because that would undermine the intent behind the show.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer (2024) TV-MA 4.5/5\n\nA seemingly innocent interaction with a customer turns into a chaotic journey as the life of aspiring comedian Donny spirals out of control and brings up the past.\n\nRelease Date April 11, 2024 Cast Richard Gadd , Jessica Gunning , Danny Kirrane , Nava Mau Main Genre Drama Seasons 1\n\nEven though Baby Reindeer stars Richard Gadd and Jessica Gunning have asked fans not to play the guessing game, King would go on to state that it's difficult for Netflix to control what viewers do online in this day and age of social media where everything is scrutinized. However, he also commented that he would not want to live in a world where \"Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.\"\n\n\"Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media. I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story .\"\n\nBaby Reindeer's Real-Life Martha Plans to 'Set the Record Straight' Close\n\nDespite Netflix taking \"every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story,\" according to King, the character of Martha was identified as Scottish lawyer Fiona Harvey, who is obviously outraged by the treatment she's received online and in person since the big reveal. She plans to \"set the record straight\" by telling her side of the story in an interview with Piers Morgan on May 9, 2024. When asked if Netflix has provided any type of support for Harvey, King responded that he didn't think it was appropriate to get into specifics.\n\n\"I cannot get into the specifics of what happened around the making of the show because it wouldn't be appropriate for me to comment. I don't want to give further fuel to some of the theories which are circling on the internet .\"\n\nRelated Baby Reindeer Producers Investigate Alleged Misconduct During the Casting Process The investigation stemmed from a 2021 incident where Gadd dated Reece Lyons, a transgender actress who was interested in auditioning for the series.\n\nThe series and its rabid fan base of amateur sleuths has unfortunately led to some being falsely accused, including Olivier Award-winner Sean Foley, who had to file a report with police after it was wrongly determined that he was the real-life Darrien, the man who is portrayed as having sexually assaulted Richard Gadd. Gadd took to Instagram at the time to shut down the rumors, commenting that people he loves are getting caught up \"unfairly in the speculation.\"\n\n\"People I love, have worked with, and admire (including Sean Foley) are unfairly getting caught up in speculation. Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. That's not the point of our show .\"\n\nKing did point out that Baby Reindeer has gone on to raise awareness for males who are the target of stalking, and that Netflix has worked with the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, a support charity for stalking victims.\n\nBaby Reindeer is available to stream on Netflix, and you can watch the trailer for the series below.", "source": {"uri": "movieweb.com", That's not the point of our show.\"\n\nFoley went on to state on X that he had reported several posts to the police for 'defamatory, abusive, and threatening posts' against him.\n\nThe comments are especially timely due to a woman named Fiona Harvey, the 'real-life Martha', being set to appear on TV for a 'tell-all' interview with Piers Morgan.\n\nNetflix made these comments regarding Baby Reindeer in a Parliamentary hearing, with policy chief Benjamin King telling the hearing that Netflix was 'satisfied with duty of care standards on the show'.\n\nKing went on to tell Parliament that Netflix and the production studio behind Baby Reindeer took 'every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story.'\n\nHe went on to say: \"We didn't want to anonymize [the authenticity of Gadd's story] or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story because that would undermine the intent behind the show\".\n\n\"Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media.\n\n\"I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.\"\n\nThis came after SNP MP John Nicholson pointed out that Netflix's work to protect identities had not prevented the identity of Martha from being discovered by the public.\n\nWhilst Richard Gadd has continued to stress a desire for fans not to find the real-life versions of any of the characters, Harvey has been critical of the series' portrayal of her, stating it gets facts incorrect.\n\nShe told The Daily Record: \"I've not been to prison.\"\n\n\"I don't know where the four -and-a-half years and nine months comes in. None of this happened. It's a load of rubbish.\"\n\nHarvey also told the Scottish newspaper she is planning on taking legal action against Netflix, in which she will represent herself.\n\nShe said: \"There are no restraining orders, injunctions or interdicts anywhere. There's just no way.\n\n\"I've not had the police at my door about any of these things. It's a load of rubbish. I don't have any money but I'm a perfectly capable lawyer so I will represent myself.\"\n\nHarvey's interview with Piers Morgan will air at 8pm tonight, May 9, in the UK.", "source": {"uri": Under her relentless barrage of attention -- including the pet name that gives the series its title -- his life spirals out of control, and past traumas are unearthed. In addition to sending emails, voicemails and Facebook messages, Martha appears at Donny's place of residence, contacts his parents and gropes him without consent, among other frightening behaviors.\n\nAs evidence to support Harvey's claim to be the \"real\" Martha, Morgan cited online sleuths who \"outed\" Harvey as the alleged basis for the character after cross-referencing her social media posts with those depicted in the show. Morgan read several 2014 tweets Harvey sent Gadd, and Harvey said that she knew Gadd for two to three months when he was a bartender about 10 or 12 years ago. Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on @PiersUncensored.\" Morgan's announcement received a mixed reaction, with many excited to watch the interview but others condemning the broadcaster for exploiting a possibly vulnerable woman.\n\nWriting on her Facebook page ahead of her first TV appearance airing at 8pm this evening, the woman told her connections on the social media site: \"Piers is a twerp. But we [already] know this. You will see in my interview.\" She then added: \"I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views. By far most of his other interviews with all misogynist men he often defends Andrew Tate Donald Trump.\"\n\nAlthough many are excited to watch the interview on YouTube this evening, others slammed Morgan as he promoted the chat on social media yesterday. \"This is completely irresponsible. I actually feel a bit sick tbh. Why is contemporary media culture like this? It's like televised cannibalism,\" one wrote to Morgan on Twitter (X).\n\nAnother added: \"exploiting someone who is - if baby reindeer is accurate in its representation - very clearly mentally unwell in the name of \"setting the record straight\" not only puts her in danger but also allows richard gadd's (likely) trauma to be debated for what?? fun?? vile.\"\n\n\"This is completely irresponsible broadcasting and I cannot wait to watch it,\" one conflicted Twitter user joked with their followers, with another potential viewer sharing the same mindset as they wrote: \"kind of shocked and disgusted that piers is exploiting a vulnerable person with severe mental issues that being said I will be watching because curiosity killed the cat.\"\n\nThe smash-hit Netflix series Baby Reindeer chronicles writer and star Richard Gadd's harrowing experience of confronting a relentless stalker named Martha, played by Jessica Gunning. The story, which transpires over seven gripping episodes, portrays Martha as a relentless stalker who eventually gets incarcerated for nine months due to her incessant harassment of the Fifer comic, which started in a Camden pub.\n\nActress Jessica Gunning played Martha in the gripping Netflix series\n\nAmid Baby Reindeer topping streaming charts across the world - and on course to become Netflix's most-watched show - the self-professed 'real Martha' previously revealed that she is contemplating litigation to \"right the wrongs of the show\", alleging a harsh portrayal. She also declared her intention to stand up for herself in court as a \"perfectly capable lawyer\", blaming the Netflix series for turning her life topsy-turvy - all purportedly linked to her relationship with Gadd.\n\nShe told the Daily Record last month: \"I've not been to prison. None of this happened. It's a load of rubbish.\" She also expressed her distress, saying she is now 'living in fear' due to online detectives tracking her down and sending threats. She revealed: \"Gadd and Netflix have portrayed this as a true story and now some little man in North Carolina giving me death threats believes it's a true story. But I think you'd need to be really stupid to believe it is true.\"\n\nShe continued: \"Any semblance of a normal life I had is gone. It's open season on me and this is my chance to speak out. Would it have been better if I spoke to nobody? No, I don't think so.\" The woman also disclosed her plans for a \"major TV appearance soon\" to set the record straight: \"everyone may as well know who I am and at least they'll hear the truth.\" She further clarified: \"I think we can easily prove I'm not a career criminal by saying I've not been to prison. {"uri": "8119725799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:02:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:02:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:02:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/tv/12934414/fiona-harvey-martha-baby-reindeer-piers-morgan-uncensored-youtube/", "title": "What Fiona Harvey said on Piers Morgan's Uncensored YouTube show", "body": "Find out the only things Fiona claims are true about the hit show\n\nFIONA Harvey, who's been dubbed the real Martha from Baby Reindeer, has given her side of the story in a Piers Morgan Uncensored interview.\n\nHere we take an in-depth look at what she had to say about the hit Netflix show and its writer.\n\nFiona has opened up in a wide-ranging interview with Piers Morgan, but the woman who inspired Baby Reindeer took a swipe at The Sun columnist just hours before their chat was due to air.\n\nShe wrote online: \"Piers is a twerp, but we already know this.\n\n\"You will see in my interview.\"\n\nHoping to set the record straight, Fiona accuses the show's writer Richard Gadd of \"making money out of untrue facts\".\n\nAs Fiona said on Piers Morgan Uncensored: \"We've had no apologies from Netflix or him, nothing. I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology.\n\n\"My character seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal, been to prison. There are a number of other allegations, and... That's not true.\"\n\nOn being 'outed' as the 'real-life Martha' online within hours of the show dropping Netflix, she told Piers: \"On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats. So it wasn't really a choice. I was forced into this situation.\"\n\nWhen Piers asked Fiona if she'd watched Baby Reindeer, she replied: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it.\"\n\n\"You're not curious, too?\" Piers added.\n\n\"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic.\n\n\"Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous.\n\n\"I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nFiona told Piers she only found out about the show being picked up on Netflix two weeks ago.\n\nOn Gadd, she said to Piers: \"I just generally think he's got extreme psychiatric problems... It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said.\n\n\"And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times...\"\n\nAsked by Piers whether she told Gadd he looked like a baby reindeer toy she had as a child, Fiona answered: \"I had a toy reindeer and he'd shaved his head, that bit is true, and there were reindeers in the shops because it was Christmas time or something. It was a joke. So I have inadvertently penned the name of the show.\"\n\nWhen Piers pressed her on the 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters she allegedly sent Gadd, she replied: \"That's simply not true. If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots.\"\n\nPushed further by Piers, she admitted there \"may have been a couple of emails... A handful, if that... Less than ten\" -- and went on to reveal she'd also sent him one letter.\n\nAnd in relation to the number of times she allegedly tweeted Gadd, she told Piers: \"I may have done years and years ago... No, it wasn't numerous. It's about 18 tweets.\"\n\nPiers asked Fiona if she'd ever attacked one of Gadd's girlfriends during a jealous rage, to which she replied: \"No, I don't think he had a girlfriend. I think he's, say, homosexual.\n\n\"But no, I have never been to his house or attacked any girlfriend or anything like that.\"\n\nWhen Piers asked her about how true scenes depicting Martha sitting at a bus stop for hours on end were, and whether she'd ever done that, Fiona replied: \"No, I don't know, I don't know where he lived. No. Absolutely no... This is a fictional character. Hyperbole, exaggeration. This is a fiction. It's based on his imagination.\"\n\nShe also denied ever contacting his parents.\n\nDuring the interview Fiona and Piers watched a clip showing Martha pleading guilty to intimidating Gadd's character Donny and being sentenced to nine months in prison.\n\nPiers then asked Fiona whether she'd ever been charged or spent time in prison.\n\nShe replied \"no\" to both questions before adding: \"That's completely untrue. Very, very defamatory to me, very career damaging.\n\n\"And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions, interdicts. This is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nWhen the Uncensored host asked if she was ever in love with Gadd, she responded: \"Piers. Is that a serious question? No... I gave him the brush off.\n\n\"He asked me to sleep with him with a big green spot on his face one day. I said no, I'm sorry, I'm not interested.\n\nShe added: \"I've got a boyfriend'. I gave him the brush off big time, I think, you know, subtly so.\n\n\"But the bottom line is.. No, I don't fancy little boys without jobs. That sounds awful. That sounds really, really callous. But, you know.\"\n\nTurning the tables on the host, Fiona asked Piers how much she thinks Gadd has made out of the hit Netflix show, to which he replied that it could be \"several millions\".\n\nIn response to this, Fiona said: \"I think he's done bloody well out of defaming me... He's making money out of untrue facts. He's been the ultimate misogynist.\"\n\nFiona was also asked by Piers what message she had for Gadd if he was watching, and she replied: \"Leave me alone, please. Get a life, get a proper job. I am horrified at what you've done. \"\n\nWhen Piers asked Fiona in the Uncensored interview whether she would take legal action against Gadd, she answered: \"Absolutely. Against both him and Netflix.\n\nTo watch the full interview tune in to the Piers Morgan Uncensored YouTube channel.\n\nPromoting the must-see TV, the host told fans: \"Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.\n\n\"Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.'\n\n\"Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on Piers Morgan Uncensored.\"\n\nWhile Fiona wrote online: \"Everything about Gadd will not be talked about now until after my TV show.\n\n\"I hope you all tune in. In the 30-minute show, the Scottish law graduate is due to talk openly about being named as comedian Richard Gadd's alleged stalker.\n\nNetflix 's original series Baby Reindeer is based on a true story and follows comedian and performer Richard's experience with a female stalker in his 20s - named Martha in the show - and how the trauma impacted his life. Now, the person accused of being the 'real life' Martha by internet sleuths has spoken out by going head to head with interviewer Piers in a TV clash.\n\nThe woman, who we are not naming, recorded her first \"big TV interview\" with the controversial broadcaster earlier this week in which she aimed to \"set the record straight\". But she told the Daily Record she was \"not happy\" with Piers' questioning and told her Facebook connections that he is a \"bully.\"\n\nShe even branded her interviewer \"a twerp\" and compared Morgan to \"misogynist men he often defends\". The 30-minute Piers Morgan Uncensored special is set to air on the broadcaster's YouTube channel, which has 2.58 million subscribers, later today.\n\nWriting on her Facebook page ahead of her first TV appearance, the woman told her connections: \"Piers is a twerp. But we [already] know this. You will see in my interview.\"\n\nShe then added: \"I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views.\" Referring to some of his previous head-to-head, she added: \"By far most of his other interviews with all misogynist men he often defends Andrew Tate Donald Trump.\"\n\nIn the show Fife-born comic Richard, 34, plays a fictionalised version of himself called Donny Dunn who is ruthlessly stalked by a Scot called Martha. The show tells viewers it is a \"true story\".\n\nRichard asked viewers not to try and track down the real-life Martha. But they defied his plea and found clues that revealed her identity, including references to a Baby Reindeer bar scene in which Martha asks for help getting her curtains hung only to face a barrage of innuendo.\n\nEnglish actress Jessica Gunning, 38, plays Martha, a Scottish woman in her 40s who lives in Camden and studied law. The TV show has become the most viewed programme on Netflix in 30 countries and is billed by the streaming channel as a true story.\n\nThe woman accused says she is now mulling over legal action against both the comedian and Netflix over the character Martha who is depicted being sent to prison twice, once for a historical crime of stalking and again for stalking Richard.
