It has become an overwhelming hit for Netflix following its 11 April release.\n\nIn a pre-taped interview for Piers Morgan Uncensored that aired on Thursday (9 May), Harvey denied stalking Gadd and said she is considering suing Netflix for defamation.\n\nBefore the episode aired on YouTube, viewers questioned the ethics of Morgan's decision to interview Harvey since Gadd told The Independent that the real person who inspired Martha was \"mentally unwell\".\n\nAs it aired, fans shared their guilt about watching the bizarre and controversial interview.\n\n\"Part of me doesn't want to watch the interview but I can't stop watching,\" said one.\n\n\"My face during this whole interview,\" wrote another alongside a gif of Steve Carrell's character in The Office grimacing.\n\n\"Time to watch Piers Morgan conducting one of the most unethical interviews ever,\" added a third.\n\nA fourth shared a gif of a man watching through his fingers.\n\nMorgan's Uncensored did not respond to The Independent's request for comment.\n\nDuring the interview, Harvey denied sending Gadd 41,000 emails and 100 letters while stalking him. Netflix has previously claimed that the emails in the show are the real emails received by Gadd from his stalker.\n\n\"I think he probably made them up himself,\" Harvey alleged, instead suggesting she sent him just \"a handful\". When pressed by Morgan for a number, she said she sent the comedian \"less than 10 emails\".\n\nShe also discussed her treatment online after fans of the show discovered her identity. \"It's taken over enough of my life,\" she said. \"I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous.\"\n\nHowever, Harvey did admit to coming up with the nickname that inspired the series: \"I had a toy reindeer and he'd shaved his head, that bit is true, and there were reindeers in the shops because it was Christmas time or something. It was a joke. So I have inadvertently penned the name of the show.\"\n\nHarvey - a 58-year-old Scottish solicitor - was tracked down by tabloid newspapers after her description closely matched that of Martha.\n\nAttempts have also been made to identify the man who raped Gadd, in a sexual assault that is recreated in the show's fourth episode - and that he explored in 2016 in his award-winning one-man show Monkey See, Monkey Do.\n\nAn actor and director named Sean Foley has indicated that he has contacted police over \"defamatory, abusive and threatening posts\" following speculation made about him in connection to the show.\n\nOn his Instagram, Gadd urged viewers to stop. \"People I love, have worked with, and admire (including Sean Foley) are unfairly caught up in speculation. Please don't speculate on who any of the real-life people could be. That's not the point of our show. It was written by Gadd, who also starred in the show as Donny Dunn. He documented Donny's strange and layered relationship with a woman named Martha, played by Jessica Gunning.\n\nHer initially friendly demeanor unraveled as she begins to stalk Donny relentlessly. Throughout numerous years, Martha sends Donny more than 41,000 emails, 744 tweets, 100 pages of letters and 350 hours of voicemails. In a bid \"to set the record straight\", the woman claiming to be the real-life Martha has spoken to Piers Morgan.\n\nThe woman, who the Mirror has chosen not to name or identify via photographs, was asked by the controversial broadcaster if she was ever in love with Gadd. She replied: \"Piers. Is that a serious question?\" The woman continued: \"No... I gave him the brush off. He asked me to sleep with him with a big green spot in his face one day. I said no I'm sorry, I'm not interested. He asked me to sleep with him.\n\nThe woman claiming to be Martha has said she was never in love with Richard Gadd\n\n\"He said, 'would I like my curtains fixed'? And I laughed and he said, that's a euphemism. You want me to come home with you? And I said, 'I've got a boyfriend'. I gave him the brush off big time, I think, you know, subtly so. But the bottom line is.. No, I don't fancy little boys without jobs. That sounds awful. That sounds really, really callous. But, you know.\"\n\nShe also addressed her own love life during the interview where she said she was in a five-year relationship with a lawyer. The woman told Piers: \"I don't want to drag him in. He thinks this is horrendous. All of my lawyer friends do. All of my professional friends do. Other people do. People are being really sympathetic. People I don't know are saying things like, 'Are you getting hounded in the street?' You know, people are being really, really nice, anyone who does know about this.\"\n\nDuring the sit down interview with Piers Morgan, he asked what she would say to him if he was watching. She replied: \"Leave me alone, please. Get a life, get a proper job. I am horrified at what you've done.\" The woman also revealed she hasn't watched the Netflix series. Asked if she had seen it, she said: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it.\"\n\nPiers asked: \"You're not curious, too?\" She replied: \"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok , Snapchat , Instagram , Twitter , Facebook , YouTube and Threads .", It was written by Richard Gadd, who starred as struggling comedian Donny Dunn and showed his strange and layered relationship with a woman named Martha, played by Jessica Gunning.\n\nThroughout the series, she began to stalk Donny relentlessly and Martha ended up sending Donny more than 41,000 emails, 744 tweets, 100 pages of letters and 350 hours of voicemails. In a bid \"to set the record straight\", the woman claiming to be the real-life Martha has spoken to Piers Morgan in her first televised interview.\n\nThe woman, who the Mirror has chosen not to name or identify via photographs, addressed the number of emails it was claimed Martha sent in the show. She said: \"There are not 41,000 emails. That's over a year.\" Piers replied: \"According to you there's only a handful.\" The woman added: \"Yeah. I mean how long would that take someone to type up?\"\n\nControversial broadcaster Piers asked: \"How many do you think you sent him?\" She replied: \"A handful, if that.\" The woman was then pushed about what she meant and asked to give a number. She told Piers: \"Less than ten.\" Piers repeated: \"Ten emails.\" The woman continued: \"Not 41,000.\" The host quipped: \"There's a massive disparity between the two things,\" as she added: \"I agree, I agree.\"\n\nThe 'real-life' Martha has shared how many emails she sent Richard Gadd\n\nDuring the sit down interview, Piers asked what she would say to him if he was watching. I haven't watched any of it.\"\n\nPiers asked: \"You're not curious, too?\" She replied: \"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. {"uri": "8119661631", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:02:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:02:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:01:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/05/09/opinion/combative-baby-reindeer-subject-fiona-harvey-rang-suspicious-alarm-bells-but-she-may-also-be-a-victim/", "title": "Combative 'Baby Reindeer' subject Fiona Harvey rang suspicious alarm...", "body": "The Netflix show \"Baby Reindeer\" has become a sensation, skyrocketing to No. 1 on the streaming service in 30 countries, including the US. Created by and starring Scottish comedian Richard Gadd, the show is based on his real-life experience. The psychological thriller centers around Donny (Gadd), a struggling comedian who meets Martha (Jessica Gunning) during a bartending gig. The encounter quickly spirals into a terrifying stalking case.\n\nThe real Martha has now allegedly come forward, claiming Gadd's version of the story is \"completely untrue.\"\n\n\"Very, very defamatory to me, very career-damaging. And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions. And this is just complete nonsense,\" Fiona Harvey, 58, said on \"Piers Morgan Uncensored,\" which aired Thursday. \"I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic.\"\n\nI've interviewed a lot of very dangerous people in my career, from serial killers to medically diagnosed psychopaths.\n\nAnd the common denominator is that they're invariably very skilled liars, often because their warped minds have made them believe what they're saying even if facts speak otherwise.\n\nFiona Harvey hasn't killed anyone.\n\nBut if she did all the things she is depicted as doing in Baby Reindeer, then she is certainly a very unstable, obsessive, and threatening stalker who made Richard Gadd's life utter hell.\n\nAnd indeed, the lives of other people she's accused of harassing too. But IS it all true?\n\nNetflix boasts it's a \"true story\" at the start of the series, without equivocation. And lest there be any doubt of the streamer's position, Benjamin King, Netflix's Senior Director of Public Policy in the UK, told a Parliamentary committee this week: \"'Baby Reindeer' is an extraordinary story, and it is obviously a true story of the horrific abuse that the writer and protagonist, Richard Gadd, suffered at the hands of a convicted stalker.\"\n\nYet Fiona says she's never been convicted of stalking Gadd, let alone shame-facedly admitted it in court as the show says.\n\nAnd no journalists have yet found any evidence that she has ever been charged or convicted of any crime.\n\nPerhaps she's lying.\n\nBut it's not a difficult thing to check, and if it turns out that Fiona Harvey has never been convicted of stalking Gadd or anyone else, then that surely blows a massive hole in Baby Reindeer's credibility?\n\nAnd it would call into serious question just how much of Gadd's version of events can be believed.\n\nNetflix also claims it did everything possible to avoid the real people behind the characters in the show being identified.\n\nBut the actress they chose to play Martha bears a striking resemblance physically, and in the way she spoke in the series, to Fiona Harvey.\n\nAnd as a result of all the clues they gave, including specific phrases used in tweets and messages purportedly from Martha to Gadd, internet sleuths identified her in about ten nanoseconds.\n\nThis led very quickly to people bombarding Fiona Harvey with abuse and death threats.\n\nAll of which points to a spectacular duty of care failure by Netflix, Gadd, and Clerkenwell Films who produced the series, which I would think carries with it serious legal jeopardy.\n\nOf course, none of this means Fiona Harvey told me the truth. I found her to be intelligent, quick-thinking, and combative.\n\nAnd on a human level, I felt sorry for her that she's been publicly dragged through the mincer like this.\n\nHer general behavior, on and off camera, with me and my team didn't give any of us cause for concern about either her potential danger or her mental state, though it should be said that stalkers can be very convincing in their ability to hide their real personalities or obsessive intent.\n\nBut there were moments in the interview where my suspicious alarm bells rang loud, especially when she suddenly said, \"Even if the email thing was true, the rest is not.\"\n\nThe \"email thing\" is the 41,000 emails she's said to have sent Gadd. And if that bit is true, then it would suggest she was very obsessively pursuing contact with him.\n\nI also found it very strange that she admitted to having up to six email addresses, and 4 mobile phones which she \"used for different people.\"\n\nThat's not normal.\n\nShe also made a series of emphatic blanket denials about how long she knew Gadd, and how much contact she had with him that are provably false.\n\nThe claim that she only sent him one letter, when he says he has 105, seems especially disingenuous.\n\nOn balance, I'd say Fiona Harvey lied to me quite a lot in the interview and if her threatened legal action against Netflix and Gadd goes ahead, I suspect it will quickly emerge she did send all the emails, messages, and letters to him.\n\nBut that doesn't mean she can't be a victim here too.\n\nGadd, by his own admission, is a very damaged guy who took a lot of drugs, enthusiastically pursued a chaotic lurid sex life, and did lead on Martha in a way that may have fueled her obsession. He's also been accused of propositioning trans actresses who he was lining up for work.\n\nFrankly, it's all a mess.\n\nBut if Richard Gadd feels entitled to make millions airing his side of the story, and make very serious allegations about Fiona Harvey in the process, then she is surely entitled to respond and defend herself.\n\nAs for who is exploiting whom, I'll leave that to the court of public opinion to decide.", "source": {"uri": "nypost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New York Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baby_Reindeer", "type": {"uri": "8119826160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:41:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:41:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:37:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/m-suing-netflix-says-woman-212933662.html", "title": "I'm suing Netflix, says woman named as Baby Reindeer stalker", "body": "The woman named as a real-life stalker who inspired the series Baby Reindeer has said she will sue Netflix, and has accused the show's writer of being \"obsessed\" with her.\n\nFiona Harvey, 58, has broken her silence after fans of the hit drama claimed to have identified her as the person who inspired the character of Martha just hours after its release last month.\n\nIn an interview with Piers Morgan Uncensored on TalkTV, she claimed no one from Netflix had contacted her, and said she had been depicted in a \"defamatory\" way.\n\nWritten by and starring Richard Gadd, a 34-year-old comedian, the drama charts the \"suffocating obsession\" of Martha towards him \"which threatens to wreck both their lives\", as well as his experience of being raped by a man.\n\nIn her first time on camera, Ms Harvey claimed the series was \"completely untrue\" and \"a work of fiction\", despite each of the seven episodes carrying the claim: \"This is a true story.\"\n\nAsked if she would be taking legal action, she said she \"absolutely\" would \"against both him and Netflix\", adding that she had instructed lawyers \"in part\".\n\nNetflix and Gadd have been contacted for comment. Gadd recently asked fans on Instagram: \"Please don't speculate on who any of the real-life people could be. That's not the point of the show.\"\n\nDuring the interview, Ms Harvey denied ever being at Gadd's home, contacting his parents or sending thousands of texts and emails. But she admitted owning four mobile phones and four to six different email addresses, as well as having a toy reindeer when she was younger, as depicted in the series.\n\nShe told Morgan she was in a five-year relationship with a lawyer and had never been charged with a criminal offence. In Baby Reindeer, Martha is given a prison sentence for stalking.\n\nAsked if it was true Gadd had offered her a free cup of tea after she first walked into the pub where he was working, Ms Harvey said she was actually having a meal with lemonade as she is diabetic, and had met him only \"five or six times\" in her life.\n\nAsked if she spoke with him after first meeting him, she told Talk TV: \"He interrupted a conversation... he said, 'Oh, you're Scottish', and basically commandeered the conversation.\n\n\"You know, I was talking to somebody. It's pretty rich. Interrupt. So he seemed to be obsessed with me from that moment onwards.\"\n\nPressed on the 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters she is alleged to have sent Gadd, Ms Harvey said: \"That's simply not true.\"\n\nShe accepted sending him \"a handful\" of emails, which she numbered as \"less than ten\", and sent \"about 18 tweets\" to him \"years and years ago\" as well as a letter. She said she also went to one of his comedy shows.\n\nShe was questioned about the possibility of Gadd having voice messages from her in real life, but claimed these \"would be [from] taping me in the Hawley Arms\".\n\n\"I mean, my point is, though, even if that were true, I didn't lunge at him across the bar. I didn't sexual[ly] assault him in a canal. I didn't go to jail,\" she said.\n\n\"On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats. So it wasn't really a choice. I was forced into this situation,\" she said.\n\nMs Harvey told Morgan she had a \"standard Scottish\" upbringing, and had not told her mother about the drama.\n\nSpeaking in Parliament this week, Netflix policy chief Benjamin King said that the streamer and Clerkenwell Films, which made the show, took \"every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story\".\n\nHe added: \"I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.\"", "source": {"uri": If you haven't seen the series yet, it's worth watching before you sit down with Piers and Harvey to hear what the lady has to say.\n\nSince the show hit the streaming service, Harvey said she is considering legal action to 'right the wrongs of the show' in which she claims that she is portrayed as a terrifying stalker. {"uri": "8119726759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:03:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:03:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:03:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/tv/27830763/fiona-harvey-martha-baby-reindeer-piers-morgan-uncensored-youtube/", "title": "What Fiona Harvey said on Piers Morgan's Uncensored YouTube show", "body": "Find out the only things Fiona claims are true about the hit show\n\nFIONA Harvey, who's been dubbed the real Martha from Baby Reindeer, has given her side of the story in a Piers Morgan Uncensored interview.\n\nShe wrote online: \"Piers is a twerp, but we already know this.\n\n\"You will see in my interview.\"\n\nHoping to set the record straight, Fiona accuses the show's writer Richard Gadd of \"making money out of untrue facts\".\n\nAs Fiona said on Piers Morgan Uncensored: \"We've had no apologies from Netflix or him, nothing. I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology.\n\n\"My character seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal, been to prison. There are a number of other allegations, and... That's not true.\"\n\nOn being 'outed' as the 'real-life Martha' online within hours of the show dropping Netflix, she told Piers: \"On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats. So it wasn't really a choice. I was forced into this situation.\"\n\nWhen Piers asked Fiona if she'd watched Baby Reindeer, she replied: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it.\"\n\n\"You're not curious, too?\" Piers added.\n\n\"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic.\n\n\"Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous.\n\n\"I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nFiona told Piers she only found out about the show being picked up on Netflix two weeks ago.\n\nOn Gadd, she said to Piers: \"I just generally think he's got extreme psychiatric problems... It's a work of fiction. It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said.\n\n\"And there are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits in the Hawley Arms. And we met, two or three times...\"\n\nAsked by Piers whether she told Gadd he looked like a baby reindeer toy she had as a child, Fiona answered: \"I had a toy reindeer and he'd shaved his head, that bit is true, and there were reindeers in the shops because it was Christmas time or something. It was a joke. So I have inadvertently penned the name of the show.\"\n\nWhen Piers pressed her on the 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters she allegedly sent Gadd, she replied: \"That's simply not true. If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots.\"\n\nPushed further by Piers, she admitted there \"may have been a couple of emails... A handful, if that... Less than ten\" -- and went on to reveal she'd also sent him one letter.\n\nAnd in relation to the number of times she allegedly tweeted Gadd, she told Piers: \"I may have done years and years ago... No, it wasn't numerous. It's about 18 tweets.\"\n\nPiers asked Fiona if she'd ever attacked one of Gadd's girlfriends during a jealous rage, to which she replied: \"No, I don't think he had a girlfriend. I think he's, say, homosexual.\n\n\"But no, I have never been to his house or attacked any girlfriend or anything like that.\"\n\nWhen Piers asked her about how true scenes depicting Martha sitting at a bus stop for hours on end were, and whether she'd ever done that, Fiona replied: \"No, I don't know, I don't know where he lived. No. Absolutely no... This is a fictional character. Hyperbole, exaggeration. This is a fiction. It's based on his imagination.\"\n\nShe also denied ever contacting his parents.\n\nDuring the interview Fiona and Piers watched a clip showing Martha pleading guilty to intimidating Gadd's character Donny and being sentenced to nine months in prison.\n\nPiers then asked Fiona whether she'd ever been charged or spent time in prison.\n\nShe replied \"no\" to both questions before adding: \"That's completely untrue. Very, very defamatory to me, very career damaging.\n\n\"And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions, interdicts. This is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nWhen the Uncensored host asked if she was ever in love with Gadd, she responded: \"Piers. Is that a serious question? No... I gave him the brush off.\n\n\"He asked me to sleep with him with a big green spot on his face one day. I said no, I'm sorry, I'm not interested.\n\nShe added: \"I've got a boyfriend'. I gave him the brush off big time, I think, you know, subtly so.\n\n\"But the bottom line is.. No, I don't fancy little boys without jobs. That sounds awful. That sounds really, really callous. But, you know.\"\n\nTurning the tables on the host, Fiona asked Piers how much she thinks Gadd has made out of the hit Netflix show, to which he replied that it could be \"several millions\".\n\nIn response to this, Fiona said: \"I think he's done bloody well out of defaming me... He's making money out of untrue facts. He's been the ultimate misogynist.\"\n\nFiona was also asked by Piers what message she had for Gadd if he was watching, and she replied: \"Leave me alone, please. Get a life, get a proper job. I am horrified at what you've done. \"\n\nWhen Piers asked Fiona in the Uncensored interview whether she would take legal action against Gadd, she answered: \"Absolutely. Against both him and Netflix.\n\nTo watch the full interview tune in to the Piers Morgan Uncensored YouTube channel.\n\nPromoting the must-see TV, the host told fans: \"Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.\n\n\"Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.'\n\n\"Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on Piers Morgan Uncensored.\"\n\nWhile Fiona wrote online: \"Everything about Gadd will not be talked about now until after my TV show.\n\n\"I hope you all tune in. {"uri": "8119829624", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:42:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:42:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:41:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/05/09/arts/television/baby-reindeer-fiona-harvey-stalking.html", "title": "Woman Who Says She Inspired 'Baby Reindeer' Character Denies Stalking", "body": "The show, a surprise Netflix hit that says it is based on real events, had inspired viewers to try to uncover the real identities of the characters depicted onscreen.\n\nAs the surprise success of \"Baby Reindeer,\" the Netflix drama about a comedian and his stalker, has highlighted the complications that can arise from basing a popular series on real events, a woman who claims to be the inspiration for the stalker character said on Thursday that much of the show's plot was untrue, calling it a \"work of fiction.\"\n\nIn the four weeks since \"Baby Reindeer\" debuted, it has been viewed more than 56 million times, according to data released by Netflix. The intense interest in the seven-episode series, which is billed as a true story based on the experience of the comedian Richard Gadd, has also spawned an army of amateur detectives trying to uncover the actual identities of the characters onscreen.\n\nThose efforts have resulted in the online abuse of a British writer and director as well as blowback for Netflix officials, one of whom was questioned about the streamer's \"duty of care\" by a British lawmaker this week. Gadd has all but begged internet sleuths to stop digging, writing on social media: \"Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. That's not the point of the show.\"\n\nBut in an interview that ran Thursday, Fiona Harvey, who says that the show's stalker character was modeled after her, provided her side of the story on camera for the first time.\n\nIn \"Baby Reindeer,\" a woman named Martha (Jessica Gunning) approaches an aspiring comedian, Donny (Gadd), while he is working as a bartender and eventually torments him through emails and voice mail messages.\n\nIn an hourlong interview on YouTube with the television personality Piers Morgan, Harvey said she had not watched the series -- \"I think I'd be sick,\" she said -- but had become aware of her connection to it after reading news media reports and being contacted by journalists. Certain details in the show had convinced some viewers that Harvey was the inspiration for Martha.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8118465377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:41:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:41:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:41:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/baby-reindeer-episode-4-darrien-richard-gadd-b2541979.html", "title": "Richard Gadd says Baby Reindeer crew cried while filming traumatic fourth episode", "body": "Baby Reindeer creator Richard Gadd has said filming the drama's fourth episode was hard not just for him but for the entire crew.\n\nSpeaking at the DGA Theater Complex for Netflix's FYC screening and panel for the limited series on Tuesday night, along with actors Jessica Gunning and Nava Mau, director Weronika Tofilska, and editor Peter Oliver, Gadd described going into an \"obsessive place\" while writing the series and the toll filming his sexual assault took on him and the crew.\n\n\"We did close the set, but I was looking over and you'd see the props guys wiping tears from their eyes as they would be putting the props back how they should be,\" Gadd recalled about filming episode 4, which features a graphic portrayal of sexual violence as Donny is groomed and later abused by an older and successful TV writer he meets at the Edinburgh Fringe festival.\n\n\"The show was based in such a trauma that everyone on set felt at times it was a huge, weighty thing. And it's why I think everyone had such respect for everything. I was blessed with this amazing team who kind of felt it with me in a lot of ways.\"\n\n\"I never wanted to kind of lie,\" he said about writing the series.\n\n\"I always had to constantly check myself to be like, 'Does this feel truthful to me to my experience all the way through?' And if it didn't, I would have to bring it back.\"\n\nGadd, 34, himself stars in the Netflix series which is based on his real-life experiences of stalking and sexual abuse.\n\nBaby Reindeer follows struggling comic Donny Dunn, played by Gadd, as he is relentlessly harassed and stalked by Martha Scott, played by Jessica Gunning, for four and a half years.\n\nA subplot sees Dunn groomed and raped by an older man called Darrian, played by Tom Goodman-Hill, who works in the comedy industry. Similar events happened to Gadd in real life which became the subject of the fourth episode.\n\nSince the seven-episode show's release on 11 April, it has become a word-of-mouth sensation, shooting to the top of the streaming service's most-watched charts with very little promotion.\n\nNetflix has now submitted Baby Reindeer to the Emmy Awards for consideration as the best limited series and Gadd as the best actor and the best writer.\n\nGadd previously talked about the charity We Are Survivors and thanked them for supporting him through the years.\n\n\"Sometimes I speak to male survivors, and I'm not an advice giver or a professional, but the first advice is: break the silence. Talk to someone, and if that's too scary, just write it down, process it into something. Because I think the more you get it out, the smaller it becomes,\" he told The Guardian.\n\nAt the panel, Gunning again brought up the charity, which works with male and nonbinary sexual abuse, rape and sexual exploitation survivors across Greater Manchester, saying it had seen a 200 percent increase in people looking for support, with 60 per cent saying Baby Reindeer was the reason behind them getting in touch.\n\n\"It's not an easy, buttoned-up story,\" Gunning said.\n\n\"Everything doesn't get tied up at the end. I think it's messy, like life is. Their dynamic is complicated and he's really honest about that. That's so refreshing to see. The response to it is shown that audiences are really hungry for that. Hungry for honest, messy storytelling.\"\n\nMany have praised Gunning's sensitive portrayal of Scott, including The Independent's chief TV critic Nick Hilton, who said in his four-star review of the show: \"Gunning's performance as Martha adds another layer of ambiguity: at times she is vicious, at times she is vulnerable, but she's always a compelling presence in his life and on It was written by Gadd, who also starred in the show as Donny Dunn. He documented Donny's strange and layered relationship with a woman named Martha, played by Jessica Gunning.\n\nIn the show, her initially friendly demeanour unravels as she begins to stalk Donny relentlessly. Throughout numerous years, Martha sends Donny more than 41,000 emails, 744 tweets, 100 pages of letters and 350 hours of voicemails. In a bid \"to set the record straight\", the woman claiming to be the real-life Martha has spoken to Piers Morgan.\n\nREAD MORE: 4 things self-proclaimed 'real-life' Martha from Baby Reindeer claims are untrue in new Piers Morgan interview\n\nThe woman, who the Mirror has chosen not to name or identify via photographs, was asked by the controversial broadcaster if she was ever in love with Gadd. She replied: \"Piers. Is that a serious question?\" The woman continued: \"No... I gave him the brush off. He asked me to sleep with him with a big green spot in his face one day. I said 'no I'm sorry, I'm not interested'. He asked me to sleep with him.\n\n\"He said, 'would I like my curtains fixed'? And I laughed and he said, 'That's a euphemism. You want me to come home with you?' And I said, 'I've got a boyfriend'. I gave him the brush off big time, I think, you know, subtly so. But the bottom line is... No, I don't fancy little boys without jobs. That sounds awful. That sounds really, really callous. But, you know.\"\n\nShe also addressed her own love life during the interview, where she said she was in a five-year relationship with a lawyer. The woman told Piers: \"I don't want to drag him in. He thinks this is horrendous. All of my lawyer friends do. All of my professional friends do. Other people do. People are being really sympathetic. People I don't know are saying things like, 'Are you getting hounded in the street?' You know, people are being really, really nice, anyone who does know about this.\"\n\nDuring the sit-down interview with Piers Morgan, he asked what she would say to Gadd if he was watching. She replied: \"Leave me alone, please. Get a life, get a proper job. I am horrified at what you've done.\" The woman also revealed she hasn't watched the Netflix series. Asked if she had seen it, she said: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it.\"\n\nPiers asked: \"You're not curious, too?\" She replied: \"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. {"uri": "8119826142", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:49:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:49:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:37:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/baby-reindeer-real-life-martha-213219571.html", "title": "'Baby Reindeer's' Real-Life Martha Has a Heated Sit-Down With Piers Morgan", "body": "Fiona Harvey has emphatically denied that she did most of the things the fictional version of herself did in Netflix's hit series Baby Reindeer -- but she wasn't terribly convincing.\n\nWeeks after fans of the show identified her as the real-life inspiration behind Martha, the show's stalker character, through some old tweets, Harvey had her first sit-down interview with British broadcaster Piers Morgan. In the interview, which aired Thursday afternoon, Harvey officially came forward as the real-life Martha and called Richard Gadd, the writer and star of the series who plays a fictionalized version of himself, a \"liar\" and \"misogynist\" who's profiting off her misery by embellishing their interactions with one another. Both Gadd and Netflix have said the series is \"a true story.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer follows Gadd's complicated relationship with his stalker, as he's plagued by Martha's constant presence and correspondence, which he says consisted of 41,000 emails, 350 voicemails, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters. But Harvey said this week that none of that ever happened -- and she plans to sue Gadd, Netflix, and anyone else who's \"going along and being in that play and doing this to somebody.\"\n\nAccording to Harvey, she and Gadd only met \"two or three times\" in real life. \"I don't lie,\" she told Morgan in their interview. But she was somehow both emphatic in her denial and uncertain at the same time. Harvey told Morgan that her only message to Gadd would be, \"Leave me alone please. Get a life, get a proper job,.\" She added, \"I am horrified at what you've done,\" and called him \"the ultimate misogynist\" and \"psychopath.\"\n\nHowever, Harvey got a bit wobbly when asked to defend herself. Questioned about whether or not she'd sent Gadd 41,000 emails, Harvey doubled down that the show is \"a figure of [Gadd's] imagination,\" but later admitted, \"There may have been a couple of emails,\" but just \"jokey banter ones.\" She said that at the time, \"I didn't think [Gadd] was a complete psychopath that would attack me.\"\n\n\"Even if it were true\" that she'd sent Gadd 41,000 emails (\"just playing devil's advocate here,\" she said), \"I didn't lunge at him across the bar, I didn't go to jail,\" as depicted in the series. Morgan pointed out that law enforcement could likely pinpoint which device the emails came from and whether it belonged to her -- and now that the world has heard her voice, it could easily be determined whether or not she'd left him the 350 voicemails. His line of questioning ultimately drove Harvey to clash with her interviewer. \"You've gone on at length for a good 10 minutes about the emails,\" she said to Morgan, sounding heated.\n\n\"I wouldn't be suing if I thought 41,000 emails were out there,\" she added, with the caveat that \"it wouldn't blow the case\" if that many emails were found. She also let slip that she has \"four phones\" and \"six email addresses\" -- but only because she likes separate communications on different devices, she said.\n\nHow Netflix's Stalker Series 'Baby Reindeer' Became a Viral Sensation\n\nAs far as the alleged 350 voicemails, Harvey initially said she \"doubt[s]\" Gadd really has that many voicemails and said, \"I've not phoned the guy\" -- but she later admitted to calling him before and even writing him a letter. If Gadd is able to provide 350 voicemails as evidence, Harvey said it'd only be because he'd taped her in the interest of drumming up media attention for his series. \"He's maybe forged things. People have forged a lot of things these days,\" she said of the other 105 handwritten letters she said she didn't write.\n\nKeeping up with the flip-flopping theme of the conversation, Harvey first told Morgan that she'd be willing to take a lie detector test to prove that she hadn't stalked Gadd, since \"I don't fancy little boys without jobs.\" But on second thought, \"A lie detector test for what?\" she asked, pushing the conversation to a different topic: \"They used [lie detectors] for mass murder and things. They don't use them that much.\"\n\nIn all, Harvey said the way she's been depicted in the series is \"completely untrue\" and has been \"very career-damaging\" to her job as an attorney, ever since social media users discovered her identity. \"Internet sleuths tracked me down, hounded me, gave me death threats,\" she said.\n\n\"[Gadd and Netflix] are milking it for all it's worth, for the money,\" she continued, adding that the actress playing Martha, Jessica Gunning, doesn't even look like her -- a point on which many viewers have disagreed.\n\nThe Scene That Should Win Netflix's 'Baby Reindeer' an Emmy\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. {"uri": "8118948557", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:29:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:29:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:29:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://thetab.com/uk/2024/05/09/i-feel-a-bit-used-what-to-expect-from-real-life-marthas-interview-with-piers-morgan-364892", "title": "'I feel a bit used': What to expect from real-life Martha's interview with Piers Morgan", "body": "She said she chose Piers Morgan's show 'because he's the best of them all'\n\nAfter breaking her anonymity and outing herself as the \"real-life Martha\" from Baby Reindeer, Fiona Harvey will now appear on Piers Morgan's show Uncensored tonight, determined to tell her side of the story and \"set the record straight\".\n\nBut what can we expect from the interview and how did it all come about? This is everything we can expect from Fiona Harvey's Piers Morgan interview tonight:\n\nIn an interview with the Daily Record, Fiona described her talk with Piers as a \"sparring match\" where she was forced to refute claims that she \"loved\" Richard Gadd.\n\nFiona said that Piers refused to accept her denial that she stalked Richard Gadd, saying: \"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent.\n\n\"I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself but I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast-paced to catch me off guard.\n\n\"Piers kept saying to me 'are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?'. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this.\n\n\"I said, 'Look, Even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff. As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100 per cent true.\n\nFiona Harvey also confirmed she was only paid \u00a3250 for the interview.\"It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used,\" she said.\n\nPiers told her the interview went well, however. \"He landed a few punches on me and I landed a few punches on him.\"\n\nDuring the half an hour interview, Piers asks Fiona whether she loved Richard Gadd and she replies \"you've got to be joking.\"\n\nTelling how the interview with Piers was set up, Fiona said: \"Piers contacted me last week about going on his show and, of course, I agreed. This Morning and everybody else has been chasing me.\n\n\"I've had people telling me they are publicists or agents but it's difficult to know who to trust. I've had people using the most foul language on the phone telling me they could make me a lot of money.\n\n\"How all these people got my phone number I just don't know but it's been hell.\"\n\nBut after calls by many other shows, Fiona said \"Piers and his people got in touch and I said yes because he's the best of them all and is seen by an awful lot of people.\n\n\"He is the biggest interviewer out there and has the biggest show so obviously I was going to speak to him. Piers sent a car to pick me up and drop me off.\n\nFiona \"Let him know what was off limits\" before the interview. \"I told him I wouldn't talk about boyfriends or my family,\" she said.\n\nBaby Reindeer is available on Netflix now. {"uri": "8119758751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:34:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:34:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:33:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/story/baby-reindeer-real-life-martha-speaks-out-piers-morgan-interview-richard-gadd-is-obsessed-with-me", "title": "Baby Reindeer's Real-Life Martha Speaks Out: Richard Gadd Is \"Obsessed With Me\"", "body": "Less than a month after the debut of Netflix's Baby Reindeer, which centers on creator and star Richard Gadd's experiences with an actual stalker, the woman who allegedly inspired the character of Martha has revealed herself -- and denied that Gadd's portrayal of her is accurate. Fiona Harvey, a 58-year-old Scottish woman who has previously been accused of stalking, now claims that Gadd is \"obsessed\" with her.\n\nSpeaking with Piers Morgan on Thursday's episode of his YouTube show, Harvey said she was forced to go public after the show debuted on April 11. \"The internet sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats,\" she said. \"So it wasn't really a choice.\" VF has reached out to reps for Netflix and Gadd for comment.\n\nHarvey, who says she has not watched any of the seven-episode series, referred to it as \"obscene,\" \"horrifying,\" and \"misogynistic\" in its depiction of Martha, a character played by Jessica Gunning. After first revealing her identity in an interview with The Daily Record, Harvey offered further details of her alleged relationship with Gadd, claiming to only have met him \"two or three times\" -- a number that shifted to \"five, six times\" by the interview's end.\n\nUnlike Baby Reindeer's Martha and Gadd's Donny, Harvey says that Gadd did not buy her a cup of tea on the day they met. \"Nobody gets anything for free at The Holy Arms,\" she said, referencing the pub where they allegedly met, before claiming that Gadd \"commandeered the conversation\" she was having with another person at the bar. \"He seemed to be obsessed with me from that moment onwards,\" Harvey said.\n\nMorgan pressed Harvey about the fact that both Netflix and Gadd say he is in possession of around 41,000 emails, 350 voice messages, 106 letters, and a number of tweets she sent to him. Harvey admitted to sending \"a handful\" of \"jokey banter emails,\" one letter, and some tweets, which can still be publicly viewed. One, dated September 1, 2014, reads, \"did you get my emails or am I emailing the wrong address?\" Harvey denied having left Gadd any voicemails. \"Unless he was taping me in The Holy Arms, I didn't phone him,\" she said. Morgan asked, \"Are you challenging him to reveal his audience?\" to which she replied, \"No, I'd challenge him to leave me alone.\"\n\nHarvey maintained that she was able to identify herself in Martha not because of the stalking, but the Netflix series' title. \"I appear to have written most of the show in my sleep,\" she said. \"I had a toy reindeer and he shaved his head, that bit is true. It was a joke. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.'\n\nShe claims Morgan, 59, grilled her over the subject of 41,000 emails sent to Gadd for a 10 minute chunk of the interview.\n\nIn an attempt to defend herself, she hit back that even if the emails are true, it does not mean the entire saga was completely factual.\n\n'It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used,' Harvey added.\n\nMorgan reportedly described the interaction as a 'sparring match' between the pair, for which his interviewee claims she was only paid \u00a3250.\n\nShe claims she has been in 'hell' as she was hounded for interviews but caved to the former Good Morning Britain host because she liked him.\n\nAs part of the deal, the 'real Martha' was given a professional hair stylist and glam team to help prepare for the first ever on screen appearance.\n\n'Piers said it went well,' Harvey continued. 'He referred to it as a sparring match. He landed a few punches on me and I landed a few punches on him. He asked me if I loved Richard Gadd and I said you've got to be joking.'\n\nThe 30-minute special will air on the Uncensored YouTube channel, which has 2.58 million subscribers, at 8pm tonight.\n\nIn a tweet, Morgan wrote: '*WORLD EXCLUSIVE* The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.\n\n'Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' {"uri": "8119741648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "20:16:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T20:16:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T20:16:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/tv/baby-reindeers-real-life-martha-29142016", "title": "What we learned from interview with Baby Reindeer's 'real-life Martha'", "body": "In her first bombshell broadcast interview, Baby Reindeer's 'real-life' Martha sat down with TV's Piers Morgan to 'set the record straight' on the story that has caught the eyes of the world.\n\nIn the drama series, inspired by the experiences of comedian and writer Richard Gadd, his character Donny is stalked by a woman called Martha after he serves her a free cup of tea in the pub where he works.\n\nFiona Harvey, 58, the woman now believed to be the inspiration behind the character Martha in the hit Netflix series, said she had been 'forced' into doing the interview on Piers Morgan: Uncensored after being contacted by 'online sleuths' and sent death threats.\n\nREAD MORE: Baby Reindeer's Richard Gadd 'struggling to cope with fame' with fans 'camping in his garden'\n\nFollowing its release viewers have been attempting track down the real Martha. Fiona Harvey has come forward as the inspiration behind the character and said: \"He's come up with this character called Martha and he has put me right in the frame.\"\n\nHere is what we learnt from the hour-long interview, which was streamed live on Youtube on Thursday night (May 9)...\n\nFiona denied sending Gadd over 40,000 emails\n\nPiers Morgan questioned whether Fiona Harvey had sent Richard Gadd over 40,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages and 106 letters.\n\nShe denied sending him the alleged 41,000 emails sent to Gadd, some of which were shown in the show, adding: \"It's simply not true.\"\n\nShe added: \"If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots. How many would that take somebody to type up?\" Pressed on where this information came from, she replied: \"I've no idea.\"\n\nShe later said she sent him 'a few emails' and approximated 'less than 10' when questioned by Morgan, admitting she sent him only 'jokey, bantery emails'.\n\nFiona claimed Richard Gadd was actually 'obsessed' with her\n\nMs Harvey said that despite not actually watching the show, she thought it was 'horrifying' Gadd had promoted it. She first claimed she had only met Gadd 'two or three times' before later approximating it was 'five to six times'.\n\nShe said the show was a 'work of fiction'. She said she initially met Gadd having first visiting the Hawley Arms pub for a meal. Ms Harvey denied Gadd offered her a cup of tea, as shown in the series.\n\n\"I was in for a meal with, a drink of lemonade, and I was very, very hungry. I'm diabetic, so, very hungry. So that's true,\" she said.\n\n\"It's a work of fiction,\" she continued about the show. \"It's a work of hyperbole, as I've always said. There are two true facts in that. His name is Richard Gadd, and he works as a jobbing barman on benefits, in the Hawley Arms. We met, two or three times.\"\n\nFiona said jail sentence part of the show was false and denies being his stalker\n\nMs Harvey said the scene in which Martha is jailed was 'complete nonsense' and that she was 'not a stalker' and had 'not been to jail'.\n\n\"It is completely untrue and very career-damaging,\" she said. \"I want to rebuttal that. I'm not a stalker. It's just complete nonsense.\n\n\"[It is] very, very defamatory to me, very career damaging. And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions, interdicts. This is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nFiona claimed she had not received an apology from Gadd\n\nMs Harvey later claimed she had never received an apology from the writer and comedian for the allegations made since the Netflix show aired.\n\n\"I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology,\" she said. \"And I have this Martha character who seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal and been to prison.\"\n\nShe added that there had been a 'number of other allegations' that were 'not true' in the show. She denied she was someone who needed help, which was widely referred to in the show.\n\nFiona said she didn't have Gadd's number and that she never left him voicemails\n\nMs Harvey said she never left voice messages for Gadd. Morgan asked: \"Why would there even be a possibility of him having that number of voice messages from you?\"\n\nMs Harvey responded. \"I've not phoned the guy. I don't have his number.\n\n\"The only explanation for having a voicemail from me would be taping me in the Hawley Arms. That's the only place we've ever met. I mean, my point is, though, even if that were true, I didn't lunge at him across the bar. I didn't sexually assault him in a canal. I didn't go to jail.\"\n\nFiona admitted having numerous phones and 'between four and six email addresses'\n\nMs Harvey said she might have up to six email addresses and used various mobile phones. She claimed she used the different emails and devices for various means, such as paying utility bills and for close friends.\n\n\"I like to keep people on different phones and different emails,\" she told Morgan. \"Maybe four. I think it's four to six. Yeah, it's just easier, it's easier. So you have some for your utilities, some for close friends.\"\n\nWhen Morgan said he didn't know anyone with six emails, she responded: \"You don't know many people then, and I know... I know people with four or six email addresses.\"\n\n\"I like keeping people on separate phones, maybe that makes me a maniac or a stalker or something,\" Ms Harvey then joked.\n\nFiona claimed they only ever shared 'Scottish banter'\n\nGrilled on whether the writer was ever her friend, she said: \"No. No. Staff asked me that as well. No, I don't think so.\" She said the pair had shared 'Scottish banter' at the pub.\n\nShe said she was never in love with him, saying: \"Is that a serious question? No. I'm not interested.\"\n\nFiona shared final direct message to viewers\n\nMs Harvey shared a final message to viewers at the end of the interview. Looking into the camera to address those watching, she said: \"I think you should look at him saying that I'm some sort of mental case and I think you should judge for yourselves. I can't change your mind on this... I can just rebut what has been said, but you need to make up your mind.\"", "source": {"uri": "manchestereveningnews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manchester Evening News"}, "authors": {"uri": "8119815564", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:27:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:27:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:26:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.thewrap.com/baby-reindeer-real-stalker-martha-piers-morgan/", "title": "Real-Life 'Baby Reindeer' Stalker Calls Series an Obscene Fiction", "body": "Fiona Harvey tells Piers Morgan she refuses to watch the Netflix series she supposedly inspired because she finds it \"obscene\"\n\nThe woman believed to be the real-life Martha from Netflix's hit series \"Baby Reindeer\" appeared on \"Piers Morgan Uncensored\" to refute the series - and her supposed portrayal in it - as \"very, very defamatory to me, very career-damaging.\"\n\nFiona Harvey's pre-taped interview aired Thursday night, in which she spent a bulk of her time denying sending over 41,000 emails and 100 letters to Richard Gadd. He's the man who turned his experience first into a one-man play and later the Netflix series he also stars in.\n\n\"That's simply not true,\" Harvey said. \"If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots.\"\n\nMorgan responded by agreeing it would be \"obsessive\" before pressing her on what she might have sent instead. Again, Harvey denied Gadd received anything from her before admitting a couple \"jokey\" emails were sent.\n\n\"I don't think I sent him anything ... No, I think there may have been a couple of emails exchanging, but that was it,\" she clarified. \"Just jokey banter emails.\"\n\nA large part of the series' success rests on Jessica Gunning's performance as Martha - the character Gadd allegedly based on Harvey. Despite the accolades for both the show and Gunning's character specifically, Harvey refuses to watch \"Baby Reindeer\" as it's \"a fiction ... based on his imagination.\"\n\n\"No, I think I'd be sick,\" she told Morgan. \"It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous.\"\n\nHarvey also made it clear she expects an apology from either Netflix or Gadd himself for the \"completely untrue\" depiction of her.\n\n\"We've had no apologies from Netflix or him, nothing,\" she said. \"I mean, for someone who says he feels sorry for me, I've had no apology. My character seems to have smashed up a bar, sexually assaulted him in a canal, been to prison. There are a number of other allegations, and ... that's not true.\"\n\n\"Baby Reindeer\" enjoyed a meteoric rise following its April 11 debut. Gadd explained during a Q&A held in Los Angeles after the show's success that he went to an \"obsessive\" place while writing the series.\n\n\"I wrote a lot of it literally surrounded by white walls on a garden deck chair and a laptop on my lap,\" he said. \"It's amazing I didn't go insane. It was a crazy, mad thing. I had to go into a very obsessive place. I did mad hours on it. My best writing was like, 5 a.m. onwards. I would get up at half four and obsessively write almost til I went to bed the next day.\"\n\nWatch the entire \"Piers Morgan Uncensored\" interview, below:", "source": {"uri": "thewrap.com", {"uri": "8119666804", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "19:06:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T19:06:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T19:06:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/05/09/entertainment/baby-reindeer-real-life-martha-claims-how-she-really-met-richard-gadd-and-it-wasnt-with-free-tea/", "title": "'Baby Reindeer' real-life Martha claims how she really met Richard...", "body": "The real-life Martha from \"Baby Reindeer\" did her first television interview to speak out against the alleged inaccuracies of the hit Netflix series.\n\nFiona Harvey, 58, appeared on \"Piers Morgan Uncensored\" and broke her silence on being the supposed inspiration for the unhinged lead character (played by Jessica Gunning) in Richard Gadd's show.\n\nHarvey told Piers Morgan that she never stalked Gadd, 34, and slammed the series -- which she still hasn't seen -- for being \"completely untrue.\" She claimed that her first encounter with Gadd didn't happen as it was shown between Martha and Gadd's character, Donny, on the show.\n\nAccording to Harvey, Gadd did not offer her a cup of tea after she walked into the pub where he worked when they met.\n\n\"That's not correct,\" she said. \"I was in for a meal with a drink of lemonade, and I was very, very hungry. I'm diabetic, so, very hungry. So that's true.\"\n\nHarvey claimed that Gadd spoke to her first in the pub.\n\n\"He interrupted a conversation...he said, 'Oh, you're Scottish', and basically commandeered the conversation,\" she alleged. \"You know, I was talking to somebody. It's pretty rich. So he seemed to be obsessed with me from that moment onwards.\"\n\nShe also said about Gadd, \"I got the impression that he was all out for himself. [He] wanted to sort of control that bar. Very, very inarticulate, very full of himself. I should never have gone in that bar.\"\n\nThroughout her interview with Morgan, Harvey cited multiple moments from the show that allegedly didn't accurately explain her real-life experience with Gadd. For example, Harvey said she never caught Gadd peeping through her window, which transpired in one scene.\n\n\"I didn't see him at my house. I think it would be impossible to look through a window... That categorically didn't happen,\" she claimed.\n\nHarvey also did not harass Gadd by sending him over 40,000 emails and reaching out via voicemails, text messages, Facebook messages and letters, she claimed.\n\n\"That's simply not true,\" Harvey said. \"If somebody was sending somebody 41,000 emails or something, they'd be doing how many a day? Lots.\"\n\nWhen Morgan pressed Harvey on the topic of the harassing messages, she responded, \"I don't think I sent him anything. No, I think there may have been a couple of emails exchanging, but that was it. Just jokey banter emails.\"\n\nHarvey claimed she sent Gadd \"less than ten\" emails and \"not 41,000.\" She also denied she reached out to Gadd by text or on Facebook, though she did admit she messaged him on Twitter \"about 18\" times and sent him one letter.\n\nOne scene from \"Baby Reindeer\" showed Martha heckling Donny at his comedy show, but Harvey said that never happened in real life.\n\n\"Why would I do that? No, no, no. I don't generally go to comedy shows,\" she claimed.\n\nFurthermore, Harvey denied attacking Gadd's girlfriend and claimed that he's \"homosexual.\" She also insisted she never sat for hours at a bus stop outside Gadd's apartment alone, contacted his parents, or was sentenced to prison for nine months for harassing Gadd.\n\n\"That's completely untrue. Very, very defamatory to me, very career damaging,\" she said about the series showing Martha go to prison in the finale. \"And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions, interdicts. This is just complete nonsense.\"\n\nWhile \"Baby Reindeer\" is a bonafide hit on Netflix and is garnering major Emmy buzz, Harvey -- who has said she's considering taking legal action against Gadd -- still hasn't watched the show.\n\n\"I think I'd be sick,\" she told Morgan after he asked her if she's \"curious\" about the series, adding, \"It's taken over enough of my life.\"\n\n\"I find it quite obscene,\" Harvey said. \"I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Please try again later{{ /verifyErrors }}\n\nBaby Reindeer viewers are questioning the ethics behind Piers Morgan's interview with the woman whose alleged campaign of stalking and harassment inspired the series.\n\nThis week, the broadcaster revealed he had spoken to Scottish lawyer Fiona Harvey, labelled the \"real Martha\", with the interview set to air on his YouTube show Uncensored on Thursday (8 May).\n\nAfter filming the interview, though, Harvey said she felt \"used\" by Morgan, who she said placed \"a heavy emphasis\" on the thousands of emails she allegedly sent Baby Reindeer creator and lead star Richard Gadd.\n\nHarvey, who has received death threats since the show started, has now hinted that Morgan capitalised on the furore, telling Daily Record: \"I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.\n\n\"It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nHarvey's claims corroborate general feeling about Morgan's interview, which was met with consternation when the broadcaster announced the \"world exclusive\" on Wednesday (8 May).\n\nHe wrote on X/Twitter: \"The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show. Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nThe post's replies section was flooded with messages from users calling the interview \"irresponsible\" and \"unethical\" due to the fact that Gadd himself told The Independent that the real person who inspired Martha to be \"mentally unwell\".\n\n\"This is exploitation of a person who is in a vulnerable position. Clearly unethical,\" one person wrote, with another adding: \"This guy has absolutely no shame!\" Others branded the decision to interview Harvey \"disgraceful\" and \"absolutely vile\".\n\nThe Independent has contacted Morgan's Uncensored for comment.\n\nMorgan's announcement arrived hours before Gadd, Gunning, co-star Nava Mau and series director Weronika Tofilska participated in a panel discussion about the show in Los Angeles.\n\nThe event was held to stir up interest among TV awards voters in Hollywood. {"uri": "2024-05-350485770", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "16:41:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T16:41:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T16:26:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/opinion/were-all-complicit-in-piers-morgans-baby-reindeer-interview-3048810", "title": "We're all complicit in Piers Morgan's Baby Reindeer interview", "body": "We're calling for his head while surreptitiously reminding each other to tune in when the interview drops\n\nFollowing the runaway success of Richard Gadd's semi-autobiographical series Baby Reindeer, about aspiring comedian Donny Dunn's ambivalent experience of being stalked by fragile, ferocious older woman Martha, viewers have gone to great lengths to track down the people behind his characters, raising countless fascinating moral questions along the way.\n\nShould Gadd have gone to greater lengths to anonymise his show? Where does his ownership of his own story end and his responsibility to others begin? And what role do we - as media and audiences alike - have to play in the equation?\n\nJust as it was inevitable that sleuths would find the (allegedly) \"real Martha\" - Fiona Harvey, 58, was located by viewers in five seconds flat, despite Gadd's pleas to call off the search - so the ensuing media circus shouldn't surprise us. On the contrary: the fact that controversy merchant Piers Morgan is gearing up to air a tell-all interview with Harvey on his YouTube channel (hip!) this evening is the most predictable thing about this whole fascinating tangle of thorns.\n\nIn the internet age, giving an audience a mystery is practically a guarantee of them trying to solve it; having framed the show as being based on a true story, it was only a matter of time before Martha's \"true\" identity came to light.\n\nBaby Reindeer might have been fiction, but it tapped into our limitless capacity for \"true crime\", steeping ourselves in the waters of human depravity with seemingly no thought for the consequences; that impulse might be ugly, but that doesn't make it any less true.\n\nNo question, then, that there is appetite for Morgan's interview - \"Is she a psycho stalker?\" barks his post on X, viewed 8.2 million times at the time of writing - the quandary is whether it should be catered to. After all, I want to eat seven kilos of chocolate, drink four bottles of wine, and smoke 500 cigarettes. Does that mean I should press on, or is it worth pausing to consider my impulses?\n\nI loved Baby Reindeer as much as anyone, and I'd be lying if I said I had no interest in seeing the \"real Martha\" - on the contrary, one small, dark bit of my psyche can think of nothing more fascinating. That doesn't mean I should indulge it - nonetheless, I believe that being honest about our nastier impulses makes it easier to see what is happening here.\n\nTuning in to watch a jumped-up school bully \"catch out\" a mentally ill woman for baying crowds is not a good look for any of us, yet millions will do just that on Thursday night - the highest of moral high horses can't carry you away from that reality.\n\nViewers want horror - and in search of ratings and clicks, cynical media can pander to our worst appetites. It's what made The Jeremy Kyle Show one of the most successful UK daytime TV shows of all time; it's also arguably what fuelled audiences for public executions, or the witch trials in medieval Europe.\n\nWe're not always nice, and it's important that we face up to that - otherwise, people like Morgan will exploit it just as they do people like Harvey. Certainly, she seems especially vulnerable; Gadd himself noted that the \"real Martha\" was \"unwell\" and \"needed help\", while Harvey says she has received death threats from Baby Reindeer fans. There's no one in the world who thinks that the decision to interview this woman is kind or responsible. What's more, if Morgan's \"psycho stalker\" tweet is anything to go by, the resulting video will no doubt be salacious and shallow - ethically and artistically bankrupt, a home run!\n\nBut however troubled we are by either Baby Reindeer or Piers Morgan Uncensored, arbitrary ethical guidelines aren't the answer; short of illegality, we have to let people make bad things (\u00e0 la Morgan) if we want them to make good things like Gadd. Rather than asking creatives to police themselves, we have to prove that we can be trusted with complex material - otherwise they'll stop taking risks altogether. And while I would love Morgan to stop taking risks if this is his idea of one, I'm afraid we can't have one without the other.\n\nOf all its triumphs, Baby Reindeer's most astonishing achievement is its unflinching moral ambiguity. Gadd's character Donny is frightened by Martha but also titillated, flattered and affirmed by her attention. Similarly, she is tender as well as terrifying, veering between gentle and brittle, fixated and funny. Gadd's honesty about his own twisted feelings is what made Baby Reindeer so compelling and refreshing - approaching the same subject matter, I'm afraid I don't hold out hope for equivalent nuance from Morgan, but perhaps audiences can take a leaf out of Gadd's book.\n\nIt's tempting to lash out at writers like Gadd, and even more so at provocateurs like Morgan, when TV gets morally muddy, but ultimately, it's down to viewers to break the cycle. If we can resist watching nonsense like Morgan's, he'll stop making it - as it stands, we're calling for his head while surreptitiously reminding each other to tune in when the interview is shown.\n\nPerhaps it's time to turn the focus on ourselves; there's a lot to learn from Baby Reindeer, not least the power of self awareness even (or especially) when it is most uncomfortable.", The series, penned by Richard himself, explores Donny's complex relationship with a woman named Martha, portrayed by Jessica Gunning.\n\nInitially friendly, Martha's behaviour becomes increasingly obsessive, culminating in her sending Donny over 41,000 emails, 744 tweets, 100 pages of letters and leaving 350 hours of voicemails over several years.\n\nThe show is set to become one of Netflix's most-watched series. In an attempt \"to set the record straight\", the woman claiming to be the real-life Martha Scott spoke to former Good Morning Britain news anchor Piers Morgan.\n\nThe woman, whose identity has been kept anonymous by OK!, revealed she had a message she has for Baby Reindeer creator Richard during her interview with Piers.\n\nSpeaking directly to the camera, she said: \"Leave me alone, please. Get a life, get a proper job. I am horrified at what you've done.\"\n\nThe woman also shared that she hasn't tuned into the Netflix series. When asked if she had watched it, she responded: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it.\"\n\nPiers inquired: \"You're not curious, too? \" To which she retorted: \"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nThe interview with Piers was set to air at 8pm on Thursday, but it seems the woman was already expressing regret before the broadcast. She accused the divisive TV personality of having \"triggered\" her emotions during their conversation for his YouTube channel, subsequently calling him a \"bully\" and a \"twerp\".\n\nThe law graduate, who is allegedly the woman at the centre of Richard's drama series, agreed to speak with the star to share her perspective. In the series he stars as the fictionalised version of himself, Donny, while Martha is played by actress Jessica Gunning.\n\nBenjamin King has stated that Netflix aimed to balance protecting the identities of the real people with upholding the \"veracity and authenticity\" of Baby Reindeer. \"We didn't want to anonymize that or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story because that would undermine the intent behind the show,\" he said. \"Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media. I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.\" He also said Netflix had worked with the Suzy Lamplugh Trust, the British charity that provides support for stalking victims.\n\nRichard and his co-star Jessica have both asked fans not to speculate on the real identity of Martha, or of any other characters in the series that follows Donny's experiences with Martha, who he first meets when she comes into the pub where he is working.\n\nOn Instagram, Richard wrote: \"Please don't speculate on who the real life people could be. That's not the point of our show. Lots of love,\" while Jessica said in an interview with Glamour Magazine: \"I would urge people not to be doing that. I think if that is happening, I think it's a real, real shame, because it shows that they haven't watched the show properly. That's not the point of it in any way. Netflix and Richard [Gadd] went to extreme lengths to try and make sure that the identities were kept private for a reason.\"", "source": {"uri": "ok.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "ok"}, You can check out at any time. More info\n\nThe woman claiming to be the real-life Martha Scott from Netflix's hit series Baby Reindeer has issued a plea to Richard Gadd. The show, which has become a viral sensation, stars Gadd as struggling comedian Donny Dunn.\n\nHe penned the series that explores Donny's complex relationship with a woman named Martha, portrayed by Jessica Gunning. Initially friendly, Martha's behaviour becomes increasingly obsessive as she starts to stalk Donny, reports the Mirror.\n\nOver several years, Martha bombards Donny with more than 41,000 emails, 744 tweets, 100 pages of letters and 350 hours of voicemails. The show is set to become one of the most viewed on the streaming platform. In an attempt \"to set the record straight\", the woman alleging to be the real-life Martha Scott spoke to former Good Morning Britain news anchor Piers Morgan.\n\nREAD MORE A Yorkshire Farm star Amanda Owen 'at one' as she braves wild swim\n\nThe woman revealed her message for Baby Reindeer creator Richard Gadd during her interview with Piers Morgan. He asked what she would say to him if he was watching. She retaliated, saying: \"Leave me alone, please. Get a life, get a proper job. I am horrified at what you've done.\"\n\nThe lady also opened up about not having watched the Netflix series. When asked if she had seen it, her response was simply: \"Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it.\"\n\nWith a tone of curiosity, Piers Morgan asked, \"You're not curious, too? \" She retorted assertively, \"No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic. Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.\"\n\nPier Morgan's sit down interview was broadcasted at 8pm on Thursday night. Prior to the show, it seemed the lady was already expressing regret. She accused the contentious journalist of triggering her emotions during their YouTube discussion, subsequently branding him as a \"bully\" and a \"twerp\".\n\nThe law graduate, who is alleged to be the woman portrayed in Richard Gadd's drama series, agreed to speak with the star to share her perspective. However, she refutes the idea that she's profiting from the show's success.\n\nThe woman stated she only made a modest sum for her London visit. On Facebook, she expressed her views about Piers Morgan: \"Piers is a twerp. But we [already] know this. You will see in my interview I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views. By far most of his other interviews with all misogynist men he often defends Andrew Tate Donald Trump.\"", "source": {"uri": "examinerlive.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "huddersfieldexaminer"}, {"uri": "8119431435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:55:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:55:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:55:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://thetab.com/uk/2024/05/09/marthas-arrest-and-all-the-other-differences-in-baby-reindeer-from-the-original-play-364871", "title": "Martha's arrest and all the other differences in Baby Reindeer from the original play", "body": "Netflix also cut out all of the bizarre gifts Martha gave Donny\n\nWhilst everyone and their nan has now seen and subsequently obsessed over Baby Reindeer on Netflix, the hype still refuses to die down - and I'm not sure I even want it to. From X to the real Martha speaking out and now due to appear on TV with Piers Morgan, there are still so many questions I have about the situation.\n\nDespite being totally engrossed in the show on Netflix, the whole show was actually based on an award winning play that Richard Gadd performed actually created and performed across the country before the story made it on the big screen. Here's a look at all the ways the Baby Reindeer play was different from the Netflix show.\n\nUsing a number of characters in the Netflix series to tell his relationships with Teri, Darrien and Keeley, Richard instead opted to perform the original play as a one man show. Performing it at Edinburgh Fringe Festival five whole years before the release of the Netflix show, Richard delivered the show's dialogue and performance alone on stage.\n\nDuring the period of time she stalked him, the real Martha actually gifted Richard an array of strange gifts. This was reflected in the play, with the performance revealing some of the items he received to be underwear, sleeping pills, a toy reindeer and a wooly hat. In the Netflix series, the only thing Donny receives from Martha is a photograph of herself in her underwear.\n\nDespite this seeming like a small detail to omit, this context was telling of the dynamic between Donny and Martha, adding layers to their relationship as he received gifts from a customer.\n\nWe hear on the Netflix show that Richard was inundated with messages, voicemails and social media messages from the real Martha, but the amount was actually significantly downplayed in comparison to the real life events. Donny explains that he received around 80 emails a day, but Richard actually got a total of 41,071 emails, 350 hours worth of voicemails, 744 tweets, 46 Facebook messages and 106 pages worth of letters throughout the four years he was stalked. The play was much more realistic when explaining the scale of messages sent by the real Martha but of course without visual representations.\n\nDespite the Netflix show portraying Martha in court and being sentenced to nine months in prison, Richard Gadd's play did not see his stalker receive prison time. Explaining in multiple interviews that he also saw the real Martha as a victim of trauma, Richard didn't write the prison sentence into his original play script as he was aware he had done several things which made him an unfavourable character himself at times and that this would have been an unfair end to the story.\n\nBaby Reindeer is available on Netflix now. For more like this and all the latest Netflix news, drops, quizzes and memes like The Holy Church of Netflix on Facebook.\n\n* Inside Baby Reindeer star Richard Gadd's life: The real man who the show is also based on\n\n* Who was Llewellyn Harrison? The man episode six of Baby Reindeer is dedicated to\n\n* This is the terrifying true story behind Netflix's creepy new show Baby Reindeer", "source": {"uri": "thetab.com", "dataType": "news",
