"news/Arts_and_Entertainment", "label": "news/Arts and Entertainment", "wgt": 82}], "image": "https://media.thetab.com/blogs.dir/90/files/2024/05/local-3-1.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": {"uri": "8119594140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:03:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:03:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:02:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/baby-reindeer-whats-true-whats-32772329", "title": "Baby Reindeer - what's true and what's not as 'Martha' chats to Piers Morgan", "body": "As Baby Reindeer's 'real Martha' appears in a divisive televised interview with Piers Morgan, the Mirror separates the truth from fiction when it comes to the hit Netflix show\n\nBased on a real story, Baby Reindeer has fascinated viewers making it one of the most talked about Netflix shows - but what's true and what isn't?\n\nThe character of Martha - shown to be a serial stalker who harasses the central character with endless messages sent from her 'iPhone' - is indeed based on a real person. A number of viewers quickly became curious about who the 'real Martha' actually is - despite writer and star of the show Richard Gadd urging them to leave such investigations well alone.\n\nNow, a woman who allegedly inspired Martha in the seven-part series has given a televised interview with Piers Morgan, who has drawn ire for potentially exploiting a vulnerable individual. The controversial interview will air on the former Good Morning Britain anchor's YouTube channel at 8 pm this evening (May 9).\n\nTaking to social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, Piers announced: \"*WORLD EXCLUSIVE* The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.\n\n\"[Redacted] wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on @PiersUncensored.\" As a heated debate over interview ethics continues to swell, the Mirror takes a look at the truth, and the fiction, in Baby Reindeer...\n\nMartha The real Martha sent Richard more than 41,000 emails\n\nScottish writer and comedian Richard Gadd penned the script, which is based on his one-man show of the same name, and even stars as a fictionalised version of himself - Donny Dunn. A barman by day, and comedian by night, Donny keeps his severe emotional wounds deeply buried but is ultimately forced to confront his demons when seasoned stalker Martha Scott takes a seat at his bar.\n\nAs Martha, Jessica Gunning gave the performance of a lifetime, managing to imbue the complex character with both menace and compassion. Like Donny, we first meet Martha in a forlorn state, crying at the bar in The Heart Pub where the dejected comedian works.\n\nFeeling sorry for Martha, who doesn't even have enough money on her for a drink, Donny offers her a cup of tea on the house - inadvertently sparking a bond that would quickly snowball into a full-blown obsession. At first, Donny views Martha as a harmless fantasist who notices him in the way his tepid audiences never do.\n\nIt soon dawns on him, however, that something far more serious is going on below the surface, with Martha's stalking behaviours infiltrating every part of his life. Martha is indeed based on a real individual who subjected Richard to a campaign of stalking - but a few details were changed during the screenwriting process.\n\nIn an interview with Variety, Richard explained that they had to make the character of Martha different from the real Martha for 'legal reasons', but what he was looking for was an actress who could capture that 'kind of energy'. According to Richard: \"I needed to see someone who was vulnerable one moment, angry the next, volatile but so desperate and sympathetic. I needed to see someone who could capture a full gamut of emotions. When somebody has severe mental health problems, they tend to leap from one emotion to the next, sometimes even quite quickly. And that's very hard to do from an acting point of view, but Jess seems to have it in her pores, it seems to just fall out of her.\"\n\nExpressing that he felt empathy for Martha, Richard continued: \"I have a bit of empathy overdrive sometimes. But it's not like anything I've seen on television before. Stalking usually is depicted as someone who is kind of evil, whereas I felt like there was a vulnerable person who genuinely couldn't stop, who for whatever reason had believed the reality that was inside her head and no matter what couldn't change from that. I mean, it is a mental illness and I wanted to portray that. I did see someone who I felt sorry for.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with The Independent, Richard shed some light on the ceaseless messages from Martha that pepper every episode. In real life, 'Martha' was similarly prolific, firing off more than 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voicemail, 744 tweets, and 46 Facebook messages, as well as 106 pages of letters. In the show, Martha is sent to jail. However, it is not believed that Richard's real-life stalker was ever convicted.\n\nAhead of tonight's pre-recorded conversation with Piers, the woman who allegedly provided the inspiration for Martha lashed out at the outspoken broadcaster, describing him as 'a twerp' and 'a bully'. In a heated Facebook post, the woman in question, who the Mirror has decided not to name or identity via pictures, wrote: \"Piers is a twerp. But we [already] know this. You will see in my interview.\"\n\nShe added: \"I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views. By far most of his other interviews with all misogynist men he often defends Andrew Tate, Donald Trump.\"\n\nAssault by TV writer Cruel Darrien positioned himself as Donny's mentor, before repeatedly assaulting him\n\nBaby Reindeer took another dark turn in episode four, which explored Donny's rape at the hands of Darrien O'Connor (Tom Goodman-Hill), a successful TV writer who initially positions himself as Donny's mentor. Donny first encounters Darrien as a young comedian cutting his teeth at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and is quickly mesmerised by him.\n\nA connection that Donny initially perceives as a friendship emerges, with Darrien showering the fledgling comic with the praise he so desperately craves. For all Darrien's talk of Donny's bright future, however, the pair spend their weekends in Darrien's dingy flat, where the older man plies his 'protege' with drugs and repeatedly assaults him.\n\nIt makes for a devastating watch, with Donny's ordeal having a catastrophic effect on his sense of self-worth. As with the character of Martha, Richard has changed the name of his abuser, but Darrien is based on a real person.\n\nIn behind-the-scenes Netflix footage, Richard clarified: \"It's a true story, based on my early 20s when I went through some pretty crazy things... There's a flashback episode where we actually go back in time to Donny going to the Edinburgh Fringe and meeting someone in the industry who helps them in their career but goes on to abuse Donny and that's obviously taken from my real-life experiences.\"\n\nHe continued: \"It was a hell of a thing to write and shoot. It shows a side of abuse that I don't think we've seen before. I still think there's an idea that sexual abuse is a pill in a drink and dissolves and someone wakes up and doesn't know where they are and that does happen, and it's a big problem, but a lot of abuse occurs in very intimate relationships. I wanted to show how complicated and psychologically messed up situations could get to.\"\n\nRelationship with Teri Donny's inner demons ultimately capsized his budding romance with Teri\n\nIn Baby Reindeer, we see Donny fall for Teri (Nava Mau), a beautiful American trans-woman who initially believes her background as a therapist could help her reach through to Martha. Although Donny clearly has strong feelings for Teri, he manages to jeopardise their blossoming romance at every turn as, in his words: \"I loved one thing in the world more than her - hating myself.\"\n\nWracked with self-loathing, Donny lies about his own name, ditches Teri on the tube and, ultimately, his internalised shame and trauma bonding with Martha leads to the demise of their relationship. Viewers have naturally been curious to know whether there really was a Teri in Richard's life.\n\nIn the behind-the-scenes Netflix video, Richard revealed that Teri was indeed based on a real woman, who he says was a 'voice of reason'. He shared: \"The real-life person always used to call me out on my s*** and I always used to find it confronting. My behaviour was irrational and so it was very important to have Teri be the voice of reason in the show. I mean, she was the voice of reason in my life at that point as well, not that I listened to her as much as I should have.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with The Independent, Richard also explained that Donny's doomed relationship with Teri was inspired by his own experience dating a trans woman, which has left him with some real regrets. Richard said: \"It's in the public consciousness now, but it wasn't back then, when I was dating. It felt so new that it added a certain pressure, to me, that I really regret now. But that's what it explores in the show. This story was set back in a time when things were very different.\"\n\nOnstage breakdown In episode six, Donny finally let himself be vulnerable in a heart-wrenching monologue\n\nIn episode six, Baby Reindeer reaches an emotional climax when, faced with a disdainful audience, Donny drops the props and the jokes and delivers the most powerful monologue of the series. After bottling up his trauma for so long, Donny opens up to the silent audience about what he's endured - in what turns out to be a turning point in the series.\n\nFootage of his speech goes viral, and Donny soon attracts praise for being so open, with his unexpected admission even bolstering his flagging comedy career. This also proves to be the catalyst that sees Donny finally tell his parents about the abuse he's suffered, receiving their support and honesty in return. Donny's onstage breakdown was one of the most memorable moments, but is there any truth in it?\n\nThis scene actually didn't happen in real life, however, Richard has spoken out about his experiences of sex abuse and stalking in his scripted theatre show Monkey See Monkey Do, in which a large monkey was used as a metaphor for the heavy burden of abuse.\n\nAlthough this show wasn't impromptu, as Donny's was, the response to Richard's story, at a time before male sexual assault was widely spoken about, proved to be equally life-changing. Remembering rehearsing before his first performance, Richard told The Guardian: \"I remember cracking up, because it was all going so badly, and the producer said, 'What do you want from this, man?' And I turned to him with tears in my eyes, and said, 'I just want to make it out alive'. Little did I know that it would provide a lifeline for me. The way people received that show, and received me, and accepted what happened to me: it saved my life. It's mad that it happened that way.\"\n\nDonny's moving monologue is given further authenticity as it contains excerpts from Richard's Baby Reindeer autobiographical one-man show, which inspired the hit series.\n\nIf you're struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open 24/7 on 116 123. Alternatively, you can email jo@samaritans.org or visit their site to find your local branch\n\nIf you've been the victim of sexual assault, you can access help and resources via www.rapecrisis.org.uk or calling the national telephone helpline on 0808 802 9999\n\nYou can stream all episodes of Baby Reindeer on Netflix now. {"uri": "8119030949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:23:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:23:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:22:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/baby-reindeers-real-life-martha-32770189", "title": "Baby Reindeer's real-life Martha brands Piers Morgan 'bully' and 'twerp'", "body": "Fiona Harvey, 58, has slammed the controversial broadcaster hours before their interview is due to air online.\n\nBaby Reindeer's real-life Martha has branded Piers Morgan as a \"twerp\" and a \"bully\" ahead of their TV interview being aired tonight.\n\nFiona Harvey, 58, claims the controversial broadcaster \"triggered\" her emotions during their recent sit-down for his YouTube channel. It comes shortly after Morgan announced the 'world exclusive' earlier this week.\n\nTaking to X, formerly known as Twitter, Morgan shared an image of himself and the woman on the set of his Piers Morgan Uncensored YouTube show.\n\nHe boasted: \"*WORLD EXCLUSIVE* The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show. [Redacted] wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on @PiersUncensored.\"\n\nBut just hours before its 8pm broadcast this evening, Harvey told her connections on Facebook: \"Piers is a twerp. But we [already] know this.\n\n\"You will see in my interview I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views. By far most of his other interviews with all misogynist men he often defends Andrew Tate Donald Trump.\"\n\nThe Record exclusively told yesterday how Harvey, originally from Fyvie in Aberdeenshire, was unhappy with the questions that Piers put to her. She described her interview as a \"sparring match\" and was forced to refute claims by Piers that she \"loved\" Fife-born Richard Gadd, whom she is accused of stalking in the Netflix series.\n\nShe said: \"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent. I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself but I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.\n\n\"Piers kept saying to me 'are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?'. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this.\n\n\"I said, 'Look, Even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff. As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100% true.\n\n\"It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nShe added: \"Piers said it went well. He referred to it as a sparring match. He landed a few punches on me and I landed a few punches on him. He asked me if I loved Richard Gadd and I said you've got to be joking.\"\n\nHarvey said she was paid only \u00a3250 for the 30-minute interview. During the show, the Scots law graduate will talk openly about being outed as comedian Richard Gadd's alleged stalker.\n\nIt is expected to air on the broadcaster's YouTube channel - which has 2.58 million subscribers - at 8pm on Thursday.\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond - Sign up to our daily newsletter here.", "source": {"uri": "dailyrecord.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "8119618928", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "18:23:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T18:23:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T18:22:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/showbiz/celebrity-news/baby-reindeer-martha-piers-morgan-32773709", "title": "Baby Reindeer - The truth and the fiction as 'Martha' chats to Piers Morgan", "body": "Based on a real story, Baby Reindeer has fascinated viewers, making it one of the most talked-about Netflix shows - but what's true and what isn't?\n\nThe character of Martha - shown to be a serial stalker who harasses the central character with endless messages sent from her ' iPhone ' - is indeed based on a real person. A number of viewers quickly became curious about who the 'real Martha' actually is - despite writer and star of the show Richard Gadd urging them to leave such investigations well alone.\n\nNow, a woman who allegedly inspired Martha in the seven-part series has given a televised interview with Piers Morgan, who has drawn ire for potentially exploiting a vulnerable individual. The controversial interview will air on the former Good Morning Britain anchor's YouTube channel at 8pm this evening (May 9).\n\nREAD MORE: 'This is not OK' - US publication sparks outrage over 'embarrassing' Barry Keoghan Met Gala post\n\nTaking to social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter, Piers announced: \"*WORLD EXCLUSIVE* The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.\n\n\"[Redacted] wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker? Find out tomorrow on @PiersUncensored.\" As a heated debate over interview ethics continues to swell, the Mirror takes a look at the truth, and the fiction, in Baby Reindeer...\n\nMartha\n\nScottish writer and comedian Richard Gadd penned the script, which is based on his one-man show of the same name, and even stars as a fictionalised version of himself - Donny Dunn. A barman by day, and comedian by night, Donny keeps his severe emotional wounds deeply buried but is ultimately forced to confront his demons when seasoned stalker Martha Scott takes a seat at his bar.\n\nAs Martha, Jessica Gunning gave the performance of a lifetime, managing to imbue the complex character with both menace and compassion. Like Donny, we first meet Martha in a forlorn state, crying at the bar in The Heart Pub, where the dejected comedian works.\n\nFeeling sorry for Martha, who doesn't even have enough money on her for a drink, Donny offers her a cup of tea on the house - inadvertently sparking a bond that would quickly snowball into a full-blown obsession. At first, Donny views Martha as a harmless fantasist who notices him in the way his tepid audiences never do.\n\nIt soon dawns on him, however, that something far more serious is going on below the surface, with Martha's stalking behaviours infiltrating every part of his life. Martha is indeed based on a real individual who subjected Richard to a campaign of stalking - but a few details were changed during the screenwriting process.\n\nIn an interview with Variety, Richard explained that they had to make the character of Martha different from the real Martha for 'legal reasons', but what he was looking for was an actress who could capture that 'kind of energy'. According to Richard: \"I needed to see someone who was vulnerable one moment, angry the next, volatile but so desperate and sympathetic.\n\n\"I needed to see someone who could capture a full gamut of emotions. When somebody has severe mental health problems, they tend to leap from one emotion to the next, sometimes even quite quickly. And that's very hard to do from an acting point of view, but Jess seems to have it in her pores, it seems to just fall out of her.\"\n\nExpressing that he felt empathy for Martha, Richard continued: \"I have a bit of empathy overdrive sometimes. But it's not like anything I've seen on television before. Stalking usually is depicted as someone who is kind of evil, whereas I felt like there was a vulnerable person who genuinely couldn't stop, who for whatever reason had believed the reality that was inside her head and, no matter what, couldn't change from that. I mean, it is a mental illness and I wanted to portray that. I did see someone who I felt sorry for.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with The Independent, Richard shed some light on the ceaseless messages from Martha that pepper every episode. In real life, 'Martha' was similarly prolific, firing off more than 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voicemail, 744 tweets, and 46 Facebook messages, as well as 106 pages of letters. In the show, Martha is sent to jail. However, it is not believed that Richard's real-life stalker was ever convicted.\n\nAhead of tonight's pre-recorded conversation with Piers, the woman who allegedly provided the inspiration for Martha lashed out at the outspoken broadcaster, describing him as 'a twerp' and 'a bully'. In a heated Facebook post, the woman in question, who the Mirror has decided not to name or identify via pictures, wrote: \"Piers is a twerp. But we [already] know this. You will see in my interview.\"\n\nShe added: \"I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views, by far, than most of his other interviews with all the misogynist men he often defends.... Andrew Tate, Donald Trump.\"\n\nAssault by TV writer\n\nBaby Reindeer took another dark turn in episode four, which explored Donny's rape at the hands of Darrien O'Connor (Tom Goodman-Hill), a successful TV writer who initially positions himself as Donny's mentor. Donny first encounters Darrien as a young comedian cutting his teeth at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival and is quickly mesmerised by him.\n\nA connection that Donny initially perceives as a friendship emerges, with Darrien showering the fledgling comic with the praise he so desperately craves. For all Darrien's talk of Donny's bright future, however, the pair spend their weekends in Darrien's dingy flat, where the older man plies his 'protege' with drugs and repeatedly assaults him.\n\nIt makes for a devastating watch, with Donny's ordeal having a catastrophic effect on his sense of self-worth. As with the character of Martha, Richard has changed the name of his abuser, but Darrien is based on a real person.\n\nIn behind-the-scenes Netflix footage, Richard clarified: \"It's a true story, based on my early 20s when I went through some pretty crazy things... There's a flashback episode where we actually go back in time to Donny going to the Edinburgh Fringe and meeting someone in the industry who helps them in their career but goes on to abuse Donny and that's obviously taken from my real-life experiences.\"\n\nHe continued: \"It was a hell of a thing to write and shoot. It shows a side of abuse that I don't think we've seen before. I still think there's an idea that sexual abuse is a pill in a drink and dissolves and someone wakes up and doesn't know where they are and that does happen, and it's a big problem, but a lot of abuse occurs in very intimate relationships. I wanted to show how complicated and psychologically messed up situations could get to.\"\n\nRelationship with Teri\n\nIn Baby Reindeer, we see Donny fall for Teri (Nava Mau), a beautiful American trans-woman who initially believes her background as a therapist could help her reach through to Martha. Although Donny clearly has strong feelings for Teri, he manages to jeopardise their blossoming romance at every turn as, in his words: \"I loved one thing in the world more than her - hating myself.\"\n\nWracked with self-loathing, Donny lies about his own name, ditches Teri on the tube and, ultimately, his internalised shame and trauma bonding with Martha leads to the demise of their relationship. Viewers have naturally been curious to know whether there really was a Teri in Richard's life.\n\nIn the behind-the-scenes Netflix video, Richard revealed that Teri was indeed based on a real woman, who he says was a 'voice of reason'. He shared: \"The real-life person always used to call me out on my s*** and I always used to find it confronting. My behaviour was irrational and so it was very important to have Teri be the voice of reason in the show. I mean, she was the voice of reason in my life at that point as well, not that I listened to her as much as I should have.\"\n\nIn a separate interview with The Independent, Richard also explained that Donny's doomed relationship with Teri was inspired by his own experience dating a trans woman, which has left him with some real regrets. Richard said: \"It's in the public consciousness now, but it wasn't back then, when I was dating. It felt so new that it added a certain pressure, to me, that I really regret now. But that's what it explores in the show. This story was set back in a time when things were very different.\"\n\nOnstage breakdown\n\nIn episode six, Baby Reindeer reaches an emotional climax when, faced with a disdainful audience, Donny drops the props and the jokes and delivers the most powerful monologue of the series. After bottling up his trauma for so long, Donny opens up to the silent audience about what he's endured - in what turns out to be a turning point in the series.\n\nFootage of his speech goes viral, and Donny soon attracts praise for being so open, with his unexpected admission even bolstering his flagging comedy career. This also proves to be the catalyst that sees Donny finally tell his parents about the abuse he's suffered, receiving their support and honesty in return. Donny's onstage breakdown was one of the most memorable moments, but is there any truth in it?\n\nThis scene actually didn't happen in real life, however, Richard has spoken out about his experiences of sex abuse and stalking in his scripted theatre show Monkey See Monkey Do, in which a large monkey was used as a metaphor for the heavy burden of abuse.\n\nAlthough this show wasn't impromptu, as Donny's was, the response to Richard's story, at a time before male sexual assault was widely spoken about, proved to be equally life-changing. Remembering rehearsing before his first performance, Richard told The Guardian: \"I remember cracking up, because it was all going so badly, and the producer said, 'What do you want from this, man?' And I turned to him with tears in my eyes, and said, 'I just want to make it out alive'. Little did I know that it would provide a lifeline for me. The way people received that show, and received me, and accepted what happened to me: it saved my life. It's mad that it happened that way.\"\n\nDonny's moving monologue is given further authenticity as it contains excerpts from Richard's Baby Reindeer autobiographical one-man show, which inspired the hit series.\n\nIf you're struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open 24/7 on 116 123. Alternatively, you can email jo@samaritans.org or visit their site to find your local branch\n\nIf you've been the victim of sexual assault, you can access help and resources via Dublin Rape Crisis Centre or calling the national telephone helpline on 1800 77 8888.\n\nYou can stream all episodes of Baby Reindeer on Netflix now. {"uri": "8119827596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:39:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:39:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:39:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/baby-reindeers-real-life-martha-has-a-heated-sit-down-with-piers-morgan", "title": "'Baby Reindeer's' Real-Life Martha Has a Heated Sit-Down With Piers Morgan", "body": "Fiona Harvey has emphatically denied that she did most of the things the fictional version of herself did in Netflix's hit series Baby Reindeer -- but she wasn't terribly convincing.\n\nWeeks after fans of the show identified her as the real-life inspiration behind Martha, the show's stalker character, through some old tweets, Harvey had her first sit-down interview with British broadcaster Piers Morgan. In the interview, which aired Thursday afternoon, Harvey officially came forward as the real-life Martha and called Richard Gadd, the writer and star of the series who plays a fictionalized version of himself, a \"liar\" and \"misogynist\" who's profiting off her misery by embellishing their interactions with one another. Both Gadd and Netflix have said the series is \"a true story.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer follows Gadd's complicated relationship with his stalker, as he's plagued by Martha's constant presence and correspondence, which he says consisted of 41,000 emails, 350 voicemails, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters. But Harvey said this week that none of that ever happened -- and she plans to sue Gadd, Netflix, and anyone else who's \"going along and being in that play and doing this to somebody.\"\n\nAccording to Harvey, she and Gadd only met \"two or three times\" in real life. \"I don't lie,\" she told Morgan in their interview. But she was somehow both emphatic in her denial and uncertain at the same time. Harvey told Morgan that her only message to Gadd would be, \"Leave me alone please. Get a life, get a proper job,.\" She added, \"I am horrified at what you've done,\" and called him \"the ultimate misogynist\" and \"psychopath.\"\n\nHowever, Harvey got a bit wobbly when asked to defend herself. Questioned about whether or not she'd sent Gadd 41,000 emails, Harvey doubled down that the show is \"a figure of [Gadd's] imagination,\" but later admitted, \"There may have been a couple of emails,\" but just \"jokey banter ones.\" She said that at the time, \"I didn't think [Gadd] was a complete psychopath that would attack me.\"\n\n\"Even if it were true\" that she'd sent Gadd 41,000 emails (\"just playing devil's advocate here,\" she said), \"I didn't lunge at him across the bar, I didn't go to jail,\" as depicted in the series. Morgan pointed out that law enforcement could likely pinpoint which device the emails came from and whether it belonged to her -- and now that the world has heard her voice, it could easily be determined whether or not she'd left him the 350 voicemails. His line of questioning ultimately drove Harvey to clash with her interviewer. \"You've gone on at length for a good 10 minutes about the emails,\" she said to Morgan, sounding heated.\n\n\"I wouldn't be suing if I thought 41,000 emails were out there,\" she added, with the caveat that \"it wouldn't blow the case\" if that many emails were found. She also let slip that she has \"four phones\" and \"six email addresses\" -- but only because she likes separate communications on different devices, she said.\n\nAs far as the alleged 350 voicemails, Harvey initially said she \"doubt[s]\" Gadd really has that many voicemails and said, \"I've not phoned the guy\" -- but she later admitted to calling him before and even writing him a letter. If Gadd is able to provide 350 voicemails as evidence, Harvey said it'd only be because he'd taped her in the interest of drumming up media attention for his series. \"He's maybe forged things. People have forged a lot of things these days,\" she said of the other 105 handwritten letters she said she didn't write.\n\nKeeping up with the flip-flopping theme of the conversation, Harvey first told Morgan that she'd be willing to take a lie detector test to prove that she hadn't stalked Gadd, since \"I don't fancy little boys without jobs.\" But on second thought, \"A lie detector test for what?\" she asked, pushing the conversation to a different topic: \"They used [lie detectors] for mass murder and things. They don't use them that much.\"\n\nIn all, Harvey said the way she's been depicted in the series is \"completely untrue\" and has been \"very career-damaging\" to her job as an attorney, ever since social media users discovered her identity. \"Internet sleuths tracked me down, hounded me, gave me death threats,\" she said.\n\n\"[Gadd and Netflix] are milking it for all it's worth, for the money,\" she continued, adding that the actress playing Martha, Jessica Gunning, doesn't even look like her -- a point on which many viewers have disagreed.", "source": {"uri": "thedailybeast.com", {"uri": "8119205253", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "13:17:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T13:17:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T13:17:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.express.co.uk/celebrity-news/1897393/piers-morgan-baby-reindeer-real-life-martha-interview-backlash", "title": "Piers Morgan's one-word response as 'real life' Martha interview sparks backlash", "body": "Piers Morgan has sparked a mixed reaction after announcing he had interviewed Baby Reindeer's 'real life' Martha in her first television interview. The woman who allegedly inspired stalker 'Martha' in Richard Gadd's Netflix series agreed to chat to Piers, 59, to \"set the record straight\" following the show creator's version of events.\n\nAnnouncing the news on his official platform X page on Wednesday, Piers shared a picture of him and his guest in the TalkTV studio alongside the caption: \"The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.\" He added of his guest, who we have chosen not to name: \"[She] wants to have her say & 'set the record straight.' Is she a psycho stalker?\"\n\nAfter making the announcement, many social media users expressed their thoughts about whether or not it was the right decision. One wrote: \"This is unacceptable and exploitative. Re-traumatising Richard Gadd by giving his abuser and stalker a voice is a new low, even for you Piers. She needs medical help not a platform! {"uri": "8119343281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:51:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:51:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:51:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/baby-reindeer-martha-fiona-harvey-netflix-b2542241.html", "title": "Piers Morgan isn't the problem with the Baby Reindeer interview - we are", "body": "I would like to be emailed about offers, events and updates from The Independent. Read our privacy policy\n\nOne of the most toxic aspects of British media culture is our tendency to seek out people - usually women, usually vulnerable in some way - who we use as a consequence-free punching bag. We did it to Jade Goody, we did it to Susan Boyle, and with the runaway success of the hit Netflix drama Baby Reindeer it seems as though we're about to start doing it to the real-life inspiration behind the show's antagonist, Martha.\n\nIf you're one of the three people who hasn't watched it yet, Baby Reindeer is a semi-fictionalised account of the life of the show's creator, Richard Gadd. The show focuses on struggling comedian Donny (Gadd's stand-in), who finds his life turned upside down when he is stalked by a customer of the pub he works at. Around 22 million people have watched the show according to Netflix's own viewing figures, which perhaps inevitably has resulted in fans wanting to know more about the real people on which the story is based.\n\nEver a man of the people, Piers Morgan has promised to satiate fans' desires by airing an interview with Fiona Harvey, the 58-year-old Scottish lawyer on whom Martha is allegedly based. The interview was filmed in advance and Harvey has already expressed some dissatisfaction with how it was conducted:\n\n\"I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard ... It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nThat isn't too surprising. In a tweet to promote the interview Morgan, with his limitless grace and tact, asked of Harvey \"Is she a psycho stalker?\", just in case you were wondering what kind of tone he's likely to strike. But that's just Piers Morgan being Piers Morgan - you can no more expect him to be sensitive than you can expect a fish to climb a tree. Morgan isn't the issue here - the real problem with this interview is that there's a market for it at all.\n\nIt seems like, when it comes to certain people, we feel as though we are entitled to wring as much entertainment and information as we can out of them to satisfy our insatiable need for drama. Regardless of what Harvey has or has not allegedly done (she denies stalking Gadd), it isn't something that any number of controversy-baiting television interviews will resolve. It certainly isn't something that can be solved with death threats, which Harvey claims to have received since being outed.\n\nIf there are any \"psycho stalkers\" in this story, it's us - the people sitting at home trying to dig up information about real people, who have experienced real trauma, because we aren't satisfied with the four-hour dramatised confessional created specifically for our consumption (probably because we binged it too quickly - I know I did). I understand being curious. If I'm being honest, the first thing I did after finishing the show was read as much information about it as I could.\n\nBut surely there's a limit to that curiosity? There should be - especially when it involves a person who might be considered vulnerable. It can be fun playing internet detective, gossiping about scandal and outrageous events - but we have a responsibility to take a step back, and consider if that gossip has the potential to be harmful.\n\nLet's not forget, part of the problem here lies with Richard Gadd himself. If Gadd wants to self-mythologise, that's one thing, but in creating Baby Reindeer he was always running the risk of dragging another, potentially highly vulnerable person into his quest for fame. Harvey has effectively been sacrificed on the altar of Gadd's career, and now she has to live with a type of fame she never asked for.\n\nDoes he have a right to do that? To tell his own story, regardless of how it might impact the other key players? Sure - it's worth remembering that he's a victim of trauma too. But while he had a measure of agency in how he approached that trauma, Harvey has not been afforded the same privilege.\n\nThere's a nasty tradition in this country of punching down on people like Harvey - people we collectively decide are worthy of our derision and declare open season on. Jeremy Kyle made an entire career out of it. It's a cornerstone of our political institutions. GB News wouldn't exist without it. But there's such a thing as going too far - and I'd say gawking at somebody with an alleged history of mental health issues qualifies.\n\nIf you're really desperate for more Baby Reindeer content, consider just rewatching the show. Bring a friend over who hasn't seen it, and enjoy watching them squirm. Or better yet, do yourself a favour and just watch something else. I've heard Squid Game is pretty good.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Netflix policy chief Benjamin King told lawmakers that the show took \"every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story.\"\n\nBased on Richard Gadd's Edinburgh Fringe show, Baby Reindeer takes elements of Gadd's real life and dramatizes them. {"uri": "8118972612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:45:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:45:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:44:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/tv/tv-news/baby-reindeer-bbc-doctor-who-russell-t-davies-1235894411/", "title": "'Baby Reindeer': 'Doctor Who' Writer Says BBC Would Be \"Much Stricter\" on Protecting Identities", "body": "The writer said in an interview with The Times that the BBC would have been \"much stricter\" when it comes to disguising the real-life identities of the characters created by Scottish comedian Richard Gadd. \"Compliance and editorial policy drives us mad here but I sleep at night,\" Davies said.\n\nHis comments follow a whirlwind of scrutiny for Netflix producers, and even fans of the series, who took it upon themselves to try and unveil the real people depicted on the show, including the trans woman Gadd's character dates, played by Nava Mau, and the TV producer who sexually assaults him, portrayed by Tom Goodman-Hill.\n\nOn Thursday, British host Piers Morgan will interview a woman named Fiona Harvey who claims to be the inspiration behind the show's stalker, Martha. Harvey was identified on Facebook by fans of the show and subsequently wrote a string of posts detailing a not-so-friendly relationship with Gadd.\n\n\"Fiona Harvey wants to have her say & 'set the record straight,'\" Morgan detailed in a post on X, along with a photo of the newsman standing behind Harvey on the set of his Piers Morgan Uncensored. The post went viral, with many users questioning the moral responsibility of providing such a public platform to someone who may be suffering from mental illness.\n\nMorgan's post came hours after Baby Reindeer came up during a U.K. parliament hearing focused on British film and television projects and featuring Netflix policy chief Benjamin King.\n\nHe told lawmakers that the streamer and producers at Clerkenwell Films took \"every reasonable precaution\" to disguise the identities of the people who inspired Gadd's work, which began as a stage play of the same name.\n\nKing said: \"Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media. I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.\"\n\nRichard Osman, TV host and author of The Thursday Murder Club - soon to be adapted by Netflix - argued that Baby Reindeer would be \"patient zero\" for Netflix's compliance with the U.K. broadcast code. Speaking on his podcast, The Rest Is Entertainment, co-hosted by Marina Hyde, Osman said: \"It's an interesting case of what happens when you suddenly have an enormous hit on your hands. If there is even the slightest crack in the foundations of that hit, it will open into a chasm.\"\n\nHe concluded: \"All of the money that's spent on compliance and aftercare and all of those things is just in case. This is the absolute classic example of just in case.\"", "source": {"uri": "hollywoodreporter.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hollywood Reporter"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8119392559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "15:27:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T15:27:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T15:26:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/scottish-news/baby-reindeers-richard-gadd-struggling-32773943", "title": "Baby Reindeer's Richard Gadd struggling to cope with fame as fans camp in garden", "body": "Richard Gadd has revealed he is struggling to cope with fame.\n\nThe Scots comedian, 34, says the Netflix show Baby Reindeer's runaway success means he is unable to walk the streets.\n\nHe expected the show to sit as \"a little cult artistic gem\" when it first aired, only to wake up and find people camping in his garden.\n\nGadd, who plays himself in the seven-part series about his real life stalker, said: \"I really believed in this show but it really felt like one day it went on the platform and the next day there were people camping in my garden.\n\n\"And it was, like, crazy. I never expected it to sort of blow up like this.\n\n\"I believed it would be successful but I didn't expect overnight, I don't even like to use this word, fame.\n\n\"Suddenly I couldn't really walk down the street any more.\"\n\nBaby Reindeer is set to be the most popular Netflix show of all time.\n\nIn his first major interview since the show made him an overnight success, Gadd said \"I always believed in the show and I really loved it and I thought it would sit as a little cult, artistic gem on the Netflix platform maybe.\n\n\"But then overnight it was crazy. It felt like I woke up one day and everyone was watching it.\"\n\nGadd and his co-stars Jessica Gunning and Nava Mau headed to the US this week.\n\nThey took part in a Screen Actors Guild discussion panel on Tuesday night and attended an Emmys for your consideration screening of Baby Reindeer at West Hollywood's DGA Theater Complex on Sunset Blvd, Hollywood.\n\nThe series has been submitted as best limited series along with Gadd for best actor and best writing.\n\nGadd, who also plays the sexually ambiguous stalking victim Donny Dunn in Baby Reindeer, previously starred in the 2022 mini-series flop Wedding Season.\n\nHe revealed he lost a staggering five stone in weight in order to star in Baby Reindeer.\n\nHe said: \"I'd just shot this TV series called Wedding Season. No one watched it but I played this villain in it.\n\n\"I was about 16 stone when I did that. I was really really massive.\n\n\"I had tattoos and a weird haircut and all this stuff.\n\n\"Then Baby Reindeer, going out in that sort of post-drugs sort of fuelled, abuse-fuelled life.\n\n\"When I look back on my life in that period of time I was rake-thin so I really wanted to go back and feel that fragile in my body and feel emotionally fragile.\n\n\"So I went from 96kg down to 68.\n\n\"It was about a third of my body weight in the end.\n\n\"I was still writing the show and it was quite self-punishing.\"\n\nHe added: \"It was very much indicative of a very sort of troubled period in my life.\n\n\"I really wanted to go back there.\n\n\"We did closed sets, but I was looking over and you'd see the props guys wiping tears from their eyes.\n\n\"The show was based on such a trauma that everyone on set felt it at times.\"\n\nThe series is an adaptation of Gadd's one-man Edinburgh Fringe show.\n\nIt has drawn controversy over the ease with which internet sleuths were able to identify the real life Martha.\n\nThey trawled social media for the real posts seen in the show and identified Scots law graduate Fiona Harvey, 58.\n\nGadd admits to mixed feelings for Harvey.\n\nHe said: \"I remember when I was getting stalked, it was relentless and felt like it was everywhere and I felt like my life wasn't really functioning.\n\n\"I still had these unbelievable pangs of feeling sorry for her.\n\n\"I never saw someone who was a villain.\n\n\"I saw someone who was lost, by the system really. I saw someone who needed help and wasn't getting it.\"\n\nAnother major storyline involves Gadd being raped by a powerful male TV producer. Despite his failure to report the abuser to the police, he is proud to have shed a light on male rape and sexual assault with a spike in victims seeking help from charities including the Suzy Lamplaugh Trust, which supports victims of stalking.\n\nGadd said: \"It's amazing. All stalking and abuse charities are on the up.\n\n\"But the main sexual abuse charity for men in Britain is called We Are Survivors and they're up 200% in terms of referrals and 53% cite Baby Reindeer as the reason why.\n\n\"And then the work of the Suzy Lamplugh Trust. That's like the legacy that I want the show to have really.\"\n\nHe also admits it was difficult finding a balance between the true story and the needs of a compelling drama.\n\nGadd said: \"I never wanted to, kind of lie.\n\n\"I always had to constantly check myself to be like, does this feel truthful to me and to my experience all the way through?\n\n\"If it didn't, I would have to bring it back. But it was a tightrope.\n\n\"It was a constant process between what works for a TV show and not selling out on your own story, and that continued all the way from writing all the way to filming and all the way through the editing process in finding that right balance.\n\n\"I think we did in the end, but it was a hell of a process.\"\n\nHe added: \"I quite like the fact that its message is ambiguous.\n\n\"I sometimes have problems with work where it's so clear what it's trying to say to you.\n\n\"I've seen so many different articles on the ending of Baby Reindeer.\n\n\"For example, that where Donny looks up at the bar and people have said, well, it means he's a stalker or it means that he's realised he's similar to Martha. \"I've seen about seven different interpretations of that and I like that because I ultimately want my people to take what they want from my work.\"\n\nDon't miss the latest news from around Scotland and beyond - Sign up to our daily newsletter here.", "source": "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.radiotimes.com/tv/drama/baby-reindeer-netflix-speculation-response-newsupdate/", "title": "Netflix boss defends Baby Reindeer following intense social media speculation", "body": "But still, much of the focus of the series has been on the online speculation about the real-life identities of the characters portrayed in the show.\n\nThe seven-part drama is based on comedian Richard Gadd's own life and experiences of being stalked by someone who he has named in the series as Martha, played by Jessica Gunning.\n\nA separate storyline also sees Donny become the victim of sexual assault, which Gadd based on his own experience of abuse.\n\nBilled as a true story, some fans quickly blitzed through the series and began theorising about the real people behind the narrative, prompting Gadd to urge viewers to stop the speculation.\n\nSpeaking at a Culture, Media and Sport Committee hearing yesterday (8th May), Netflix's Senior Director of Public Policy Benjamin King was asked about the streamer's duty of care responsibility on Baby Reindeer and whether he was concerned that the characters might be identified.\n\nKing said that both Netflix and Baby Reindeer producer Clerkenwell Films took \"every reasonable precaution in disguising the real-life identities of the people involved in that story\".\n\nHe said that Netflix had to balance the protection of identities with upholding the \"veracity and authenticity\" of Baby Reindeer.\n\nRead more:\n\n\"We didn't want to anonymise that or make it generic to the point where it was no longer his story because that would undermine the intent behind the show,\" King said.\n\n\"Ultimately, it's obviously very difficult to control what viewers do, particularly in a world where everything is amplified by social media.\n\n\"I personally wouldn't be comfortable with a world in which we decided it was better that Richard was silenced and not allowed to tell the story.\"\n\nWriting on social media last month, Gadd asked fans not to speculate on the real identities of the Baby Reindeer characters.\n\nHe said: \"People I love, have worked with, and admire are unfairly getting caught up in speculation. Please don't speculate on who any of the real life people could be. The woman, who the Mirror has chosen not to name or identify via photographs, claims the controversial broadcaster \"triggered\" her emotions during their sit-down for his YouTube channel - and then branded him a \"bully\" and a \"twerp\".\n\nThe law graduate, who claims to be the woman accused in Richard Gadd's drama series, said yes to the star because she wanted to air her side of the story. But she denies suggestions she is cashing in - and said she earned just a few hundred pounds from her trip to London, where she spoke openly about being outed as the comedian's alleged stalker.\n\nJust hours before her interview goes online this evening, she told her connections on Facebook: \"Piers is a twerp. But we [already] know this. You will see in my interview I'll let the [interview] speak for itself. Piers is a bully, we all know that. He triggers emotions. But this interview will get more views. By far most of his other interviews with all misogynist men he often defends Andrew Tate Donald Trump.\"\n\nPiers Morgan was a 'twerp' according to the woman who claims to be the real-life Martha\n\nNow the woman told the Daily Record how she was unhappy with the questions that Piers put to her and described her interview as a \"sparring match\". She said: \"There was a heavy emphasis from Piers Morgan on Gadd and the emails I am supposed to have sent. I have my own thoughts on it that I'd like to keep to myself but I wouldn't say I was happy. It was very rapid to try to trip me up. He did it fast paced to catch me off guard.\n\n\"Piers kept saying to me 'are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?'. A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this. I said, 'Look, Even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff. As I said, in order to bill something as a true story, it's got to be pretty much 100% true. It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.\"\n\nSince the show hit the streaming service, the 'real Martha' said she is considering legal action\n\nThe chilling drama series centres on struggling comedian Donny Dunn's (Gadd) strange and layered relationship with a woman named Martha (Jessica Gunning), whose initially friendly demeanor unravels as she begins to stalk Donny relentlessly. During the course of multiple years, Martha sends Donny more than 41,000 emails, 744 tweets, 100 pages of letters and 350 hours of voicemails.\n\nFollowing its release last month, Baby Reindeer became a streaming sensation and is on course to be one of the Netflix's most-watched shows. Now, in a bid \"to set the record straight\", she will speak to former Good Morning Britain news anchor Piers Morgan in what he describes as a \"world exclusive\".\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on And it's why I think everyone had such respect for everything. I was blessed with this amazing team who kind of felt it with me in a lot of ways.\"\n\nDuring the discussion, Gadd also spoke about writing the show, saying that he \"never wanted to kind of lie\" about his real-life experience.\n\nRelated: Baby Reindeer star Richard Gadd opens up about \"toxic empathy\" after show success\n\n\"I always had to constantly check myself to be like, 'Does this feel truthful to me to my experience all the way through?' And if it didn't, I would have to bring it back,\" he added.\n\nFollowing Baby Reindeer's success, Gadd has opened up about the \"unbelievable response\" to the series.\n\n\"I always believed in the show and I really loved it, and I thought it would maybe sit as maybe a little cult, artistic gem on the Netflix platform,\" he told The Hollywood Reporter.\n\n\"But then overnight it was crazy. I have heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences.\"\n\nShe added: \"I haven't watched any of it... I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic.\n\n\"Some of the death threats have been really terrible online, people phoning me up. It has been absolutely horrendous.\"\n\nShe also alleged that Gadd had \"extreme psychiatric problems\" and labelled the show as a \"work of fiction\".\n\nHarvey went on to say: \"There's two true facts in that. That his name is Richard Gadd and that he works as a jobbing barman on benefits in the Hawley Arms - and that we met two or three times.\"\n\nJessica Gunning plays Martha, who becomes obsessed with the failing comedian after he gives her a cup of tea, following him home and staking out the pub where he works.\n\nBut Harvey denied that is how the pair met and alleged that she was in a pub for a meal and a drink of lemonade and that Gadd interrupted a conversation she was having with another barman.\n\nThe series, which the Standard has described as \"nail-bitingly tense\" and \"not for the faint-hearted\", has drawn huge speculation around the real identity of the stalker dramatised in the show.\n\nThe seven-episode series started on April 18 and was viewed 56.5 million times in just 26 days. {"uri": "8119531353", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:11:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:11:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:10:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-13401043/Richard-Gadd-reveals-tears-shed-set-Baby-Reindeer-filming-sexual-assault-scene.html", "title": "Richard Gadd says tears were shed on set of Baby Reindeer", "body": "Richard Gadd has revealed there were tears shed on the set of Baby Reindeer during filming of some of the show's most harrowing scenes.\n\nThe Netflix show, which follows Richard's character Donny as he is stalked by a woman named Martha, played by Jessica Gunning, has become a global hit since its release.\n\nIt shows Martha's obsession developing as she emails Donny hundreds of times a day, turning up outside his house and harassing his family and friends. It is based on Richard's real life experience.\n\nRichard has opened up about filming episode four, in which his character is sexually assaulted by a male TV writer who takes struggling comedian Donny under his wing.\n\nHe told Variety: 'We did close the set, but I was looking over and you'd see the props guys wiping tears from their eyes as they would be putting the props back how they should be.'\n\nRichard Gadd has revealed there were tears shed on the set of Baby Reindeer during filming of some of the show's most harrowing scenes\n\nRichard has opened up about filming episode four, in which his character is sexually assaulted\n\n'The show was based in such a trauma that everyone on set felt at times it was a huge, weighty thing. And it's why I think everyone had such respect for everything. I was blessed with this amazing team who kind of felt it with me in a lot of ways.'\n\nIn the same interview, Jessica told how Richard works with We Are Survivors, a non-profit organisation that supports male victims of rape and sexual abuse.\n\nThe organisation has reportedly experienced a 200% increase in people looking for support, with 60% of them citing Baby Reindeer as the reason they reached out.\n\nJessica said of the show: 'It's not an easy, buttoned-up story. Everything doesn't get tied up at the end. I think it's messy, like life is. Their dynamic is complicated and he's really honest about that. That's so refreshing to see.'\n\nRichard said making the show with Netflix, based on two critically acclaimed shows he wrote and performed at the Edinburgh Fringe festival, was cathartic and helped him come to terms with what happened earlier in his life.\n\n'If people see it they will know almost everything about me. They might judge, they might not agree, and that innately comes with some degree of anxiety, but that's what I signed up for,' he told The Times.\n\nHe pitched the show to Netflix after combining two critically acclaimed Edinburgh Fringe shows, Baby Reindeer and Monkey See, Monkey Do, which addressed his stalking and sexual assault respectively.\n\nOver a period of four-and-a-half years, the actor said he received 41,071 emails , 744 tweets, letters totalling 106 pages and 350 hours of voicemail messages. Richard told the Times police did not take his concerns seriously despite his worries about how far the real-life Martha might go in her twisted pursuits.\n\nHe said: 'We did close the set, but I was looking over and you'd see the props guys wiping tears from their eyes as they would be putting the props back how they should be'\n\nThe Netflix show, which follows Richard's character Donny as he is stalked by a woman named Martha, played by Jessica Gunning, has become a global hit since its release\n\nHe now says he is less likely to trust people after his adverse experiences with both men and women.\n\nRichard concluded: 'I used to enter situations with such abandonment, never thinking ahead and throwing my trust into people, and I got burnt. Now getting close to people can be hard.'\n\nBaby Reindeer has proven a surprise smash for Netflix, having been viewed more than 60 million times in the first month.\n\nRichard claimed he went to great lengths to conceal the identity of the woman who stalked him in real life.\n\nIn the series, after Richard meets his stalker at the bar, things soon descend into chaos.\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd at the hands of 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning, right)\n\nRichard was a struggling stand-up comic working behind the bar at a pub in London\n\nIt sees him being regularly followed at home and work, and tracked on Facebook using three fake accounts.\n\nHe told The Times: 'At first everyone at the pub thought it was funny that I had an admirer. Then she started to invade my life, following me, turning up at my gigs, waiting outside my house, sending thousands of voicemails and emails.'\n\nHe said it was 'years' before the police eventually took his complaints seriously - and six years before they finally intervened - something which prolonged the agony for everyone involved including his relatives.\n\nThe police told him at the time that unless his stalker became physically violent, there was little they could do to resolve the issue.\n\nHe has said he still finds it hard to trust people and has had 'every therapy going'.\n\nHe added that the years of being stalked have left him with something 'like PTSD'. For the Netflix role, he lost weight to match his 10-and-a-half stone 'neurotic' self at the height of his own stalking nightmare.\n\nGadd has revealed he first encountered 'Martha' when he was working in a pub and offered her a cup of tea because she was crying\n\nRichard said he's currently single and 'is more cautious' of people because of the campaign of terror that Martha inflicted, saying: 'It takes me a long time to trust them. Before, I entered situations with such abandonment and I got burnt.'\n\nHowever, performing a version of what happened to him has enabled him to have 'ownership' of the trauma. And it's why I think everyone had such respect for everything. I was blessed with this amazing team who kind of felt it with me in a lot of ways.\"\n\nDuring the discussion, Gadd also spoke about writing the show, saying that he \"never wanted to kind of lie\" about his real-life experience.\n\nRelated: Baby Reindeer star Richard Gadd opens up about \"toxic empathy\" after show success\n\n\"I always had to constantly check myself to be like, 'Does this feel truthful to me to my experience all the way through?' {"uri": "8119533188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "17:12:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T17:12:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T17:12:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/tv/baby-reindeers-richard-gadd-struggling-29141416", "title": "Baby Reindeer's Richard Gadd is 'struggling' as fans 'camp in his garden'", "body": "Richard Gadd has revealed he is struggling to cope with fame following the success of his Netflix show Baby Reindeer. The Scottish comedian, 34, says show's runaway success means he is now unable to walk the streets.\n\nHe expected the show to sit as 'a little cult artistic gem' when it first aired, only to wake up and find people camping in his garde. Baby Reindeer is set to be the most popular Netflix show of all time, reports the Daily Record.\n\nGadd, who plays himself in the seven-part series, said: \"I really believed in this show, but it really felt like one day it went on the platform and the next day there were people camping in my garden.\n\nREAD MORE: Residents react as 'Baby Reindeer star moves to Skelmersdale'\n\n\"And it was, like, crazy. I never expected it to sort of blow up like this. I believed it would be successful, but I didn't expect overnight. I don't even like to use this word, 'fame'. Suddenly I couldn't really walk down the street any more.\"\n\nIn his first major interview since the show made him an overnight success, Gadd said he 'always believed in the show and really loved it and thought it would sit as a little cult, artistic gem on the Netflix platform maybe'. He added: \"But then, overnight, it was crazy. It felt like I woke up one day and everyone was watching it.\"\n\nGadd and his co-stars Jessica Gunning and Nava Mau headed to the US this week to take part in a Screen Actors Guild discussion panel and attended an Emmys for your consideration screening of Baby Reindeer at West Hollywood's DGA Theater Complex on Sunset Blvd, Hollywood.\n\nThe series has been submitted as best limited series along with Gadd for best actor and best writing. Gadd, who plays stalking victim Donny Dunn in Baby Reindeer, previously starred in the 2022 mini-series Wedding Season.\n\nHe revealed he lost five stone to star in Baby Reindeer. He said: \"I'd just shot this TV series called Wedding Season. No one watched it, but I played this villain in it. I was about 16 stone when I did that. I was really really massive.\"\n\n\"I had tattoos and a weird haircut and all this stuff. Then Baby Reindeer, going out in that sort of post-drugs sort of fuelled, abuse-fuelled life. When I look back on my life in that period of time I was rake-thin so I really wanted to go back and feel that fragile in my body and feel emotionally fragile.\n\n\"So I went from 96kg down to 68. It was about a third of my body weight in the end. I was still writing the show and it was quite self-punishing. It was very much indicative of a very sort of troubled period in my life. I really wanted to go back there.\n\n\"We did closed sets, but I was looking over and you'd see the props guys wiping tears from their eyes. The show was based on such a trauma that everyone on set felt it at times.\"\n\nThe series is an adaptation of Gadd's one-man Edinburgh Fringe show. It has drawn controversy over the ease with which internet sleuths were able to identify the real life Martha.\n\n\"I remember when I was getting stalked, it was relentless and felt like it was everywhere and I felt like my life wasn't really functioning,\" Gadd added. \"I still had these unbelievable pangs of feeling sorry for her.\n\n\"I never saw someone who was a villain. I saw someone who was lost, by the system really. I saw someone who needed help and wasn't getting it.\"\n\nAnother major storyline involves Gadd being raped by a powerful male TV producer. Gadd said he is proud to have shed a light on the issue, with a spike in victims seeking help from charities including the Suzy Lamplaugh Trust.\n\nGadd said: \"It's amazing. All stalking and abuse charities are on the up. But the main sexual abuse charity for men in Britain is called We Are Survivors and they're up 200 per cent in terms of referrals - and 53pc cite Baby Reindeer as the reason why.\n\n\"And then the work of the Suzy Lamplugh Trust. That's like the legacy that I want the show to have really.\"\n\nHe also admits it was difficult finding a balance between the true story and the needs of a compelling drama.\n\nGadd said: \"I never wanted to, kind of lie. I always had to constantly check myself to be like, does this feel truthful to me and to my experience all the way through? If it didn't, I would have to bring it back. But it was a tightrope.\n\n\"It was a constant process between what works for a TV show and not selling out on your own story, and that continued all the way from writing all the way to filming and all the way through the editing process in finding that right balance. The story, created by Richard Gadd, tells how Donny Dunn (Gadd), a comedian going through a bad personal moment, suffers constant harassment from Martha Scott (Jessica Gunning) for four and a half years.\n\nA success that has caught the actor by surprise, who did not expect that the series, based on real events that happened to Gadd himself, would have such reach. However, who is not at all happy with all this fuss. Her name is Fiona Harvey and she is a 58-year-old lawyer who claims to be the real Martha Scott.\n\nThis was revealed in an interview with the Scottish newspaper The Daily Record last weekend, revealing his face to the world in the pages of the newspaper.\n\n\"This is Fiona Harvey. \"She is the real-life Martha from My Stuffed Reindeer and is considering taking legal action for the program in which she is portrayed as a terrifying stalker,\" they revealed from the Scottish newspaper, to whom the lawyer gave permission to reveal her identity. .\n\nAfter almost a month of experiencing media pressure due to the success of the series, Harvey wants everyone to know what he has been through since his identity became public. \"I give you my permission to name me because people have to know what is happening.\"\n\nThe woman also announced that she will sit down with journalist Piers Morgan on Thursday night for an interview.\n\n\"Fiona Harvey wants to speak out and 'set the record straight'. \"Is she a psychopathic stalker?\", they ask from the program, to announce her participation.\n\nWith this interview, the Scottish lawyer wants to tell how she has been living all this time, under pressure since the story on which the series is based was announced as a \"real\" case, based on the chilling account of Gadd's experience with her alleged stalker.\n\nFrom what is known, the lawyer is thinking of taking legal action both against Richard Gadd for how he has been portrayed in fiction and against Netflix for broadcasting the series, alleging that all the events seen in the scenes are \"a lot.\" of garbage\".\n\n\"Gadd needs to prove that I went to jail, it didn't happen. They have never sent me to jail, it's obvious,\" explains Harvey, who insists that everything that can be seen in the series is an \"invention.\" \"There are no restraining orders, court rulings or prohibitions anywhere. They do not exist. I haven't had the police at my door for any of those things,\" he insists.\n\nFor Harvey, everything is \"a bunch of crap,\" and he plans to \"go all the way,\" even though his resources are limited. {"uri": "8119812973", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "21:24:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T21:24:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T21:24:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://ew.com/baby-reindeer-richard-gadd-jessica-gunning-series-success-real-people-8645751", "title": "'Baby Reindeer' stars Richard Gadd and Jessica Gunning open up about the 'complicated' stalker series", "body": "Gerrad Hall is an executive editor at Entertainment Weekly, overseeing TV, music, and awards coverage. He is also host of the daily What to Watch podcast and weekly video series, as well as The Awardist podcast. Gerrad also cohosts EW's live Oscars, Emmys, SAG, and Grammys red carpet shows, and he has appeared on Good Morning America, The Talk, Access Hollywood, Extra!, and other talk shows, delivering the latest news on pop culture and entertainment.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning are in disbelief.\n\n\"It's been crazy,\" Gadd, the creator and star of the limited series Baby Reindeer, says on The Awardist podcast of the past few weeks since the show's debut on Netflix. \"I always believed in the show and I always thought it would be maybe a critical cult success, but I don't think I expected it to blow up in the way that it has.\"\n\nGunning is just as amazed. \"I think I knew it'd be a pretty special thing to be part of when I first read it, but I never, ever in my wildest dreams thought it would be this big,\" she says.\n\nSince its debut on April 11, the series -- based on Gadd's own experiences of being stalked by a woman who happened upon the bar where he worked, as well as being sexually assaulted by a TV producer who had become a mentor-like figure to him -- has spent the past three weeks at No. 1 on the streaming platform.\n\nGadd plays a fictionalized version of himself named Donny Dunn. A struggling comedian, he bartends at a pub where a depressed and broke Martha Scott, played by a magnetic Gunning, wanders into one day. His ability to make her laugh becomes anything but funny when she begins stalking him, turning up daily to the pub, following him home, sending more than 41,000 emails and hundreds of texts, and more.\n\nYears prior, we see how Donny was groomed and sexually assaulted by a TV producer, here named Darrien O'Connor (played by Tom Goodman-Hill), who takes him under his wing.\n\nGadd originally shared his story in a one-man show; he then wrote the series and also stars, reliving the traumas of his life. But he says he never considered someone else playing this version of himself.\n\n\"I was always willing to go down that road. I would never cast myself to the detriment of a project. I think there's been projects -- I'm not going to name any names or something -- where I think people have cast themselves in roles to the detriment of the project, and it's just felt like a vehicle for them to do an acting turn or something like this,\" Gadd tells EW. \"But I felt that it added a layer of intrigue to the show, the fact that I had been through things and then playing them out on screen. I thought it would be an interesting discussion point, which it has proved to be, and I thought it added a layer of almost art to the show.\"\n\nCheck out more from EW's The Awardist, featuring exclusive interviews, analysis, and our podcast diving into all the highlights from the year's best in TV.\n\nA discussion point, indeed. With millions of eyes on the series, interest -- understandably, inevitably -- has turned to viewers' desire to know the real identity of the people at the center of his story. As he has maintained since the series debuted, Gadd says that isn't the point. (Gunning says she doesn't \"know anything about the real person\" and \"no one's been in touch with me.\") Even with some very convincing proof pointing to one specific woman, who is now doing interviews about the series, Gadd holds firm on protecting the identities of the real Martha and Darrien.\n\n\"I've gone about telling this story how I want to tell it. How I heal myself and my journey is up to me, really. I think it's a dark society that puts pressure on victims -- survivors -- of sexual abuse, to sort of do anything with it. Their job is to do what's right for them at the time,\" Gadd says. \"I want Baby Reindeer to be enjoyed as a piece of work. I got a great deal of catharsis from doing shows like [the one-man show] Monkey See Monkey Do and shows like Baby Reindeer and putting both those live shows into the series that we now know as Baby Reindeer. I got a great deal of healing from that. And I am not going to ever name the real-life people behind this show, and I don't think the pressure should be on survivors to out their abusers -- the pressure should be on the abusers to stop abusing.\"\n\nAs Donny's stalker, Gunning is captivating in her ability to be sheepish or flirty one minute and angry and obsessive the next. It's a gem of a role on paper -- \"It's the best thing I've ever read,\" Gunning admits -- and, while complicated and daunting, also one to play.\n\n\"I don't think there has been a character like Martha really written before, with so many sides to her, so complicated and truthfully told, so nuanced, and not black and white, not your kind of average stalker story at all,\" she says. \"That's what was so exciting about the project.\"\n\nGiven the enormous success of the series, one might assume that Netflix would be hungry for more. Audiences, it seems, would come along for the ride. But by all accounts, Gadd is done with this chapter of his life.\n\n\"I'm 99.9 percent sure that Baby Reindeer is done,\" he says. \"It's got this full circle element to it -- the way he meets Martha, the way it finishes. I think it's a limited series. It captures that moment in my life [from] the moment it kind of began up to the moment it ended. But season 2 would be some sort of fictional jump-off point of some kind. Baby Reindeer has been received with such global love and affection, and I think a lot of that stems from the authenticity of everything, and I wouldn't want to just do a second season for the sake of it and start placing these characters inside moments and stuff that I couldn't recognize in myself and in my own life. And I worry that the authenticity would leak out of the screen.\"\n\nListen to the Awardist podcast below for more from Gadd and Gunning, as they look back on the episodes they couldn't wait to get filmed and behind them, why Gadd wishes this is a show he was able to watch when he was younger, how they found moments of levity on the set, and more.", "source": {"uri": "ew.com", "dataType": As you know, it's the fog of war...\"\n\nMorgan pressed further: \"You've got exact numbers for the Hamas terrorists you've killed, why wouldn't you know how many civilians you've killed?\"\n\nHyman replied: \"Because obviously, our focus is to go after the Hamas terrorists...\"\n\nMorgan interjected: \"But hang on, that does imply that you're putting a bigger premium on killing Hamas terrorists in terms of numbers and accountability, than you are innocent civilians - that can't be right, surely?\n\n\"If you know exactly how many Hamas terrorists you've killed, you must know how many civilians you've killed, otherwise you're prioritising the lives of terrorists over innocent people.\"\n\nAfter a five-minute clip of the longer interview was shared to social media, viewers have praised the \"exemplary\" display of journalism:\n\nThis, however, was soon contrasted by the news that, on Thursday's edition of his programme, he would be interviewing Fiona Harvey, who he described as the \"real-life Martha\" who inspired the character in the Netflix series, Baby Reindeer.\n\nWritten by and starring Richard Gadd, and drawing from his real-life experience (it's also based on a stage play of the same name), the limited series follows a comedian who is stalked by a woman named 'Martha' after offering her a free cup of tea at a bar he works at.\n\nFollowing Morgan's announcement of the interview on social media, people have slammed the \"world exclusive\" as \"irresponsible\":\n\nThe upcoming interview is despite Gadd issuing a statement on social media last month urging internet sleuths not to speculate on the real-life identities of those featured in the series - not just Martha (played by Jessica Gunning), but also a TV executive named 'Darrien' (played by Tom Goodman-Hill) who groomed and sexually assaulted Gadd.\n\nHe said: \"People I love, have worked with, and admire (including Sean Foley) are unfairly caught up in speculation.
