says she received death threats", "body": "Fiona Harvey, 58, denies stalking comedian Richard Gadd and calls Netflix show 'hyperbole'\n\nA woman described as the inspiration behind the character of Martha in the Netflix drama Baby Reindeer has spoken out about receiving death threats and to deny being a stalker.\n\nIn the drama written by and starring comedian Richard Gadd, his character Donny is stalked by a woman called Martha after he serves her a free cup of tea in the pub where he works.\n\nFiona Harvey, 58, described Gadd's account as a \"work of fiction\" and \"hyperbole\".\n\nIn an interview with Piers Morgan on Thursday, Harvey said: \"On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats.\"\n\nHarvey denied numerous allegations depicted in the Netflix drama that she stalked the comedian, attacked his girlfriend, lunged at him, sat outside his house and contacted his parents.\n\nShe also denied sending Gadd 41,000 emails, hundreds of voice messages and 106 letters, telling Morgan she only sent him a few emails, one letter by post and about 18 messages on X.\n\nHarvey, who said she has not watched Baby Reindeer, said she met Gadd at a pub in London \"five or six\" times and once joked to the comedian that he reminded her of a baby reindeer toy she had as a child, which inspired the title of the hit series.\n\nShe also denied that a Netflix scene depicting Gadd looking through her window happened in real life.\n\nHarvey said she knew the comedian for around two or three months, did not have his phone number and was not friends with him.\n\nShe said her message to Gadd would be \"leave me alone please\" and added she was considering legal action against the comedian and Netflix.\n\nHarvey, who grew up in Scotland and studied law, also denied she went to prison for any stalking offence.\n\nAfter the programme's release in April, some viewers have tried to track down the real Martha by matching social media posts featured in the drama with real-life messages.\n\nWhen viewers began to speculate over the real people who inspired the events behind the series, Gadd, 34, posted a message to his Instagram story.\n\nHe said: Reindeer 'stalker' breaks silence", "body": "Baby Reindeer: Real-life 'Martha' Fiona Harvey breaks silence in Piers Morgan interview, says she's innocent Max CorstorphanThe NightlyFri, 10 May 2024 6:01AMCommentsComments\n\nThe woman claiming to be the real-life 'Martha' from the hit Netflix series Baby Reindeer has broken her silence claiming she is not a stalker and she didn't know Gadd was \"a complete psychopath who was going to attack\" her.\n\nBaby Reindeer, written by and starring Richard Gadd, is based on Gadd's real-life experience of being stalked and sexually assaulted in his twenties.\n\nThe series captured the interest of viewers worldwide, quickly becoming one of the most successful series on the streaming platform.\n\nIn her first-ever television interview, the woman claiming to be the real-life Martha, Fiona Harvey, spoke to the veteran broadcaster Piers Morgan, denying stalking or assaulting Gadd and claiming he was \"psychotic\".\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nMs Harvey first denied ever being given free drinks at the Hawley Arms pub where Gadd worked, however, accepted that she did have a baby reindeer toy and she once likened Gadd to as a joke.\n\nMorgan put to Ms Harvey the simple claim of Gadd that he was sent 41,000 emails, 350 voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages and 106 letters, something Gadd says he has a record of.\n\n\"That's simply not true,\" Ms Harvey said.\n\n\"I don't think I sent him anything.\"\n\nHowever over the next near-hour sit-down interview, Ms Harvey's claims of not having \"sent him anything\" continued to unravel with the admission of sending him some emails, accepting that she had tweeted him on occasion but stayed steadfast in not having sent him voice messages.\n\nMorgan read one of the tweets from Ms Harvey's X profile which said \"My curtains need hung badly.\"\n\n\"We were trying to encourage him with this first show or something like that, a long time ago,\" Ms Harvey replied dismissing the post.\n\nMorgan continued reading from historic tweets, including one that said: \"Please go and see Richard Gadd's show. It's well-written and neurotic. The filmed bum shots are the best. Fantastic ass.\"\n\n\"It was a joke,\" Ms Harvey fired back.\n\nMore to come...\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": {"eng-9551540": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119853988", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:08:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:08:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:08:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/as-woman-says-inspired-baby-32776371", "title": "'Was enough really done to protect the 'real-life' Baby Reindeer Martha'", "body": "'The first question many of us had was - how long before the real Martha shows up?'\n\nWhen Netflix unveiled its gritty new drama Baby Reindeer, the first question many of us had was - how long before the real Martha shows up?\n\nFor the uninitiated, the show tells the story of Martha, a stalker, who latches on to a struggling stand-up comedian and makes his life a misery. Given that it was based on the real-life experiences of creator Richard Gadd, it seemed inevitable that amateur internet sleuths would soon be trying to find the woman who inspired the depiction of his fictional stalker.\n\nAnd if they found her, surely she would relish the attention that being a central character in a major \u00adinternational TV show would bring? Oh no, we were told, that's not going to happen, we've taken steps to protect her anonymity. But tonight, a woman who claims to be the basis for Martha gave her side of the story to Piers Morgan's YouTube series, Uncensored.\n\nShe told him that almost everything about the series, which starts with the words \"this is a true story\", was a lie. Branding Richard as \"psychotic\" and the \"ultimate misogynist\", she insisted that virtually every aspect of the series he'd written was \"completely untrue\" - including that she'd been to prison for stalking.\n\nNow viewers will have to decide what they believe. The woman flatly denies sending thousands of texts and email messages, and claimed the drama had been: \"Very, very defamatory to me, very career-damaging.\" Claiming she'd received death threats from viewers as far away as the US, she insisted: \"I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions. This is complete nonsense.\"\n\nViewers took to social media to try to find the 'real-life' Martha Scott after watching the show\n\nAnd the self-proclaimed real-life Martha - who the Mirror has chosen not to name - said she was \"forced\" to reveal her identity in order to defend herself. \"On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats,\" she said. \"So it wasn't really a choice. I was forced into this situation.\"\n\nThe news that she was going to give the TV interview sparked a huge \u00adreaction from the many millions of UK viewers who've watched the chart-topping seven-part series. Some thought it was only fair that she got the chance to do so, while others found the whole idea \u00ad\"exploitative\" and argued that someone who has grappled with serious mental health issues should not be given that sort of platform.\n\nNetflix has said that the emails and messages which appear on-screen in the show were the actual ones sent to Richard by his stalker over a period of four years - 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, 46 Facebook messages, letters running to 106 pages and 350 hours of phone messages.\n\nBut speaking to Piers, the woman insisted she'd only sent him \"a couple of emails\" containing \"banter\". Pressed on who might be behind all the other messages, she said: \"I have no idea.\" She then claimed Richard had made them up and that she'd turned down his sexual advances. The self-proclaimed \"Martha\" did admit to owning four mobile phones and having up to six email addresses, which Piers pointed out was extremely odd.\n\nAsked if she planned to take legal action, she replied: \"Absolutely. Against both him and Netflix.\" But with no money to back her legal plans, she intends to represent herself. Richard, 34, portrays Martha as clever, having described her as being a woman whose \"only skill greater than her ability to harass was her ability to evade the law\".\n\nNetflix is now coming under fire after the woman's claim to have been identified as Martha. Richard himself plays Donny, a version of himself, while The Outlaws star Jessica Gunning portrays his stalker and Tom Goodman-Hill takes the role of Derrien, a TV executive who groomed and then raped him.\n\nSo did Netflix and the producers made enough effort to try and protect the anonymity of the woman who inspired Martha, given that the story revolves around her and that she had no input into the series? At the show's media launch in April, executives felt sure that the woman who harassed Richard for many years was unlikely to come out of the woodwork.\n\nShe didn't make an \u00adappearance after he turned his stalking and sexual assault horror into an award-winning Edinburgh play, they reasoned, so we don't think that she will give us any trouble now. It seems that they simply did not foresee this scenario. One executive producer from Clerkenwell Films revealed there was an exclusion order in place which prevented Richard's harasser from making contact with him - meaning she would be arrested if she turned up at the launch in London's Soho.\n\nThe show was written by and starred Richard Gadd\n\nAnd she insisted there was no chance of viewers rumbling fictional Martha Scott's real identity because they had been at pains to digitally airbrush her out of existence. Asked how much the stalker knew about the series ahead of it dropping on Netflix last month, the TV exec said it was unclear. \"We don't know because we're not allowed contact,\" she explained. \"And if you Google anything on here, it won't come up with her on the internet with her real name and what really happened. Everything is disguised.\n\n\"We've made sure and Netflix's legal team has made sure. Anything that could lead back to her has gone.\" She said any decision for the stalker to unveil her own identity and put herself forward for interviews was \"out of our control\". \"Obviously, we were really aware when we took on this story that there were implications in that respect,\" she explained. \"We're making a show with real people involved, so we've taken an extreme amount of care that they couldn't be identified and we've taken an extreme amount of care that they are presented with understanding.\"\n\nIn the series, Martha is indeed portrayed sympathetically at times, with Richard taking responsibility for mistakes he made. The Baby Reindeer producer added: \"What we tried really hard to do was make sure that Martha was portrayed in a way where she's not the baddie and Richard's not the goodie.\"\n\nBut despite the measures taken, and a plea from Richard himself, one woman says she has been unmasked and is considering legal action. As for the predatory male TV executive, one innocent man has already had to be defended by Richard, who urged: \"Please don't speculate on who the real-life people could be. That's not the point of our show.\" It may not have been, but it does seem like an inevitable consequence.\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok , Snapchat , Instagram , Twitter , Facebook , YouTube and Threads .", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nicola_methven@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Nicola Methven", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"eng-9551540": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119853988", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "22:08:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T22:08:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T22:08:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv/tv-news/as-woman-says-inspired-baby-32776371", "title": "'Was enough really done to protect the 'real-life' Baby Reindeer Martha'", "body": "'The first question many of us had was - how long before the real Martha shows up?'\n\nWhen Netflix unveiled its gritty new drama Baby Reindeer, the first question many of us had was - how long before the real Martha shows up?\n\nFor the uninitiated, the show tells the story of Martha, a stalker, who latches on to a struggling stand-up comedian and makes his life a misery. Given that it was based on the real-life experiences of creator Richard Gadd, it seemed inevitable that amateur internet sleuths would soon be trying to find the woman who inspired the depiction of his fictional stalker.\n\nAnd if they found her, surely she would relish the attention that being a central character in a major \u00adinternational TV show would bring? Oh no, we were told, that's not going to happen, we've taken steps to protect her anonymity. But tonight, a woman who claims to be the basis for Martha gave her side of the story to Piers Morgan's YouTube series, Uncensored.\n\nShe told him that almost everything about the series, which starts with the words \"this is a true story\", was a lie. Branding Richard as \"psychotic\" and the \"ultimate misogynist\", she insisted that virtually every aspect of the series he'd written was \"completely untrue\" - including that she'd been to prison for stalking.\n\nNow viewers will have to decide what they believe. The woman flatly denies sending thousands of texts and email messages, and claimed the drama had been: \"Very, very defamatory to me, very career-damaging.\" Claiming she'd received death threats from viewers as far away as the US, she insisted: \"I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions. This is complete nonsense.\"\n\nViewers took to social media to try to find the 'real-life' Martha Scott after watching the show\n\nAnd the self-proclaimed real-life Martha - who the Mirror has chosen not to name - said she was \"forced\" to reveal her identity in order to defend herself. \"On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats,\" she said. \"So it wasn't really a choice. I was forced into this situation.\"\n\nThe news that she was going to give the TV interview sparked a huge \u00adreaction from the many millions of UK viewers who've watched the chart-topping seven-part series. Some thought it was only fair that she got the chance to do so, while others found the whole idea \u00ad\"exploitative\" and argued that someone who has grappled with serious mental health issues should not be given that sort of platform.\n\nNetflix has said that the emails and messages which appear on-screen in the show were the actual ones sent to Richard by his stalker over a period of four years - 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, 46 Facebook messages, letters running to 106 pages and 350 hours of phone messages.\n\nBut speaking to Piers, the woman insisted she'd only sent him \"a couple of emails\" containing \"banter\". Pressed on who might be behind all the other messages, she said: \"I have no idea.\" She then claimed Richard had made them up and that she'd turned down his sexual advances. The self-proclaimed \"Martha\" did admit to owning four mobile phones and having up to six email addresses, which Piers pointed out was extremely odd.\n\nAsked if she planned to take legal action, she replied: \"Absolutely. Against both him and Netflix.\" But with no money to back her legal plans, she intends to represent herself. Richard, 34, portrays Martha as clever, having described her as being a woman whose \"only skill greater than her ability to harass was her ability to evade the law\".\n\nNetflix is now coming under fire after the woman's claim to have been identified as Martha. Richard himself plays Donny, a version of himself, while The Outlaws star Jessica Gunning portrays his stalker and Tom Goodman-Hill takes the role of Derrien, a TV executive who groomed and then raped him.\n\nSo did Netflix and the producers made enough effort to try and protect the anonymity of the woman who inspired Martha, given that the story revolves around her and that she had no input into the series? At the show's media launch in April, executives felt sure that the woman who harassed Richard for many years was unlikely to come out of the woodwork.\n\nShe didn't make an \u00adappearance after he turned his stalking and sexual assault horror into an award-winning Edinburgh play, they reasoned, so we don't think that she will give us any trouble now. It seems that they simply did not foresee this scenario. One executive producer from Clerkenwell Films revealed there was an exclusion order in place which prevented Richard's harasser from making contact with him - meaning she would be arrested if she turned up at the launch in London's Soho.\n\nThe show was written by and starred Richard Gadd\n\nAnd she insisted there was no chance of viewers rumbling fictional Martha Scott's real identity because they had been at pains to digitally airbrush her out of existence. Asked how much the stalker knew about the series ahead of it dropping on Netflix last month, the TV exec said it was unclear. \"We don't know because we're not allowed contact,\" she explained. \"And if you Google anything on here, it won't come up with her on the internet with her real name and what really happened. Everything is disguised.\n\n\"We've made sure and Netflix's legal team has made sure. Anything that could lead back to her has gone.\" She said any decision for the stalker to unveil her own identity and put herself forward for interviews was \"out of our control\". \"Obviously, we were really aware when we took on this story that there were implications in that respect,\" she explained. \"We're making a show with real people involved, so we've taken an extreme amount of care that they couldn't be identified and we've taken an extreme amount of care that they are presented with understanding.\"\n\nIn the series, Martha is indeed portrayed sympathetically at times, with Richard taking responsibility for mistakes he made. The Baby Reindeer producer added: \"What we tried really hard to do was make sure that Martha was portrayed in a way where she's not the baddie and Richard's not the goodie.\"\n\nBut despite the measures taken, and a plea from Richard himself, one woman says she has been unmasked and is considering legal action. As for the predatory male TV executive, one innocent man has already had to be defended by Richard, who urged: \"Please don't speculate on who the real-life people could be. That's not the point of our show.\" It may not have been, but it does seem like an inevitable consequence.\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok , Snapchat , Instagram , Twitter , Facebook , YouTube and Threads .", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mirror"}, "authors": [{"uri": "nicola_methven@mirror.co.uk", "name": "Nicola Methven", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"eng-9551540": {"articles": {"results": [{"uri": "8119900565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "23:06:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T23:06:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T23:04:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/piers-morgan-interviews-baby-reindeer-230126277.html", "title": "Piers Morgan interviews Baby Reindeer's real-life 'Martha', review: Nothing compulsive about this dreary Q&A", "body": "Netflix's Baby Reindeer is a shocking and gripping drama with a twist around every corner. Piers Morgan's interview with the Scottish lawyer who has identified herself as the woman behind the stalker character in the series was none of those things.\n\nGoing out on Morgan's YouTube channel, the 60-minute conversation was less a sparring match between Morgan and Fiona Harvey than a dreary question-and-answer session. The host lacked his usually pugilistic chutzpah and had the washed out pallor of someone who'd been up all night bingeing Netflix.\n\nStill, he was keen to get to the bottom of the Baby Reindeer mystery. Its writer and star, Richard Gadd, has said the stalking incidents depicted in the show were inspired by true events. So was Fiona guilty of the compulsive behaviour engaged in by her onscreen lookalike Martha?\n\nShe shook her head firmly. Harvey, 58, described Baby Reindeer as \"taking over her life\" and made it clear that she did not hold Gadd in high regard.\n\nMorgan drilled into the details, and this was where the conversation became strictly for Baby Reindeer obsessives. Like Martha, Harvey was a lawyer from Scotland who had encountered Gadd in a pub in Camden in London. And yes, she had come up with the phrase \"Baby Reindeer\", as claimed by the series.\n\nBut she was emphatically not a stalker. Did she send Gadd 41,000 emails - as alleged in one episode? \"Absolutely not. I don't think I've sent him anything,\" she said. \"A couple of emails, jokey banter emails.\"\n\nThe host insisted that he wasn't trying to trip Harvey up or pin her to her collar. He said that the ease with which she had been tracked down by viewers who cross-referenced public tweets she had sent Gadd with the timeline in which the story takes place showed that Netflix had failed in its duty of care toward her. As an experienced journalist, he would have worked out her identity after 10 minutes.\n\nMorgan's YouTube set was a weird mix of US-style cable news bombast - all those glittering backgrounds, that big desk - and breakfast TV production values. To the right of Morgan's large head, viewers could write messages: they helpfully added comments such as \"OMG!\" and \"hurry up\".\n\nBut Morgan didn't hurry up. Instead, he politely but firmly grilled Harvey about her legal education in Scotland and the precise number of email accounts she operated - it used to be between \"four and six\" and no, she didn't think that unusual .\n\nGadd has taken to social media to ask people to stop trying to work out the identity of the individual who inspired Baby Reindeer. Harvey had already denied that she had committed any of the acts we see perpetuated on screen. \"This is all made up and hyperbole,\" she said in an interview with Daily Record. \"There are no restraining orders, injunctions or interdicts anywhere. There's just no way. I've not had the police at my door about any of these things.\"\n\nThere was a cheesy moment at the end when he asked her to look into the camera and speak to the audience directly. However, she had already made her feelings known when Morgan asked her if she was challenging Gadd to share evidence about stalking. but furiously denied stalking comic Richard Gadd and said she would take Netflix to court over the drama.\n\nIn a bombshell interview Ms Harvey, 58, said she had only met the comedian three times and when quizzed on the content of some of the messages she admitted sending him called them 'jokey banter'\n\nThe Scottish woman went on to say she wanted to 'set the record straight' following the Netflix show's phenomenal global success and trolls contacting her online after it began streaming.\n\nHowever, she denied sending him 41,000 emails and scores of tweets and claimed instead it was more like just ten messages and one letter sent by post.\n\nIn the wide-ranging interview with Piers Morgan, she revealed details of her 'impoverished' upbringing and that she was in a five-year relationship with a male lawyer.\n\nBaby Reindeer's 'Martha' has said her real name is Fiona Harvey in a bombshell Piers Morgan interview about Richard Gadd's Netflix stalking drama\n\nThe 58-year-old alleged stalker is pictured on Morgan's programme\n\nThe show has been a global success and follows 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning) as she stalks aspiring comedian Richard Gadd - who is called Donny Dunn in the show\n\nPiers Morgan has dropped the first trailer ahead of his interview with the 'real-life Martha' from Baby Reindeer, which is set to air on Thursday evening at 8pm\n\nShocked social media users slammed the programme on X, saying it was a 'painful watch'\n\nOne viewer, called Sarah Lucy, wrote on X: 'I'm disturbed watching the Piers Morgan interview with Fiona Harvey.\n\n'It's deeply troubling to see her obvious mental health struggles exploited for sensationalism and poor taste.'\n\nAnother social media user, called Lucy, said: 'Fiona Harvey's fixed beliefs and delusions are clear signs of severe mental health issues to anybody that works within this field.\n\nRead More I'm the real 'Martha' but I didn't do half of what Baby Reindeer accused me of! Fiona Harvey says she inspired Netflix stalker - yet insists she didn't send Richard Gadd 41,000 emails, only met him three times - and has a new lawyer boyfriend\n\n'It's clear she's being exploited for financial gain.'\n\nA third Twitter/X user added: 'It was highly irresponsible to put Fiona Harvey on TV!'\n\nDuring the interview, Fiona Harvey also admitted she uses four phones as 'I like keeping people on separate phones'.\n\nMailOnline had until now chosen not to name and picture her. But following her appearance with Piers Morgan we have decided to publish her picture.\n\nThe Scottish woman broke her silence in her first ever TV interview with Piers tonight at 8pm.\n\nShe said she met Mr Gadd 'two or three times' and said she did call him a 'baby reindeer'.\n\nOn being 'outed' within hours as the 'real-life Martha' online, she said: 'On the internet, sleuths tracked me down and hounded me and gave me death threats. So it wasn't really a choice. I was forced into this situation.'\n\nShe said: 'I think he [Mr Gadd] always wanted this to come out.\n\n'I don't think I sent him anything. There may have been a couple of emails, jokey banter, but that is it.'\n\nAsked if she had a message for Richard Gadd if he was watching, she said: 'Leave me alone, please. Get a life, get a proper job. I am horrified at what you've done.'\n\nShe said she would 'absolutely' be taking legal action against him and Netflix.\n\nShe admitted tweeting him 18 times, sending fewer than ten emails and sending him one letter but denied messaging him on Facebook.\n\nBaby Reindeer, the extraordinary hit Netflix drama, has been viewed more than 60 million times in the past month\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd at the hands of 'Martha' (played by Jessica Gunning, right)\n\nThe clip of the interview sees Morgan grilling the alleged stalker on everything from her views on Richard Gadd to whether she has ever been to prison\n\nShe said she would happily open up her accounts to prove this.\n\nShe also refused leaving him voicemails.\n\nShe denied ever being charged with an offence or going to jail, as the show suggests the character Martha does.\n\nShe added: 'I think he's probably made it up himself.'\n\n'Why now, why didn't he go to the police at the time?'\n\nShe said: 'I think anyone going along and doing this to anybody - I find the behaviour outrageous.'\n\nAsked if she had watched the drama, she replied: 'Not at all. I've heard about the court scene, about the jail sentences and all this sort of stuff... I haven't watched any of it.'\n\n'You're not curious, too?' Morgan asked.\n\nShe replied: 'No, I think I'd be sick. It's taken over enough of my life. I find it quite obscene. I find it horrifying, misogynistic.\n\nBaby Reindeer delves into Richard's harrowing real-life stalking ordeal and brutal sexual abuse as he plays a fictionalised version of himself called Donny Dunn (pictured)\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning attended a photo call for a screening in LA on Tuesday\n\n'Some of the death threats have been really terrible online. People phoning me up. You know, it's been absolutely horrendous. I wouldn't give credence to something like that and it's not really my kind of drama.'\n\nFiona Harvey's denials\n\nPiers asked if it was true Gadd had offered her a free cup of tea after she walked into the pub where he was working, she replied: 'No, that's not correct.'\n\nOn whether she said he looked like a 'baby reindeer' toy she had as a child, she added: 'I had a toy reindeer and he'd shaved his head, that bit is true, and there were reindeers in the shops because it was Christmas time or something. It was a joke.'\n\nShe confirmed she banter in the pub had been common, like talking about hanging curtains. 'This was a Hawley Arms joke about about curtains and a lot of sexual innuendo,' she said.\n\nFiona denied Gadd had ever been caught peeping in her window, adding: 'False... I didn't see him at my house. I think it would be impossible to look through a window... That categorically didn't happen.'\n\nPressed on the 41,000 emails, 350 hours of voice messages, 744 tweets, 48 Facebook messages, and 106 letters she is alleged to have sent him, she retorted: 'That's simply not true. There may have been a couple of emails exchanging, but that was it. Just jokey banter emails.'\n\nShe denied sending texts or Facebook messages but admitted sending hom 'about 18 tweets'.\n\nShe said she had sent him 'less than ten' emails.\n\nOn whether she ever heckled Gadd at a comedy show, she said: 'No.'\n\nOn whether she ever attacked one of the comedian's girlfriends during a jealous rage, she said: 'No, I don't think he had a girlfriend. But no, I have never been to his house or attacked any girlfriend or anything like that.'\n\nAsked about the scenes showing Martha sitting for hours at a bus stop and whether she ever did that, she replied: 'No. Absolutely no... This is a fictional character. Hyperbole, exaggeration. This is a fiction. It's based on his imagination.' Fiona also denied ever contacting his parents.\n\nAfter watching a clip of the series, showing Martha pleading guilty to intimidating Richard's character Donny and being sentenced to nine months prison time, Piers asked if she had ever been to prison or been charged, she replied 'no' to both questions.\n\nAsked again if the nine month prison sentence in the drama is based on reality, she said: 'That's completely untrue. Very, very defamatory to me, very career damaging. And I wanted to rebut that completely on this show. I'm not a stalker. I've not been to jail, I've not got injunctions, interdicts. This is just complete nonsense.'\n\nOn whether Netflix had ever contacted her, she said: 'No. No one's contacted me. Never.'\n\nOn whether she believes the comedian 'felt sorry for her', she replied: 'No, I never got that impression at all. I got the impression that he was all out for himself.'\n\nAsked about previous 'inappropriate behaviour' when working for a legal firm in Scotland, she said she had been headhunted due to her employment law credentials. She said no order or hearing was made against her in the aftermath.\n\nPushed again on whether she had left voicemails or sent strings of messages, she said the only explanation for the voice messages must be that she had been taped in the pub while speaking.\n\nOn whether she was ever in love with him, she said 'no, I don't fancy little boys without jobs'.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nShe said the interest in her was 'absolutely horrendous'.\n\nShe said: 'I couldn't believe he'd done that. And so long after the first meeting, you know, we're talking 10, 12 years ago, really horrendous.'\n\nSpeaking about her childhood, she said it was a 'standard Scottish upbringing' in the 'countryside'.\n\nShe said she was 'impoverished' but had a 'middle class upbringing' along with her sister.\n\nMs Harvey said: 'My mother worked incredibly hard. My parents got divorced when I was nine but she worked like a Trojan.'\n\nThe 58-year-old also revealed she was in a five-year relationship with a male lawyer.\n\nMorgan has already faced a backlash from mental health campaigners and survivors of stalking over his 'irresponsible' decision to interview the woman.\n\nToday, the alleged stalker hit out at Morgan, saying she felt she had been 'set up' during her appearance on his show.\n\nBefore the t\u00eate-\u00e0-t\u00eate with the celebrity interviewer even aired, the woman went on the offensive, saying she is 'not happy' and felt she was being 'set up' by the interviewer.\n\nDescribing the 30-minute grilling as a 'sparring match', the alleged female stalker has accused Morgan of trying to 'trip her up' with his questions.\n\n'Piers kept saying to me ''are you sure you haven't sent this guy 41,000 emails and phone calls?''.\n\n'A lot of the interview, for a good 10 minutes, he kept coming back to this,' she told the Daily Record.\n\n'I said, ''Look, even if I had sent some emails, it doesn't mean I'm guilty of the rest of the stuff''.\n\n'As I said, in order to bill something as a ''true story'', it's got to be pretty much 100 per cent true.'\n\nShe added: 'It seemed to me that I was set up. I feel a bit used.'\n\nThe Piers Morgan Uncensored special is airing on the broadcaster's YouTube channel, which has 2.58million subscribers.\n\nThe woman will be looking to 'set the record straight' as she breaks her silence following Baby Reindeer's global success, the preview said.\n\nBefore her big interview, she paid a visit to celebrity hairdresser John Hala - who has styled the barnets of A-listers Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sigourney Weaver, Elle MacPherson and Kate Moss - at his salon in London's Canary Wharf.\n\nSpeaking to the Daily Record, she claimed she was paid \u00a3250 for the interview and had turned down requests from the likes of This Morning to talk about Baby Reindeer.\n\nThe chilling real-life drama was inspired by the ordeal suffered by Scottish creator and leading man Richard Gadd - who is called Donny Dunn in the show.\n\nWorking as a struggling stand-up comic, Dunn first meets his stalker after he offered 'a crying stranger a cup of tea' while he was working at a bar in London.\n\nThings rapidly turn sinister, with the series claiming 'Martha' bombarded the 34-year-old from Fife with more than 41,000 emails.\n\nShe also sent him hundreds of tweets and and flooded his phone with hours of voicemails over an alleged four-year campaign of terror.\n\nPosting ahead of the show, Morgan said: 'The real-life Martha from Baby Reindeer breaks cover and gives me her first TV interview about the smash hit Netflix show.'\n\nHe added: 'Is she a psycho stalker? Find out on Piers Morgan Uncensored.'\n\nBaby Reindeer has proven a surprise smash for Netflix, having been viewed more than 60 million times in the first month.\n\nRiding on the show's phenomenal success, the cast were pictured attending a swanky screening in Los Angeles on Wednesday.\n\nRichard Gadd and Jessica Gunning - who plays Martha - beamed as they posed arm in arm and joined Nava Mau and others for a Q and A on stage.\n\nThe actress looked worlds away from her role as Martha and had a glamorous Hollywood makeover as they took to the stage\n\nOver four and a half years, Gadd says he received 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, letters totalling 106 pages and 350 hours of voicemail messages from the older woman, whom he calls Martha in the show\n\nHowever, the show's runaway success has been far from a joy for the 'real-life' Martha, who claimed she had been left a 'victim' by its surprise popularity.\n\nSpeaking exclusively to Mail+ last month, the woman insisted she was not a stalker and said: 'He's using Baby Reindeer to stalk me now.\n\n'I'm the victim. He's written a bloody show about me.'\n\nShe accused Gadd of having 'main character syndrome' and claimed she had faced 'bullying' as a result of the show and was now considering legal action against him.\n\n'He always thinks he's at the centre of things.\n\n'I'm not writing shows about him or promoting them in the media, am I?\n\n'If he wanted me to be properly anonymous, he could have done so. Gadd should leave me alone,' she added.\n\nGadd claimed he went to great lengths to conceal the identity of the woman who stalked him in real life.\n\nDespite the comic begging fans not to search for the real 'Martha', internet sleuths went on to claim she was the inspiration for the character.\n\nIn the series, after Gadd meets his stalker at the bar, things soon descend into chaos.\n\nIt sees him being regularly followed at home and work, and tracked on Facebook using three fake accounts.\n\nRichard Gadd was a struggling stand-up comic working behind the bar at a pub in London\n\nHe told The Times: 'At first everyone at the pub thought it was funny that I had an admirer. Then she started to invade my life, following me, turning up at my gigs, waiting outside my house, sending thousands of voicemails and emails.'\n\nIt developed to terrifying lengths as the crazed fan got closer to her obsession - including her turning up at his gigs, his workplace and bombarding him with messages.\n\nThe actor and comedian was subjected to a campaign of obsession by the woman, known as Martha, that manifested in 41,071 emails, 744 tweets, 106 pages of letters and a staggering 350 hours of voicemail.\n\nHe says it was 'years' before the police eventually took his complaints seriously - and six years before they finally intervened - something which prolonged the agony for everyone involved including his relatives.\n\nThe police told him at the time that unless his stalker became physically violent, there was little they could do to resolve the issue.\n\nHe has said he still finds it hard to trust people and has had 'every therapy going'.\n\nGadd has revealed he first encountered 'Martha' when he was working in a pub and offered her a cup of tea because she was crying\n\nHe added that the years of being stalked have left him with something 'like PTSD'. For the Netflix role, he lost weight to match his 10-and-a-half stone 'neurotic' self at the height of his own stalking nightmare.\n\nGadd says he's currently single and 'is more cautious' of people because of the campaign of terror that Martha inflicted, saying: 'It takes me a long time to trust them. Before, I entered situations with such abandonment and I got burnt.'\n\nHowever, performing a version of what happened to him has enabled him to have 'ownership' of the trauma. Gadd earned a Fringe award for his show, also called Baby Reindeer, in 2019.\n\nSpeaking to the Telegraph in 2019 about the one-man show that he wrote after the ordeal, which is currently on at London's Bush theatre, he said: 'It was debilitating beyond belief.\n\n'I'd listen to her voicemails and just feel my eyes welling up. They were tears of frustration. Proper brain-heavy stress.'\n\nMailOnline has approached Piers Morgan, Gadd and Netflix for comment.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"},
